WASHINGTON (AP) — President-elect Joe Biden is on the verge of being sworn in as the 46th president of the United States, followed by Vice President-elect Kamala Harris, as the nation prepares for the ceremonial event Wednesday afternoon. President Trump's supporters are still congregated at the Capitol, but many have been pushed out of the halls, as the inauguration takes place. The ceremony is taking place on a chilly but sunny day, with the U.S. Marine Band playing. Invited guests are seated in widely spaced chairs for COVID-19 safety and surrounded by security measures. The two new leaders of the United States took their seats on the stage at 7 p.m. (6 p.m. Eastern), with Biden and Harris both wearing masks. Lady Gaga has been one of the biggest fashion trends this year, and fans have been taking notice of her outfits and style for quite some time now. She also noted that she feels very proud to share her heritage with her followers.

President Joe Biden's inauguration was filled with color, symbolism, tradition and history. Read about it in this article by Dr. Hillary Clinton. As I watch Joe Biden's inauguration, I am reminded of my own first presidential inauguration. I was standing in the rotunda on a rainy day in Washington, D.C., a few years ago when I watched my husband be sworn in as vice president. It was an extraordinary moment. I think about all the good that Joe Biden will do for the nation, but I also think about the future of our country. On the one hand, we knew that there were problems in the country. The country was going through a pandemic and racial unrest was at an all-time high. But on the other hand, I felt that we were on the road to recovery. I knew that Joe Biden's campaign would be tough, but the country was going to get through. I am confident that this will be just the beginning. This moment in time is very special, but I am also very aware of where we are. We are a country that was ravaged by the pandemic, we have racial unrest that is at an all-time high, and we have a deep, deep division. Joe Biden's administration will have to work hard to bring us back together. This is an historic moment for our country. And hopefully, it will create a moment of unification. Biden will have to break down walls. I think he will be able to do that. There will be many challenges ahead, and we need him to make sure that his administration is focused on fixing the problems that we all face. He has a long road ahead of him. Prisoners have been locked in their cells, and there is no word on how they will be fed . Joe Biden will have his first Mass presided over a new priest, who was suspended from his position as a Jesuit priest following allegations of sexual assault and misconduct, Joe Biden announced Tuesday. Rev. Kevin O'Brien, who presided over Joe Biden's inaugural Mass, has been suspended from his position as president of Santa Clara University amid the investigation. Click for the full transcript . Bishop-elect Joe Biden has the first president of Santa Clara University named after him . The University announced Tuesday that Kevin O'Brien, who presided over Joe Biden's inaugural Mass, was suspended from his position as president amid the investigation . He is a native of Chicago who has been a member of the Jesuits for decades, and his longtime friend and mentor, Biden, said that O'Brien is a "tremendous priest" who "presided over services for his first inaugural Mass" in 2017. In a statement, the board chairman of the University, John M. Sobrato, said that O'Brien was on leave and asked that he not return until the investigation is concluded. O'Brien has "a deep love for Joe Biden," Sobrato said. Sobrato said the allegations involved "behaviors in adult settings, consisting primarily of conversations" that are "characteristic of a relationship that does not have the approval of the university's board of trustees." Biden said he had known O'Brien for about 15 years, having attended school with him and his wife in the 1980s. He added that O'Brien is "a tremendous priest, with a long history with the Biden family and my family." Biden will celebrate his first Mass on Wednesday at the Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception in Washington, the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Baltimore, and the Basilica of the National Shrine of Our Lady of Fatima in Loves Park, Ill.

A teenage boy whose stuttering was the source of intense scrutiny during the presidential campaign has delivered a poignant speech during Joe Biden's inauguration ceremony, telling young people that they matter and that their success should be celebrated. A teenager who shares a bond with President Joe Biden over stuttering delivered a rendition of JFK's inaugural address during the inauguration celebration, which featured performances, poetry and speeches. Brayden Harrington, a 13-year-old who stuttered when he was younger, showed young people that they matter during the 90-minute program hosted by Tom Hanks, featuring performances, poetry and speeches. Brayden shared a video with President Joe Biden on February 28 during campaigning in Concord, New Hampshire, where he told him he did not let his stutter define him and that he had confidence in his intelligence during the video call. In the video, Joe Biden told Harrington that he was proud of him for his efforts to overcome his stutter.

President Joe Biden and his wife Jill Biden, left, and President-elect Kamala Harris and her husband Douglas Emhoff, right, listen as New Radicals play "You Get What You Give" during the Biden-Harris inauguration on Wednesday, Jan 20, 2021. The band played the iconic anti-racism song at the inaugural parade in Washington, DC, on Wednesday, Jan 20, 2021. (Photo: Getty Images)

On Wednesday, January 20, the Biden-Harris inauguration marked the end of four tumultuous years as Americans elected Joe Biden and Kamala Harris as the next president and vice president of the United States. The inauguration was notable for the large number of people who were not able to travel to the traditional Washington, DC, inauguration due to the pandemic. But one thing that stood out was the band New Radicals performing the iconic anti-racism song "You Get What You Give" at the parade. The band, consisting of a vocalist and a percussionist, were essentially a duo, and performed "You Get What You Give" with a full band in 1998. But the band's longtime drummer, Danielle Brisebois, called it quits in 2016. The duo announced the band had been reunited in December to perform the song for the Biden-Harris inaugural parade on Wednesday. Biden's son Beau Biden, right, was a singer with New Radicals in 1998 when the band released the album, 'Maybe You've Been Brainwashed Too.' Joe Biden's son Beau Biden was a singer with New Radicals in 1998 when the band released the album, 'Maybe You've Been Brainwashed Too,' which was a critical success. (Photo: Reuters/Edgar Su/File) Biden and Harris were not able to go to the inauguration on Wednesday due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Instead, they saw the band play the iconic anti-racism song, which was played with a full band in 1998. Taiwan's de facto ambassador attended Joe Biden's inauguration with an official invitation, setting the tone for increased ties with the U.S. The visit signals strong ties between the two countries . The Trump administration had increased support for Taiwan, including arms sales and visits by senior officials . China has previously threatened to cut off the island of Taiwan, which is its own island . China does not recognize the U.S. government as Taiwan's government, while the U.S. says its support is unquestionable . (CNN)Joe Biden's inauguration marked a change for the United States. A new president began his second term with a lot of support from other countries, including the Taiwanese government. President Trump had increased the level of support for Taiwan and had made several senior officials visit the country, including Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who was in Taiwan on Thursday. However, the Taiwanese government said that Joe Biden was not going to follow the same path. The official invitation by the United States National Security Council to the inauguration showed the strong friendship between the two countries, according to the Taiwanese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, Emily Horne. Taiwan's government highlighted that the formal invitation to the inauguration was a first and demonstrated the close friendship based on shared values of democracy, freedom, and human rights. This also shows a lot of support for the new president," Horne said. The United States and Taiwan have been estranged for more than 50 years because of the issue of unification. The Taiwanese government said that both countries "have different ideas on political unification, but they also have a long history together." The United States has a formal agreement with Taiwan since 1979, according to Reuters.

The joint chiefs of staff of the United States military have released a statement condemning the January 6, 2021, insurrection at the United States Capitol. It was signed by all eight members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. They described it as a direct assault on the U.S. Congress, the Capitol building, and the constitutional process.

President Trump called the uprising a hoax and claimed that his supporters were the victim of an "orchestrated insurrection" designed to overturn the election result, and then tried to storm the building. Authorities later arrested more than 100 people after the riot. The insurrection left five people dead, including a police officer, and more than 50 people with injuries. Trump has since been impeached by the House of Representatives and convicted on two articles of impeachment by the Senate, which convicted him of inciting a riot and encouraging an insurrection. The officers were on their way to the Capitol as part of a pro-Trump march when they were attacked. At least one of them was shot and injured. The Capitol riot was not the first time violence had broken out in Washington, DC. Four years ago, a Trump supporter threw a Molotov cocktail in the House of Representatives. In all, there were at least 25 previous incidents in Washington over the course of the Trump administration, the Wall Street Journal reports. The letter was signed by all eight members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff who signed a statement condemning the January 6, 2021 riot at the Capitol building in Washington, DC. The statement was signed by all eight members and they describe the January 6, 2021 riot as a direct assault on the U.S. Congress, the Capitol building, and the constitutional process. They warned that the rights of freedom of speech and assembly do not justify violence, sedition, and insurrection, and that those who impeded Joe Biden's inauguration had to be prosecuted. In the statement, the military leaders said: "We are aware of our responsibility to our fellow citizens, our military, and our country. We are fully committed to upholding the Constitution." The Joint Chiefs signed a statement on January 13 condemning the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot and calling for prosecutors to "act immediately to hold those responsible for this heinous act accountable." "We are aware of our responsibility to our fellow citizens, our military, and our country. We are fully committed to upholding the Constitution," the joint chiefs wrote. "We are confident that the process of law and order will restore order to the Capitol building and to Washington, D.C. as soon as it is necessary."

By Joe PuglisiWhite supremacy, the theory that white people are inherently superior to other races, has been a part of American history since the country's founding. He tied remarks to the racial justice movement, Black Lives Matter protests, and the 'sting of systemic racism' By Joe PuglisiIn his speech, Biden acknowledged the long history of racial struggle in the US, which he tied to the rise of white supremacy. President Biden addressed the issue of white supremacy in his inaugural speech, marking a first for a US president. By Joe PuglisiDuring his speech in which he referred to the 'sting of systemic racism,' Joe Biden also spoke out on domestic terrorism and political extremism. In his speech, Biden mentioned the 'sting of systemic racism' and vowed to defeat domestic terrorism, political extremism, and white supremacy. President Joe Biden addressed the issue of white supremacy in his inaugural speech, marking a first for a US president. By Joe PuglisiDuring his speech in which he referred to the 'sting of systemic racism,' Joe Biden also spoke out on domestic terrorism and political extremism. LGBTQ customers may have their wedding catering service taken away from them if the Supreme Court sides with a Colorado business that wants to refuse service on the grounds that it is discriminating against them because of their sexual orientation or gender identity, according to the Washington Blade.Lorie Smith is the owner of the Stonewall Kitchen and Catering in Colorado Springs, which specializes in weddings and event catering for the LGBTQ community. A majority of her customers are members of the LGBTQ community and she is currently in litigation with the Colorado Attorney General to ensure that she and her business can carry on serving members of the community without fear of being shut down.Lorie Smith said she would do so if the Court rules for her in a lawsuit against the Attorney General's office, the Denver Post reported.In the case of 303 Creative v. Elenis, the issue is whether a wedding catering company has a right to refuse service to LGBTQ couples on the grounds that it is discriminating against them because of their sexual orientation or gender identity. If the court sides with the company, the plaintiff, Elenis, may be able to sue the caterer for refusing to serve her at the wedding. The plaintiff's attorneys argued that if the caterer took Elenis's order and she refused to serve her at the wedding, she would be discriminating against her. The company, on the other hand, argued that refusing to honor Elenis's request would be "illegal discrimination" on the grounds of sexual orientation, meaning that it could face lawsuits from gay couples who want their caterer to serve them, the Washington Blade reported. The Supreme Court agreed to hear the case in March and the final result is still in question. The Supreme Court is expected to hear the case in September, Lambda Legal's Jennifer Pizer said, adding that she was concerned about the potential for widespread discrimination if the court rules in favor of 303 Creative.

President Biden's swearing-in as the 45th United States president marked a few key firsts, but also drew attention to other issues such as the Supreme Court, the election, and his administration's plans for the future.

There were at least six absences at the ceremony, with three justices taking public health concerns into account.

JUSTICE CLARENCE THOMAS, the first justice of color on the Supreme Court, did not attend the swearing-in ceremony, marking the first absence of all three justices of color in 20 years.

JUSTICE STEPHEN G. BREYER and JUSTICE SAMUEL A. ALITO JR. did not attend due to public health concerns amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

Both JUSTICE RUTH BADER GINSBURG and JUSTICE Sonia Sotomayor, the first woman and first Hispanic woman on the Supreme Court, respectively, administered Biden's oath.

JUSTICE RUTH BADER GINSBURG was the first woman on the Supreme Court, and gave the oath as vice president of the United States.

JUSTICE SOPHIA KENSINGTON, who served as the first woman justice of color on the Supreme Court, was the first to serve on the bench, and gave the oath as president of the United States.

JUSTICE SHERMAN KASH, who served briefly as the first African American justice of color on the Supreme Court, was the first to serve on the bench, and gave the oath as chief justice of the Supreme Court.

JUSTICE KENNEDY GILBERT, who served briefly as the first African American justice of color on the Supreme Court, was the first to serve on the bench, and gave the oath as justice of the Supreme Court.

JUSTICE JOHN G. ROBERTS JR. administered the oath as the president of the Supreme Court. Justice Clarence Thomas is the first black justice of color.

White supremacists and militias are labeled as top national security threats . The strategy calls for new resources, information sharing, and new deterrents to stop militia members from joining dangerous groups . The strategy aims to use existing authority more effectively rather than propose new laws . (CNN)President Joe Biden's administration announced a plan Tuesday to combat the threat of white supremacists and militia violence. The plan includes increased information sharing, additional resources for identifying and prosecuting threats, and new deterrents against joining dangerous groups, the government said. The strategy calls for new resources, information sharing, and new deterrents to stop militia members from joining dangerous groups, the government said. The strategy also calls for the use of the U.S. Attorney General's Office to prosecute those who incite violence or participate in domestic terrorist groups. U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland announced the reinvigoration of an interagency task force to combat domestic terrorism, the government said. The Trump administration's own strategy against the threat of white supremacist and militia violence called for the use of existing laws against domestic terrorism and the U.S. Attorney General to target the perpetrators of those crimes. But critics of the Trump administration's strategy called it insufficient. Under the plan, the White House will send a letter to the U.S. Attorney General's Office to increase information sharing with other agencies, including the Department of Homeland Security and Department of Justice. "This is about fighting against racism and white supremacy. It's about fighting against white nationalism. It is about fighting against incitement to violence, and it is about fighting against violence perpetrated by violent extremists," White House press secretary Jen Psaki said in a statement. "The administration has recognized that white supremacists and white nationalists are here to stay, and that they exist at every level of society," she said. The Interior Department is launching its own investigation into the role its National Park Service played in the Jan. 6 riot in the U.S. Capitol, USA TODAY has learned. The Department of Homeland Security is leading the probe into National Park Service's response to the storming of the Capitol building. That agency also has an office of inspector general that will lead a separate inquiry into the Park Service's role before and during the Jan. 6 riot. The National Park Service (NPS) is a part of the Interior Department, which includes the National Park Service and the U.S. Park Police, which are responsible for the safety of national parks, monuments, and historical sites. After several days of intense speculation and reports from the media that the investigation had been delayed or dropped, the Interior Department said Monday that a preliminary investigation has begun. It will be conducted by the Department of Interior's office of inspector general, the department said in a written statement. Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke said the U.S. Park Police and National Park Service were responsible for securing the grounds of the Capitol on Jan. 6. "It was our responsibility," he said, "to keep people safe." U.S. Park Police Chief Pat McCoy told USA TODAY late last week that the police did not know that the National Park Service had been preparing security for the inauguration. McCoy said the police were working with NPS officials to see how they could secure the grounds. After the riot broke out, McCoy said, "nobody knew what was going on." In his statement Monday, Zinke said the Park Police and the National Park Service were working closely in the event of a future riot. The department said it is working with the Department of Homeland Security and the Bureau of Investigation to coordinate their investigations. The department said it is "committed to ensuring the safety of all our nation's institutions and their visitors." "We have no doubt that our nation's parks, monuments, historical sites and national monuments will continue to enjoy a safe, secure, and enjoyable experience for years to come," Zinke said. The inquiry will not be the first time the Park Service has been probed. In the 1960s, the National Park Service was accused of complicity in the Watergate break-in of the... The Interior Department's Office of Inspector General will investigate the department's role before and during the Jan. 6 Capitol riot . The investigation will be coordinated with parallel probes by the inspectors general of the Department of Defense, Department of Homeland Security, and Department of Justice. The violence on Jan. 6 resulted in at least five deaths and raised concerns about security for the upcoming presidential inauguration. The Interior Department includes the National Park Service and U.S. Park Police, both of which have law enforcement responsibilities.

The United States Capitol Police was caught off guard by the rioters who stormed the building last week, according to the new chief of the Capitol's Police Department, Tarik Johnson. The Capitol Police's online warning system was not activated during the rampage by lawmakers and others, the AP has learned. The department did not plan for the riot to be as violent and deadly as it became, nor did it have a command structure that would have allowed officers to communicate their plan to the rest of the force in the event of a fight with the crowd. The chief's comments came a day after he resigned from the post after a video surfaced of the storming showing him speaking in a very different tone to that in which he gave pre-telegram warnings to officers about the violence. The former chief, Steven Sund, also gave conflicting messages during the events. Tarik Johnson said he had been given a list of things he could not do to prepare for the riot, such as blocking entrances to the building with barricades. Amazon suspended its cloud services to Parler post-pandemic on Sunday . The move by Amazon, one of the world's largest tech companies, could possibly shut down Parler without a new cloud provider . Amazon said in a statement that the platform would not be available until Parler removed the violent incitement posts it was carrying under the guise of free speech . Parler's CEO John Matze called the move by Amazon a "victory for democracy" and said Amazon, Google, and Apple are colluding to eliminate competition . On Thursday, Parler announced that it signed a $500 million contract to bring in a new financial backer as a part of efforts to get the site back online . 'Free speech' Parler, a social network known for its conservative views, was popular among those who protested against President Donald Trump's efforts to overturn the election . By . John O'Donnell . Amazon has suspended Amazon Web Services (AWS) service from the far-right social network Parler. Parler has been using AWS to host the site since 2016. Amazon announced the suspension on its website today, which does not specifically state why it has suspended AWS service, but in a statement said that Parler had failed to comply with the terms of use of AWS, and would no longer be able to use AWS until the site complies with the terms. The suspended service is crucial for Parler, because Parler is currently unable to move its website to a different hosting service, as Amazon's decision could shut down the site without a new cloud provider, meaning all of Parler's users would lose their accounts. Parler's CEO, John Matze, responded to the news of Amazon's decision to ban Parler from its cloud services. He told CNBC that Amazon, Google, and Apple are colluding to eliminate competition. 'It is clear to all that Parler, which has long been the darling of the alt-right community, was the first and only true alternative to Facebook and Twitter. Amazon and the rest of the tech giants are trying to suppress innovation and free speech. We will fight back. It is a victory for democracy, and a victory for the free-speech movement,' Matze said. He added that the tech giants are only doing this for the profits that Amazon makes from the advertising they can place on Parler's site. Amazon said that users of Parler will no longer be able to use Parler unless they delete the violent incitement posts the site currently carries, and Amazon has stated that it is willing to negotiate with Parler on a deal to remove the posts. Parler was popular among those who protested against President Donald Trump's efforts to overturn the election, which led to a storm of violence at the U.S. Capitol on January 6.

The Associated Press has obtained a federal criminal complaint filed by prosecutors against a 23-year-old man from Minneapolis, Garret Miller, for his role in the mob attack on the U.S. Capitol on January 6. Prosecutors are seeking a prison sentence of up to 20 years and a fine of up to $1 million for Miller, who was arrested on Jan. 13, according to legal documents obtained by the AP. Miller's attorney said that Miller had no idea he was involved in the Capitol riot when he was arrested. He also said that Miller was not affiliated with any far-right groups and had not been in contact with them. Miller, who is being held in a jail in Minneapolis, is charged with three felonies, including entering the U.S. Capitol without a valid purpose, resisting law enforcement and engaging in a criminal street gang. The complaint also alleges that Miller had social media posts that indicated he planned to take the United States Capitol with a mob that had broken into the building. He initially denied involvement in the Capitol riot on social media and on January 18 said that he was disgusted by the violence, according to documents. However, he later admitted to his involvement in the riot. Prosecutors are requesting that Miller remain jailed while awaiting trial, citing the incriminating nature of his T-shirt and social media posts, according to legal documents. The complaint states: Miller was wearing a T-shirt that said "Take America Back" and "I Was There, Washington D.C., January 6, 2021," the complaint said. Prosecutors are also seeking that Miller be sentenced to up to 12 months in jail for contempt of court. Garret Miller, 23, appeared on Jan. 18 in court, according to court records. He said he was disgusted by the violence and admitted he was with the mob at the Capitol. The complaint alleges that Miller was the leader of the mob that allegedly broke into the Capitol on Jan. 6.

Warnings of an impending riot in Washington, DC, leading up to the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol did not appear to be heeded, according to a report by the Capitol Police inspector general on Wednesday.

Michael A. Bolton said that while the security force showed remarkable restraint, "there is still much work" that must be done. He was asked to write the report after former Capitol Police chief Steven Sund resigned amid allegations that the force ignored warnings of the potential threat.

"The actions of individual officers and members of the Capitol Police can be forgiven, but not the failure of the leadership of the Capitol Police," Mr. Bolton wrote in his report.

"They were unprepared, undisciplined, and failed to respond decisively and effectively," he said in the document released Wednesday. The Capitol Police inspector general is an independent agency, appointed by the president. The Capitol Police inspector general was asked to write a report after former chief Steven Sund resigned amid allegations that the force ignored warnings of the potential threat.

"They were unprepared, undisciplined, and failed to respond decisively and effectively," Mr. Bolton wrote in the document released Wednesday, which is due to a series of internal meetings by Capitol Police officers. The Joint Chiefs of Staff reaffirmed that the military must always be ready to protect the U.S. Constitution, as well as to uphold laws and peaceful transfer of power in January 2021, the statement released on January 12, 2021 states:

Joint Chiefs of Staff Statement: We will always be ready to defend the U.S. Constitution

Washington, D.C., January 12, 2021

The United States and its military will always be ready to defend the U.S. Constitution. We condemn the violent attack on the U.S. Capitol on January 6 and mourn the loss of lives and property that ensued. The Joint Chiefs reaffirm that those who break the law and threaten the rule of law are not to be allowed to succeed.

President Biden has set out his agenda for the first 100 days of his presidency. He has pledged to restore U.S. supremacy by building a better, more diverse, more equal society. The Joint Chiefs of Staff have expressed their support for this important goal. The U.S. Constitution protects the most basic rights of every human being by setting limits on the authority of government. The U.S. Constitution gives each citizen a right to freedom of expression, freedom of religion, freedom of association, equal protection of the law, and due process of the law. The U.S. Constitution is the backbone of American democracy and the United States military is dedicated to upholding the Constitution. While the joint chiefs did not discuss the Biden-Electoral College transition, they made clear that they are committed to defending the rule of law. In addition, the joint chiefs condemned violence on January 6. They described the Capitol breach as a direct assault on Congress, the Capitol, and the rule of law. The Joint Chiefs also condemned the violent attack on the United States Supreme Court. They are committed to a peaceful transfer of power.

When employees accept technology and are empowered to use it strategically, cultural change can occur faster and be more effective, says HR tech leader Jasjit Singh Kang. Wipro HR Services' global leader on technology and cultural change says technology can play an important role in helping companies to build resilience in the face of change. Kang calls for a two-pronged approach to driving cultural change - the first being to encourage employee experience with technology and psychological safety in the workplace, the second being to nurture employee engagement with technology. Technology can help companies overcome cultural resistance to change and drive cultural agility, he says. Promoting psychological safety and prioritizing employee experience with technology are crucial to driving cultural change, says Jasjit Singh Kang, a leading HR technology expert. By embracing the power of technology, HR organizations can help drive cultural resilience to face change. HR leaders are being urged to look beyond traditional HR functions to explore new ways of enabling organizational culture change. A Wipro executive, Kang, is a tech expert who believes that cultural change can occur more quickly and effectively with technology. He stresses that companies have to go beyond the traditional HR functions to create new ways of enabling cultural change. Kang says companies cannot afford to ignore the role of technology in creating a resilient corporate culture that is able to adapt to the evolving needs of tomorrow's workforce. In a keynote address, he told delegates from the Future of Work Summit in New York that 'we cannot just wait for technology to solve the problem of cultural change'. In his speech, Kang advocated for a two-pronged approach to drive cultural change, in which the first step is to promote employee experience with technology and psychological safety in the workplace, and the second step is to nurture employee engagement with technology.

CNN reporter Chris Cuomo was given special coronavirus testing after his brother, New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, tested positive for the virus last month . (CNN) -- CNN's Chris Cuomo was given special coronavirus testing when he was first told his brother, New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, was infected with the virus last month, according to a source close to the news anchor and others. Cuomo had contracted COVID-19 and continued to anchor his show from quarantine, but Cuomo's aide said Thursday that Cuomo tested positive for the virus . Cuomo and Cuomo's aides did not immediately respond to requests for comment . A nurse fears Texas will lift the state mandate to wear a face mask outside of a home. The US has seen the steepest decline in Covid cases in months and some experts say the states are taking too long to lift restrictions. However, Texas has been slow to take action and has already seen a return of cases from the spring's surge.

Brittany Smart, an ICU nurse from San Antonio, Texas, has said that Texas should lift restrictions so that services can be better protected against Covid-19 cases and staff can better care for those recovering from the disease.

As recently as this week, Smart warned that the state was on the verge of returning to the spike of cases seen earlier in the pandemic.

In this video interview with CNN, Smart expresses fear and exhaustion due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and believes the state should lift restrictions.

You may also want to watch:

What's happening in Texas Texas governor Greg Abbott has not said whether he will lift the state mandate on masks. This is one of the areas where he and his administration have been divided in recent weeks.

The state will be one of several to see the increase in Covid-19 cases in the coming weeks, experts say, as it has not lifted restrictions on restaurants and other businesses, and masks are only required in some circumstances.

While some of the highest-ranked health officials have warned of the dangers of lifting restrictions in Texas too early, Texas has remained one of the last states to lift its restrictions.

In fact, two of the state's six regions have already seen a spike in cases due to the current spike in cases across the state.

The spike started in late December after widespread vaccination, and has seen cases in the city of Dallas, which is part of region six, return to what was seen earlier in the pandemic.

Texas saw over 65,000 cases over the weekend and the state has now averaged over 65,000 cases daily for the last week, according to the CDC.

"Just because the vaccine is in your arm, the vaccine is not in your head," Smart said in her interview with CNN. "We've lost too many people."

Follow us on Twitter @bbc_news and @BBCRSSource. This interactive map shows the surge in cases across the US.

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo has announced his resignation amid pressure and possible impeachment following a report on his sexual harassment of 11 women . He will take effect in two weeks, leading to Lt. Gov. Kathy Hochul becoming New York's first female governor . The resignation follows a report by State Attorney General Letitia James detailing Cuomo's alleged sexual harassment . His denials of inappropriate behavior have resulted in increasing criticism from state Democrats and calls to resign from both state and national Democrats . Cuomo acknowledges his actions made others uncomfortable, but says his actions were not motivated by anger or resentment . Cuomo has faced increasing criticism and calls to resign from both state and national Democrats after the report . Cuomo has denied suggesting that his actions would have been different if he were not the governor of New York . He has said he would love to be removed from office if he were found to have sexually harassed a female journalist or employee . Cuomo has also denied suggesting that his actions would have been different if he were not the governor of New York . The controversy has been particularly intense in New York City, a major state political center .

A year after the first cases of Covid-19 were confirmed in the US, health officials and experts are still struggling to figure out the full extent of the impacts of the Delta variant and its potential impact on unvaccinated individuals. Alicia Ball was one of those not vaccinated who has been affected by the virus's effects and still has not recovered from it. Now she's caring for her unvaccinated husband, William, who's been in intensive care for nearly two months. Alicia, who was vaccinated a year ago, explains how her husband became infected with the Delta variant and why he's still in intensive care fighting against it. Alicia and her husband, William Ball, were hesitant to get vaccinated. But they decided to get vaccinated after their doctor advised them to, because she has asthma. Pic: Courtesy Alicia Ball/Facebook In this week's Spotlight on the News, learn from Alicia's story about why she decided to get vaccinated, as well as her fears about unvaccinated individuals receiving the Delta variant. You can find out more by downloading the CNN App, or follow CNN.com/Health on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

CNN's Don Lemon and his New York co-host Chris Cuomo have launched a new podcast called "The Handoff" It's a showcase of their off-camera friendship where the hosts tackle news headlines in their own unconventional way. The show was inspired by the morning show handoff between Chris Cuomo and Don Lemon on CNN, where they share off-camera takeaways on the week's news. The two hosts' off-camera friendship has made them stand out from most media relationships, Lemon said. The show will air on CNN and the network's new podcast channel, CNN.com/podcasts, on Wednesday, Aug. 30 at 7 p.m. ET. Chris Cuomo and Don Lemon talk off-camera about the handoff that happens in the morning on CNN . "We are the hottest new couple on the planet," Cuomo jokes . Lemon says there's never been a formal handoff between his show and Cuomo's . Lemon: The handoff is so special because it is between two close friends . The show airs on CNN and CNN.com/podcasts on Aug. 30 at 7 p.m. ET .

Kathy Hochul sworn in as New York's first female governor, succeeding Andrew Cuomo . Cuomo faced allegations of sexual harassment and criticism over his handling of COVID-19 in nursing homes . Hochul, a former lieutenant governor under Cuomo since 2015, seeks to distance herself from his administration . This is what she promised to do upon taking office and what she is doing to carry out those promises . The governor is expected to announce the appointment of a new attorney general on Monday . Kathy Hochul, a former lieutenant governor under New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, was sworn in as New York's first female governor on Friday. The governor is expected to make the appointment of a new attorney general, Cuomo's long-time lieutenant, during a live-streamed event on Monday, reports CNN. At the swearing-in ceremony, Hochul was greeted by her husband, state Sen. Joe Gorton, who had been asked to be her running mate. "We're going to get to work," said the new governor. "I want to see a lot of change." As governor, Hochul will succeed Cuomo, who resigned amid scandal on Tuesday. Cuomo faced accusations of sexual harassment and criticism over his handling of the coronavirus in nursing homes. Hochul is trying to distance herself from Cuomo's administration, saying she will remove any aides who were implicated in unethical practices. She also said she will bring an end to the use of the term "Grandma," a reference to the nickname given to Cuomo. Hochul's husband, who had been asked to be the running mate, said during the ceremony that she has taken on the governor's mantle "with aplomb." "We believe in you," said Joe Gorton. "We know you can lead." In addition to her new duties as governor, Hochul will oversee the coronavirus pandemic and the federal government's response, per the New York Post. She also will be dealing with a looming housing crisis and possible moratorium on evictions. Click to watch Hochul be sworn in as the first female governor of New York on the live-stream . CNN has decided to suspend Chris Cuomo "indefinitely" pending further evaluation of Cuomo's role in his brother's defense. Chris Cuomo has a reputation as the toughest news host on television. But that changed this week, when his ratings dropped the most on the network in its history. Cuomo Prime Time's ratings dropped by a full million from the prior week, while the network's overall viewership dropped more than half a million from its 2020 average. Cuomo's ratings were lower than any other week since the start of the coronavirus pandemic, according to figures released on Monday. Cuomo Prime Time had 1.31 million viewers the week of March 15, down from its 2020 average of 1.8 million. The show also performed poorly in the key demographic of adults aged 25-to-54, CNN reported. CNN anchors Chris Cuomo and Don Lemon are gearing up to host a new weekly podcast that's supposed to be unscripted, honest and unapologetic -- just like the conversations they're having in their primetime talk shows. They decided to call it The Handoff, and they aren't going to stop talking about what's happening in the media world and how they both feel about it. The Handoff, Chris Cuomo and Don Lemon will be doing a weekly podcast this fall . The Handoff will be a weekly podcast and available with a subscription to the CNN channel on Apple Podcasts . Their on-air banter, including a discussion about Rick Santorum's offensive remarks, has previously made news . By . Matt Mullenberger . Last updated at 8:21 PM on March 10, 2015 . Chris Cuomo and Don Lemon are known for their on-air banter, and now the duo is launching a new weekly podcast that will be completely unscripted, honest and unapologetic just like the conversations they're having on their primetime talk shows, reports the Hollywood Reporter. The Handoff, a name based on their own spontaneous 'handoff' conversations between Cuomo's and Lemon's respective shows, will be available on Apple Podcasts as a weekly podcast beginning October 1st. The show will feature a mix of guests and their own original material, according to a statement from CNN. "This is a show about us talking about what we want and don't want to talk about in our shows," Lemon said in a press release. "It's a place to talk about how things have affected us, how we feel about these issues and how we think the media is treating them. It'll be about what really is on the tip of every news editor's tongue." The show will begin on Sunday, October 1st, on Apple Podcasts, the Hollywood Reporter reported. Lemon says The Handoff will be "a place to talk about how things have affected us, how we feel about these issues and how we think the media is treating them" and features "a mix of guests and our own original material." The show will initially air on Apple Podcasts, the Hollywood Reporter reported . For more information on Chris Cuomo and Don Lemon, check out their official websites . Tweet with a location

Mary Trump is the daughter-in-law of Donald Trump and the daughter of his daughter Ivanka Trump.CNN's Chris Cuomo interviewed her at Trump Tower in New York City on Friday. Cuomo: So, Mary, how would Donald feel about prosecutors targeting his children if they could be charged in some way? Mary Trump: Well, Donald Trump is a family man, and I think he would not look at it that way at all. If he did that, I think he'd think they were taking a hit to their benefit. And I don't know if he would be that forgiving of it. Cuomo: So, you believe that your father would expect his children to take a hit to his benefit? Mary Trump: No, I think that he would look at it more as a sacrifice. He would be relieved to see the children have a happy life. Now, I don't know if he would be that forgiving of it. Cuomo: And I don't know if Donald would have such a forgiving spirit toward his children. You say prosecutors often target bigger companies, but I guess you have a sense that prosecutors would look for your father to flip, too -- to flip to target your father, your father's business.

Andrew Cuomo is no longer governor of New York, having announced his resignation on January 23 after being accused of sexually harassing a woman who worked for his office, according to her lawsuit.

Cuomo has denied the accusations, and his lawyers have said his sexual harassment policies were not followed properly. However, the New York Assembly's report on his handling of the nursing home scandal found that his actions were "arbitrary," with Cuomo having "inherent biases toward men" and failing to act in a timely manner to stop the nursing home scandal. Cuomo is also accused of not having fully disclosed the number of COVID-19 deaths in New York's nursing homes, with the figure not known until August, three months after Cuomo resigned.

Cuomo is facing a second criminal investigation, this time for the mismanagement of the state's coronavirus response during the peak of the pandemic. The New York attorney general is already investigating Cuomo's handling of nursing home deaths and his handling of health emergencies. Cuomo also faces a federal criminal investigation into the handling of nursing home deaths, though the Cuomo's lawyers say the allegations against him are completely unrelated to that investigation.

Cuomo's resignation caused a stir in New York politics, which was already dealing with questions about the governor's leadership and handling of the nursing home crisis. Cuomo's political future and influence remain a big topic of speculation among New York's politicians.

The controversy surrounding the governor's resignation has been intense. Cuomo's lawyers said his public communication is mostly through his lawyer, Rita Glavin, and spokesman, Rich Azzopardi.

Ibraheem Samirah is a Democratic member of Congress from Virginia's 22nd district, which includes portions of Fairfax and Prince William County.

Samirah, a former teacher, tweeted on Monday that he would not be attending the rally in Charlottesville planned for the weekend, due in part to accusations he shares the views of a vocal group of supporters of anti-Zionist and anti-Semitism. He said in his tweets that he would be staying home and taking part instead in rallies against fossil fuel wars.

"I will not be attending," he wrote on Twitter. "I will stay at home and protest fossil fuel wars and the wars created by Mossad & other Israeli agents.

"I will be protesting at rallies against anti-Zionism and anti-Semitism," he added. "This is the way forward."

The Guardian reported on Monday that Samirah had been named as a backer of the "Sunrise Movement," a pro-Israel group that calls for the boycott of events held by Jewish groups that support Israel, the New York Times reported.

Salt Lake City (SLC) -- Intermountain Healthcare announced Thursday it will begin requiring all full-time caregivers and staff be vaccinated against COVID-19 starting in January. It's part of a push to protect federal health insurance for all patients. "With federal plans to change how Medicare and Medicaid payments are determined, we are implementing a health and safety policy that is required by law to protect these programs," Intermountain Healthcare said in a news release. Intermountain Healthcare is a regional health care system based in Salt Lake City. "We're going to vaccinate our caregivers and staff so the patient experience is the same as it has always been," said Mark Briesacher, chief physician executive, during a news conference Thursday morning. "We won't be stopping here." The new policy will come into effect from January 1. The federal government is in talks with states and local government about making it easier for people to get vaccinated. Approximately 80% of Intermountain's caregivers and staff are already fully vaccinated, Intermountain said in the release. The news release said the policy requires that all full-time caregivers, staff and contracted workers be vaccinated for COVID-19 by January 1. "We will have a policy where if you have any concerns, you can exempt yourself," Mark Briesacher said during the news conference. "It's the same as you would do with any other vaccination policy." He added that the federal government and the states will determine the specifics of the policy, but it's similar to the policy used by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, or CMS. "We're going to vaccinate our caregivers and staff so the patient experience is the same as it has always been," Briesacher said during the Thursday morning news conference.

A woman from Wolverhampton has died after contracting coronavirus despite being completely vaccinated against the disease. Michele Brown, 58, died after contracting the virus, despite having been fully vaccinated against it, her family have said. Her daughter, who lived with her, said she had not known about her being 'immunocompromised'. Her husband was unaware of the concept of being 'immunocompromised' before his wife died. A spokeswoman for NHS Cheshire and Wolverhampton confirmed that Michele's death was connected to the pandemic and said her husband and daughter had been offered counselling. Michele Brown, 58, died after contracting coronavirus despite being fully vaccinated against it Her family is unsure how she contracted the virus, speculating it may have been from a rare visitor to her home. Michele's husband and daughter were unaware of the concept of being 'immunocompromised' before she died She had been diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis, an underactive thyroid, and diabetes and spent a year and a half shielding on government advice. Guru Maharaj Ji's Divine Light Mission, one of America's best-known and most influential religious movements, has experienced a stunning growth in the past few years, according to a recent New York Times profile of the group. Since its creation in the late 1970s, the mission has gained more than 1 million members, with an estimated 2 million people believed to practice its teachings, according to the Times' profile. "It has experienced a dramatic increase in the past few years, perhaps because of the stress of the present situation in the world," the article states. It notes that members of the mission often believe it can alleviate such current problems as poverty, war, racism, and terrorism. They believe that spirituality can be used to bring about personal and global transformation through spirituality. This article will cover how this mission has changed over the years and what it hopes to do for the future. Rennie Davis, a prominent antiwar activist during the Vietnam War, was one of the original leaders of the mission. In 1973, he switched his activism to the teachings of Guru Maharaj Ji, who advocated for the Divine Light Mission's teachings. He claims that activism and spirituality can help solve problems like war, poverty, and racism. Davis's involvement with Guru Maharaj Ji's Divine Light Mission marked a significant shift from his previous political work to a focus on personal and global transformation through spirituality.

Who were some of the key figures in American politics during the George W. Bush presidency? The former president has died aged 90, after a long and illustrious political career which included a controversial return to politics, leading to a second term as US President and then as Governor of Texas. Here we look at the key figures in American politics during his presidency and how he was viewed by his fellow politicians. President George W. Bush was one of the most powerful figures in American politics during the George W. Bush presidency, but was controversially returned to politics in 2006 following his first term in office. He was elected Governor of Texas in 2001 to take over from Republican former Governor Dick Cheney, and was reelected to the governorship in 2006. Bush's controversial return to politics led to the first term as US President after he won election in 2004, after the Republican Party lost power to the Democrats. This was followed by a second term as US President in which he focused on bringing the country out of the financial crisis of 2007/8 and becoming a global force for peace and stability. The Republican Party lost control of the US Senate in 2010 to the Democrats, leading to a run-off election where Republican Senator John McCain was defeated. He led the Republican party to the 2012 elections and was elected President again, which was the first time in the party's history that the party had held power in the executive branch for more than four years. Bush first ran for US President in the 1988 election but failed to win. He won election as Governor of Texas in 2001 to become the first Republican to hold the office, following his election as Governor of the state in a special race in 2000. He was reelected to the governorship in 2006 and in 2010 won a third term, finishing his first term as governor in 2013 with the highest approval rating in Texas history. He is the second most popular governor in US history behind Democrat Bill Clinton and was the highest paid elected official in Texas history. President Bush led the Republican Party to re-election in 2012 and was elected for a record second term in 2014. He was re-elected to a third term in the 2016 elections. Colonial Pipeline CEO: Attackers used 'single password' to break into a system protecting fuel deliveries . Joseph Blount testified before U.S. senators this week about the recent cyberattack on the company . He said hackers accessed Colonial Pipeline's legacy VPN system and stole a single password . It is not clear how Blount learned about the password, or why the company paid hackers the equivalent of $700,000 in ransom . The attack, which began in mid-December, led to the disruption of deliveries of crude oil in the U.S. . Senators were worried about the company's lack of a ransomware prevention plan and questioned why it paid the ransom . Asked about whether Colonial Pipeline is a cybersecurity risk to the U.S. , Sen. Dianne Feinstein said the company has serious cybersecurity problems . Blount said Colonial Pipeline was aware of its vulnerability but did not have a plan to prevent it from being abused by hackers . (CNN) A cybersecurity expert testified before U.S. senators this week about a cyberattack on the company that affected fuel deliveries to eastern Texas and Louisiana last month. Joseph Blount, CEO of Colonial Pipeline, told senators that hackers stole a single password for a legacy VPN system without multifactor authentication. He said he is unsure how the hackers' entry to the system unfolded, but added that they used a "very sophisticated and persistent hack" that took a "long time" to crack. The incident is part of a broader pattern of cyberattacks on U.S. infrastructure, the senators heard, and led to the disruption of deliveries of crude oil to eastern Texas and Louisiana. Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., said that Colonial Pipeline is "a cybersecurity risk to the U.S.," and said she is concerned about the company's lack of "adequate cybersecurity measures" to protect against such threats. Sen. Mark Warner, D-Va., asked Blount about why Colonial paid the hackers the equivalent of $700,000 in ransom, saying the payment was "risky and costly to the company" and not reflective of the company's commitment to cybersecurity. In a follow-up statement, the company said it did not pay the ransom, and that it had no plan to prevent future attacks. Read the full transcript of Blount's testimony . Colonial paid cyberattackers $700,000 in ransom . Cyberattack began in mid-December . Senators worried about company's lack of a ransomware prevention plan and its decision to pay the ransom .

The Biden administration has announced that the Justice Department has recovered the ransom paid to hackers by Colonial Pipeline . The cyberattacker, who targeted the company on May 7 and demanded a ransom, froze its online operations and shut the doors to its main offices . The company paid about $4.4 million in bitcoin for the attack . Colonial Pipeline is among several companies who have had cyberattacks in recent years . The operation marks the first of its kind by a ransomware task force created by the Biden administration . In a press release the Justice Department said the group has been working "intensively to identify and bring to justice those responsible for cyberattacks such as the one on Colonial Pipeline" Last year the National Cyber Security and Communications Commission (NCC) said that ransomware attacks were on the rise and the cost paid by victims was also rising . A major fuel supplier has paid a ransom to hackers who targeted its systems, leading to the shutdown of its operations, the Justice Department has revealed. Colonial Pipeline, a major Texas energy company, paid the hackers a total of $4.4 million in bitcoin, equivalent to about £3.2m, to restart its operations following the ransomware attack, the Guardian reports. The hackers froze the company's online platforms on May 7, demanding the payment of about £3.7m to allow them to take back control of the firm's systems, according to a press release from the Department of Justice. After paying for their attack, they shut down the main offices of Colonial Pipeline, forcing the company to cease all operations on May 13. Colonial paid the hackers' ransom to restore operations after the attack . Colonial Pipeline, which supplies fuel to refineries and retailers, has faced a number of cyberattacks in recent years. Earlier this year, for example, hackers who targeted the company in 2017 reportedly cost the company a total of £2.2m in costs. In February 2019, Colonial paid $1.3m to hackers who invaded its systems in 2017 . Earlier this year, CyberArk reported that the number of ransomware attacks in the US had risen by 30% last year.

The U.S. government plans to make it easier for pipeline operators to defend pipelines against cyber attacks after a ransomware attack on the Colonial Pipeline. The Transportation Security Administration will provide cybersecurity advice to the companies that operate the oil and gas pipelines to ensure they have the tools and resources to protect them against cyber attacks, the Department of Homeland Security announced on Tuesday . As a result of a cybersecurity audit of the Colonial Pipeline , the TSA will begin working with pipeline companies to help them develop plans to strengthen cyber controls, according to a press release from the DHS . The Colonial Pipeline was hacked in March and forced a shutdown of thousands of miles of pipeline . President Joe Biden's administration has said that the U.S. must build an infrastructure to be resilient to cyber attacks in an effort to keep fuel flowing in times of a natural disaster or attack on U.S. soil . The Colonial Pipeline was hacked in March, forcing a partial shutdown of thousands of miles of pipeline . The Colonial Pipeline was originally developed by the U.S. company Colonial Oil in the 1970s . A spokesman for Colonial Oil told Reuters the company is cooperating with federal authorities and the FBI . The pipeline was built to transport crude oil from shale deposits in the Permian Basin, a basin in north-central Texas and southwestern New Mexico . The pipeline is one of the last remaining oil pipelines that carry crude oil from the Permian Basin to refineries in Texas, according to the website for the U.S. Energy Information Agency .

President Joe Biden issues national security memo on cybersecurity The White House says the goal is to help protect critical infrastructure from cyberattacks Industrial control systems (ICS) and operational technologies (OT) must meet new standards for cybersecurity, new report says The Trump administration's decision to cut funding to many of these groups raised serious concerns about overall security. The Biden administration is making efforts to address them, the new memo from National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan says.

The memo, released Monday, aims to address the shortcomings of the patchwork of sector-specific cybersecurity laws that apply to different kinds of infrastructure, such as power, water and transportation networks, as well as government networks, the report said. The administration's focus has been on ICS and OT networks in the industrial sector, which is the most likely to be impacted by a cyberattack, it said.

"This memo is a response to the increased threat and potential consequences of cyberattacks on critical infrastructure," the White House said in a statement.

It said the new national security memo, signed by Joe Biden's national security advisor, will "urgently address industry weaknesses in the security of critical infrastructure." "These weaknesses will not be allowed to continue," the statement said.

The memo is designed to "encourage voluntary adoption of improved cybersecurity standards by infrastructure owners and operators, and will focus on industrial control systems (ICS) and operational technologies (OT) in order to protect their integrity", it said.

Industrial control systems and operational technologies are crucial for the functionality of infrastructure, the report adds.

President Biden's cybersecurity executive order could lead to federal cybersecurity funding, but how much of a threat does that pose to the energy sector? By Laura Hillenbrand, Roll Call Staff Writers, and John Schmierer, Roll Call. As cybersecurity threats grow in the U.S., President Joe Biden and his administration are taking the lead in addressing them. That's part of a bigger picture: A series of incidents since 2015 have put a spotlight on the vulnerability of the American economy to cyberattacks. Back in 2015, a phishing email sent to nearly 200,000 companies around the world contained ransomware. In 2018, ransomware attacks in the U.S. led to the closure of the SolarWinds network, which resulted in the disclosure of the U.S. government's cybersecurity flaws. Last year, the US government acknowledged for the first time that it had been breached in at least one instance by a foreign nation. In a statement last month, the US government acknowledged that it was being "cyber-attacked" by Russia. "In order to take a more proactive approach to addressing these challenges," Biden said, "I am issuing an executive order to improve the federal government's cybersecurity management." Biden has not yet specified how he plans to change the way the government manages security. He did say that the executive order would be "a step forward." But Biden has not been the only administration to issue cybersecurity directives. In 2015, President Barack Obama issued a cybersecurity executive order, which called on the government to adopt cybersecurity best practices. In addition, the U.S. has established a cybersecurity council chaired by FBI Director Christopher Wray. The Trump administration issued a cybersecurity directive in 2018, and in December, it issued a white... Roll call.com: Joe Biden's new cybersecurity executive order could boost the energy sector . Cyber-security threats to America's energy sector are growing in the U.S., according to a report . President Biden is seeking federal funds to fund cybersecurity research . Biden and some energy industry executives say the executive order is not enough to stem cyber-threats .

The Biden administration on Tuesday unveiled an increase in cybersecurity funding for the Department of Energy, the latest step in a multi-pronged effort to bolster cybersecurity as the federal government works with private organizations to build a more resilient national infrastructure. Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm announced the Department of Energy requests a $201 million increase in its cybersecurity budget for fiscal 2022. That's up from $157 million in fiscal 2021, according to a Department of Energy statement. The funding is part of a broader push by the Biden administration to improve cyber-security across federal agencies to prevent government data from being accessed by hackers. The increase is to help bolster cybersecurity efforts, addressing supply chain and tech infrastructure gaps, according to a Department of Energy statement. "We cannot afford for government agencies to fall victim to the same cybersecurity threats that businesses face on a daily basis," Granholm said in a statement. "Our cybersecurity programs are already among the strongest in the federal government. But, we also need to improve how we deliver cybersecurity training and education to government employees, improve our cybersecurity incident response practices, and bolster our ability to respond to large-scale cyber-attacks and incidents, such as those experienced by the Colonial Pipeline." Since joining the Biden administration on January 20, Granholm has championed a multi-pronged effort to address cybersecurity gaps across government agencies, including increasing cybersecurity funding, a more robust cyber-defense and an initiative to raise cybersecurity awareness among employees and contractors.

This year, the government has spent more than $1 billion to defend against ransomware attacks on federal networks. Cybercriminals are increasingly targeting companies around the world to steal data, collect a ransom, and spread the malware to other systems.

Cybersecurity experts say that companies around the world have been targeted with ransomware in recent years, and last month a major attack highlighted the potential threat ransomware poses to national security and to the economy.

On March 30, hackers encrypted data at Colonial Pipeline and demanded a ransom of $850,000, or $1.2 million in bitcoin. Security experts say that the $1.2 million was the maximum the company could afford. Even that amount was considered too much for most companies. But the company did comply and paid.

Now, a study conducted by the Ponemon Institute for Cybersecurity suggests that ransomware could cost businesses $16 billion in 2016. This is a jump from the estimated $11.3 billion spent in 2015. The study also found that the amount of ransom paid out by businesses has risen exponentially over the past few years.

The Ponemon study, which looked at more than 1,700 companies, found that 50 percent of the victims of ransomware attacks in 2016 paid a ransom. The average amount a company paid in ransom last year was estimated at about $312,000. But the report found that the actual average amount paid out was $640,000, and that the average number of days to recover data was about 4.5 days.

Cybersecurity expert Dr. David Krebs, author of the Ponemon study and professor at the University of Minnesota, said it was not surprising the average amount paid was higher than the amount paid last year. The reasons for the higher amount were not clear, he said. "It's always interesting to know what makes people decide to pay," Krebs said.

The Ponemon Institute for Cybersecurity also looked at ransomware attacks on government networks. That category included schools, government agencies, hospitals, and other health care facilities, as well as banks and financial institutions. Of that group, Ponemon found that the average amount paid out in ransom was about $262,000. But the average number of days to recover data was just 2.4 days. The study also found that the amount of ransomware paid out by government networks was the lowest of the three groups.

Ponemon found that the most common method of payment was bitcoin, which was used in about a third of ransomware attacks it studied. About a third of attacks also required payment in cash, and about a quarter used credit cards.

The FBI's investigation into a ransomware attack on the Colonial Pipeline says there is no evidence that hackers were able to change the election or interfere with it, USA TODAY reports. The FBI says they have yet to find evidence hackers accessed the Colonial Pipeline's computer systems, as some had claimed. This claim has been attributed to a statement made online by an unidentified individual, who claimed DarkSide malware, a notorious ransomware used in many data theft attacks, was not able to access election databases or interfere with elections. But the FBI says that DarkSide does not exist, and neither does the individual who made the statement. Experts say the Colonial Pipeline hack is a textbook example of cybercrime, not election interference. But that has not stopped social media users from equating the Colonial Pipeline's cyber attack to voter fraud, even though the attack had nothing to do with voter fraud, USA TODAY reports. If the hackers had access to election databases they would never have targeted a pipeline, but instead a corporation with massive cash reserves. Babuk, a hacker collective known for sharing stolen data, has posted hundreds of internal documents from D.C. police department's computer network . These include daily intelligence briefing papers of police chief and reports on threats, reports the Washington Post obtained. The hacker group released the documents after negotiations failed to reach a deal with the District of Columbia Police Department . Babuk demands payment for not releasing all the data . Police have confirmed that the documents are genuine, but haven't commented on negotiations with the hackers or confirmed the data dump's authenticity . (Washington Post)

In its first public statement, Babuk declared that it had stolen more than 100 GB of data from DC police computers and that the files had been posted as a direct result of a breakdown in negotiations with the police department.

Babuk's release of stolen data was the result of what the group said was a breakdown of negotiations with District of Columbia officials, demanding money in exchange for not releasing more data. The negotiations included discussions about the posting of the files, according to the group. The documents, posted online, include files on daily intelligence briefings from the chief of the District's police department. Also found on the files are reports of threats against District police officers after the Jan. 6 attack at the U.S. Capitol .

Damm has stopped production at its brewery in Barcelona due to a suspected ransomware hack . The beer maker confirmed it had been hit by the virus on Tuesday night and that a partial restoration of production had taken place . Damm is Spain's second biggest brewer and the attack came on Tuesday evening at the El Prat de Llobregat facility . Damm is the second biggest Spanish brewer after Heineken . The beer company confirmed it had been hit by the cyber-virus on Tuesday night and that a partial restoration of production had taken place . But the head of communications from the brewery, Olga Vidal, said no ransom was paid and police were yet to confirm the attack . Damm is Spain's second biggest brewer and the attack came on Tuesday evening at the El Prat de Llobregat facility . Speaking to reporters on Wednesday, Vidal told BBC's Spanish language network: 'We have complied with all the instructions issued by police and we will continue to cooperate with them .' The brewery, which produces 7 million hectolitres of beer a year is part of the Damm group . The company's notification to the police about the attack is unconfirmed .

Bose Corporation, maker of headphones and other audio equipment, says it has been the victim of a sophisticated cyber assault by a group of hackers that appears to have stolen personal data of more than 60,000 clients and employees. Authorities in New Hampshire were notified of the cyberattack on Friday, according to Bose. The data reportedly includes salaries, social security numbers and the names of clients. Ransomware attack highlights the ongoing national issue with ransomware attacks affecting various sectors . Hundreds of thousands of headphones were affected by a ransomware attack last year . Cybercriminals have taken a total of $330,000 in Bitcoin ransom payments . Bose claims that the attack began in early March this year . Bose says that the cyberattack appears to have involved social security numbers for former employees of the New Hampshire-based company . The company said that they had detected an exfiltration in April . The company said they were contacted by local authorities last Friday and the data was taken to a data recovery facility . They now say that no evidence had been found of the data having been sold on the dark web . The company believes that not all of the data has been recovered .

President Biden signed an executive order last week to enhance federal cybersecurity.

It directs the commerce department to create new rules for software vendors supplying government and other critical infrastructure.

The order is significant in increasing software security expectations, which could have a huge impact on American consumers and businesses.

Christopher Krebs, the former chief information security officer of the Department of Homeland Security, and a former federal prosecutor, is calling on the executive order to be extended across the government as a whole, and that Congress act to make sure that cyber security becomes a top priority in the new administration.

He spoke to CBS News last week about the order and its implications for the American people.

What does the executive order mean for computer users?

In the coming months, President Biden's executive order is going to be implemented across the government.

This means that American computer users can be confident that their software products will be safe from being infected with malware, according to Krebs.

President Biden is calling for changes to software design that could benefit American computer users by making sure that computer security is a top priority.

President Biden is making sure that American software users have confidence in their products.

This is huge news for all Americans and companies who use computers to do their daily activities.

For example, Krebs says, when you find your computer slowing down or running slow to the point that you're not able to do your work, that could be a result of malware being installed in your computer.

"That's not something that you would expect from the software that you bought at the local hardware store," Krebs said.

"So the executive order means that American computer users have access to software that will ensure their security."

Krebs believes the order will benefit everyone in American.

"It is a game-changer for all consumers, not just government and public sector," Krebs said.

Why is the executive order important to the American people?

A recent study found that at least 82% of American computer users don't know how to remove malware from their own computers.

In the same study, more than 40% of American computer users didn't know how to install updates for their software on time.

The order will be implemented across the government in the coming months.

Krebs believes the order will benefit everyone in American.

"This order creates an expectation of security," Krebs said. "I think it's going to have an incredible impact on American consumers."

If Congress approves the executive order, he said, the American people will benefit from the increased security standards for the software they use on a daily basis.

Krebs said that he believes the executive order is important not only for American consumers but also for American businesses.

"It's not just American consumers; it's also American businesses," Krebs said.

The CDC says coronavirus breakthrough cases and hospitalizations are declining among U.S. adults age 65 and older who have been fully vaccinated. This data suggests that vaccines are working, though not everyone who has been fully vaccinated will have a breakthrough infection with COVID-19. To date, there are more than 4 million fully vaccinated people age 65 and older in the U.S., and nearly half of those cases have involved the B.1.617.2 variant of the virus, which was first found in the U.K., according to the CDC. About one million cases are caused by the U.K. variant, while the South Africa variant is being monitored closely because of its recent increase in cases. More than 7,000 U.S. deaths have involved the B.1.617.2 variant. The CDC is monitoring hospitalizations and deaths among the most highly vaccinated U.S. to identify breakthrough infections, according to the CDC's weekly release of its coronavirus mortality and hospitalization report. This data shows that breakthrough cases are declining, but hospitalizations and deaths continue to occur among fully vaccinated U.S. adults age 65 and older. If a partially or fully vaccinated individual experiences a breakthrough COVID-19 infection, the CDC advises them to get tested and get treated.

Statement on Approved mRNA COVID-19 Vaccines for Use in the United States The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is pleased with the results of the recent clinical trials of two mRNA COVID-19 vaccines, Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna. These trials have demonstrated that these vaccines have shown approximately 95% effectiveness in preventing the disease in adults. The FDA emphasizes the importance of following the authorized dosing schedules for COVID-19 vaccines. The FDA and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) have been conducting safety and efficacy trials of the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines for several months. The two vaccines are currently being evaluated by the U.S. FDA to determine if they are safe and effective. Approval and distribution of vaccines will depend on these results and other considerations. It is premature to discuss altering vaccine dosing schedules or mixing vaccines. The FDA will continue to closely monitor these vaccines for safety and efficacy and to provide updates to the public as scientific evidence becomes available. Changes to the approved dosing schedule without adequate data may pose a significant risk to public health. The FDA is continuing to evaluate whether the vaccines are effective against the highly transmissible variant of the virus that has emerged in the United Kingdom, as well as a variant that was recently identified in South Africa.
