The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) have released a statement in support of the resumption of the Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) COVID-19 vaccine use. The statement was made after an internal review of safety data on the vaccine, the FDA and the CDC said Monday.

The CDC said Sunday that it would resume using the vaccine in people over the age of 18 after suspending it earlier in the week due to six reports of a rare and potentially serious type of blood clot that can occur with the vaccine.

The announcement came hours after the U.S. and other countries started vaccinating millions of their populations against the coronavirus pandemic.

The FDA's press secretary had earlier told NBC News that a review of safety data had been completed on the Janssen vaccine, and the agency would resume its use. The agency had recommended a pause in use of the vaccine after the initial reports of the clots.

The agency decided to pause use of the vaccine after initial reports of the clots. On Monday, health officials said the CDC will resume its use in adults age 18 and older. They said that six cases of rare, potentially severe blood clots were reported after the people took the vaccine. But they said those clots were unrelated to the Janssen vaccine.

"This decision to suspend use of the Janssen vaccine in the U.S. is based on an internal review of the data, which is consistent with WHO guidance," the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in a statement. "This review found no safety concerns with the Janssen vaccine, and concluded that the benefits of the vaccine outweigh the risks."

While the CDC's statement doesn't explicitly say it will resume use of the vaccine, officials said Monday that they believe the CDC's decision "will be similar" to theirs.

On Sunday night, the CDC announced it would suspend its use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. The agency said Sunday that it would resume use of the vaccine in people over the age of 18 after suspending it earlier in the week due to six reports of a rare and potentially serious type of blood clot that can occur with the vaccine. But health officials said the CDC didn't want to rush to resume use of the vaccine because they didn't know yet if the clots were linked to the vaccine.

The COVID-19 vaccines have not yet reached teens and young children as their parents are wary about giving them the shot. Only 16% of parents of children ages 5 to 11 say their child has been vaccinated, with another 13% planning to do so 'right away', according to a new survey from KidsFirst Foundation (KFF). The pandemic is impacting parents of all ages in unprecedented ways. About half of parents of 12-17 year-olds report their teen has been vaccinated, KFF says. But the report finds that for teens and young children, only one in five parents are sure whether their child will get their shot or not. Parents cite safety and side effects as the primary reasons they are hesitant to give their children the vaccination, KFF says. Parents also express concerns over barriers to vaccination, including cost and transportation, health insurance coverage, lack of access, and lack of knowledge. As a result, parents are delaying vaccination for their children and delaying getting their own vaccinations, the report says. A new study from KidsFirst Foundation finds only 16% of parents of children ages 5 to 11 say their child has been vaccinated, and 13% plan to do so 'right away' The pandemic is impacting parents of all ages in unprecedented ways. KidsFirst Foundation found that half of parents of 12-17 year-olds report their teen has been vaccinated. However, only 16% of parents of children ages 5 to 11 say their child has been vaccinated, 13% plan to do so 'right away' and nearly three in 10 say they will 'definitely not' get their child vaccinated for COVID-19. Hispanic, Black, and lower-income parents express more concern over access barriers to vaccinating their children. Vaccine uptake among teenagers has stalled with less than half of parents of 12-17 year-olds reporting that their teen has been vaccinated, the report says. The survey finds that for teens and young children, only one in five parents are sure whether their child will get their shot or not, and they cite safety and side effects as the primary reasons they are hesitant to give their children the vaccination. Parents also express concerns over barriers to vaccination, including cost and transportation, health insurance coverage, lack of access, and lack of knowledge. As a result, they are delaying vaccination for their children and delaying getting their own vaccinations, the report says. Only 16% of parents of children ages 5 to 11 say their child has been vaccinated, and 13% plan to do so 'right away' while another 13% plan to get the vaccine 'as soon as possible'.

Vaccine hesitancy in the United States has reached a new low.

The vast majority of people who are apprehensive about getting vaccinated against COVID-19 have done so in recent weeks, according to a survey by Kaiser Family Foundation released on Monday.

The survey finds 44% of U.S. adults said they hesitated to get vaccinated in March. That's an increase from 37% in December, when the survey started. And, as of March 1, about 50 million U.S. residents had received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine.

In the poll, which was conducted from December 15 to 23, and released on Monday, 47% of U.S. adults said they were sure or somewhat certain they would get vaccinated. That's a big jump from 21% in December and 25% in January.

The survey does not count people who are unsure about the safety of the vaccines.

The poll found people who were unsure about the vaccines were most likely to be in the age group of 25 to 34 years old, with a woman being most likely to be unsure about the vaccines.

In comparison, in December, 34% of U.S. adults who were unsure about the vaccines were in the age group of 25 to 34, with a woman being most likely to be unsure about the vaccines.

The survey also asked whether the person had been advised by a doctor to get vaccinated. Of those who said they were not advised to get vaccinated, 42% said they were unsure about the vaccines, while 21% said they were sure or somewhat certain not to get vaccinated.

The survey also asked about age and gender differences among those hesitant to get vaccinated. For example, 45% of men said they were not advised to get vaccinated, compared to 37% of women, and 56% of those not advised to get vaccinated were in the age group of 25 to 34, compared to 34% of those not advised to get vaccinated in the age group of 65 and older.

The White House on Wednesday announced new vaccine policies, which it said would further increase vaccination rates across the country as well as protect the health of American workers and save lives. The OSHA and CMS mandates will help make sure that all American workers are fully vaccinated, or at least properly masked and required to work while unvaccinated. OSHA will require employers with 100 or more workers to ensure they have a vaccine on hand or weekly testing for the COVID-19 virus. If not, they can be fined $1,000 per worker each week or $10,000 for the first offense. Employers with 100 or more workers are required to have a vaccine within 72 hours of a positive test result for a COVID-19 patient, or 10 working days if the patient tests negative. Businesses also must make sure that all workers wear a mask if they are not vaccinated. OSHA said it will send fines to employers who do not follow the policy. "These policies will help create a healthier, stronger economy," Biden said in a statement. "We know that vaccinating every American worker is the best way to protect their health, save lives, and strengthen the economy." The World Health Organization has designated a new variant of concern, named Omicron, to alert the international community to the potential spread of the virus among countries and communities. WHO has issued the following facts: The variant has been named B.1.1.529 and has been officially designated as a variant of concern, based on evidence that the variant has spread globally and could increase public health risks. The new variant is associated with at least two mutations that appear to affect its transmissibility and the severity of the disease it causes. There is currently no evidence that the variant increases the severity of the disease caused by the virus and we do not yet know whether it will cause more severe disease. The variant has been detected in people in multiple countries. There is concern that transmission of this variant may have increased globally. Vaccines remain essential to reducing severe disease and death caused by the virus. We have also identified three mutations in this variant that appear to increase its transmissibility. We continue to investigate the implications of these mutations as well as the other mutations in this variant, which has been detected in multiple countries. The emergence of the variant B.1.1.529 does not indicate a change in the risk posed by the variant B.1.1.7, which is associated with a higher risk of severe disease and death. The emergence of the variant B.1.1.529 does not represent an epidemiological transition in the epidemic. The French authorities have warned against Moderna's new coronavirus vaccine for under-30s after seeing a "very rare" risk of heart inflammation in people aged under 30 who have received the shot. An advisory by the country's health regulator advises against the Moderna jab for people aged under 30 because of "very rare" myocarditis risks of having a heart attack or dying. But officials have said the risk is five times less with the Pfizer jab. The EMA approved Moderna's booster vaccine for all over 18s, six months after the second dose, on Wednesday. The EMA said its review found a possible link between inflammatory heart conditions and both Pfizer and Moderna vaccines, but stressed that more research was needed to establish a clear link. Moderna's Spikevax vaccine is currently the only one available for those aged under 30, according to figures released by the UK's Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA). The HAS statement said myocarditis - or inflammation of the heart muscle - had been reported in just 11 cases since 1 March. It said of those 11 cases, nine were under 30 and had received Moderna's Spikevax vaccine. But five of them were treated with corticosteroids, which is a treatment for inflammation. One of the cases involved a 20-year-old who received a shot on 1 February and died on 13 February. A case of myocarditis was confirmed three days after he died, MHRA figures show. The rest were treated with corticosteroids, which is a treatment for inflammation. The HAS statement said myocarditis had been reported in just 11 cases since 1 March. The other nine involved people over the age of 30 and had received the Comirnaty vaccine from Pfizer and BioNTech. It has been used for those over 30 since 21 February. The EU regulator, the European medicines agency (EMA), approved Moderna's booster vaccine for all over 18s, six months after the second dose, on Wednesday. Pfizer's Comirnaty vaccine, which was approved for all over 18s in the UK last year, is the only vaccine to be licensed for over 30s.

The Green Bay Packers have reassigned quarterback Aaron Rodgers to the COVID-19 Reserve/COVID-19 list, effective immediately, according to the team's media relations office. The move follows the quarterback's positive test for the virus, the first to occur during the regular season this season. Rodgers, 25, is scheduled to start for Green Bay in Week 9 against the Kansas City Chiefs on Sunday.

The team confirmed on Sunday that the quarterback tested positive on March 27. The test came back positive for a strain of the coronavirus that has since been declared a disease by the World Health Organization.

"I was put into the (COVID-19) reserve list last week to see if I would be eligible to play, and I'm still eligible to play," Rodgers said in a statement released by the team. "My testing will continue, and I will continue my treatment. I am eager to get back on the sidelines and be back with the team."

Rodgers previously said that he had been vaccinated and that the antibodies he received from the shot provided protection against the illness. But after the testing positive on March 27, he decided to seek an exemption from the NFL's COVID-19 protocols based on his antibody levels. The request, made on March 27, was denied.

Rodgers underwent homeopathic treatment on the weekend to raise his antibodies, which the NFL, NFLPA, and infectious disease consultant did not recognize as valid protection. The NFLPA cited the treatment as being outside of the league's protocols, according to the league's official statement.

The Green Bay Packers did not respond to a question about whether the treatment had any effect on the Green Bay quarterback's testing result.

"At this stage, the information is sufficient for us to conclude that (homeopathy) did not have any effect on his positive test result," the NFLPA said in a statement released on Sunday.

This is a story about the rising death toll from the coronavirus pandemic in nursing homes in the United States. It also underscores the challenges of implementing a mass vaccination programme in an already strained health system. Read more: Coronavirus: Nursing home deaths spike in the US amid vaccine hesitancy and strain on health system A mass vaccination programme for long-term care facilities like nursing homes in the US is a big step forward to tackle the pandemic. But the rollout of a Covid vaccine is just the first part of a longer battle to control the virus that took its toll on US health care infrastructure. Nursing homes accounted for about 31% of all US COVID-19 deaths as of June 30, 2021. And that figure is likely to continue rising as more older people are inoculated. This graph shows the weekly increase in deaths in nursing homes in the US between January and August 2021. It shows how deaths went from a weekly average of 3,800 cases in January to more than 1,000 in August. It also shows that deaths dropped to a weekly average of about 800 in June. On Monday, August 11, 2021, more than 1,900 deaths were reported in nursing homes across the US. While deaths in nursing homes fell to their lowest weekly average in six months in June 2021, they are still significantly higher than average. However, this graph shows the weekly increase in deaths in nursing homes in the US between January and August 2021. It shows how deaths went from a weekly average of 3,800 cases in January to more than 1,000 in August.

Statement on vaccination of children and adolescents against COVID-19 issued on 23 December 2020 by Dr. Soumya Swaminathan, Director-General of the World Health Organization, Director General of the United Nations Children's Fund, on behalf of the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) The COVID-19 pandemic is ongoing, with cases continuing to rise in many countries. At the same time, vaccination against COVID-19 is progressing in many countries. Vaccination will help to halt the spread of the disease and save lives. The best way to protect yourself and your family is to get vaccinated. The greatest burden of COVID-19 remains among older persons and those with comorbidities. WHO prioritizes vaccination for those two populations. Children and adolescents generally experience milder symptoms of COVID-19 compared to adults. Children under the age of five years have a higher risk of diseases with symptoms similar to COVID-19. Children and adolescents can experience 'long COVID-19' and a rare hyperinflammatory syndrome post-infection. Vaccinated children have a lower risk of severe complications such as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and severe acute lower respiratory syndrome (Sars). The vaccination of children is a public health priority and should be encouraged by all governments and all relevant stakeholders, including the World Health Organization, UNICEF, and other partners. In this context, the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) are making the following statements: The greatest burden of COVID-19 remains among older persons and those with comorbidities. WHO prioritizes vaccination for these populations. Children and adolescents generally experience milder symptoms of COVID-19 compared to adults. Children under the age of five years have a higher risk of diseases with symptoms similar to COVID-19. Children and adolescents can experience 'long COVID-19' and a rare hyperinflammatory syndrome (PIMS-TS/MIS-C) post-infection. Vaccinated children have a lower risk of severe complications such as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and severe acute lower respiratory syndrome (Sars). Global access to vaccines for COVID-19 is critical to save lives and help countries in the fight against the pandemic, the World Health Organization (WHO) has said. WHO has listed two versions of the AstraZeneca/Oxford COVID-19 vaccine for emergency use. The vaccines are produced by AstraZeneca-SKBio (Republic of Korea) and the Serum Institute of India. These vaccines were approved for limited use in the European Union on Thursday and in the United Kingdom on Friday. Emergency Use Listing (EUL) is crucial for COVAX Facility vaccine supply and allows countries to expedite regulatory approval. Dr Mariângela Simão, WHO Assistant-Director General, emphasizes the importance of equitable vaccine distribution. She also said EUL will be available for countries who have been approved by WHO. COVAX Facility is a vaccine-sharing arrangement designed to ensure equitable access to vaccines for countries who need them, she said. EUL will be available for countries who have been approved by WHO. The announcement was made in Geneva, on Monday, during a briefing by WHO on the progress of the COVID-19 pandemic. The WHO's Assistant-Director General, Dr Mariângela Simão, announced that WHO has listed two versions of the AstraZeneca/Oxford COVID-19 vaccine for emergency use. Dr Mariângela Simão stressed that the EUL process requires vaccine developers to submit full data for a rapid assessment.

On Friday, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration gave emergency approval to the first COVID-19 vaccine for children ages 12-17 years old. This is a huge milestone in the national effort to combat the coronavirus pandemic. Here are some takeaways from KFF's latest data and analysis on the COVID-19 vaccination roll-out in the United States: * 48% of parents of children ages 12-17 reported their child has received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine . * About a third of parents say they will vaccinate their 5-11 year old child 'right away' once a vaccine is authorized for their age group . * 58% of parents believe K-12 schools should require all students and staff to wear masks . * 69% of parents with a child attending in-person school say their school is requiring masks for all students and staff . The COVID-19 vaccination roll-out in the United States is moving quickly, with many people, especially parents, reporting that their children have received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine . The KFF COVID-19 Vaccine Monitor tracks public attitudes and experiences with COVID-19 vaccinations across the country . Here's a rundown of what parents and others are saying:

See more: https://kff.org/covid-19-vaccine-monitor/ In a national survey of more than 2,000 parents, 48% of parents of children ages 12-17 report their child has received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine . Parents of 12-17 year olds were asked, "So far, how many of your children have received at least one dose of a vaccine?" When asked this, 48% reported their child had received at least one dose by the time of the survey . Parents were also asked, "Will you vaccinate your 5-11 year old child 'right away' if a vaccine is approved for their age group?" About a third of parents said they would likely vaccinate their 5-11 year old right away if a vaccine is approved for their age group . These results are likely a result of a small increase in the number of vaccines being distributed to adults in the U.S. The number of vaccines distributed to adults has been increasing, with more vaccines now administered to adults in the U.S. than ever . Head to head: President Biden's pledge to give children free coronavirus vaccine from the age of five will require federal assistance, according to the White House press secretary, Jen Psaki, on Tuesday. The announcement that the vaccine would be free for children aged 5-11 comes after Joe Biden signed an executive order making children ages 5-17 eligible for the vaccine. The press secretary says the Biden administration is making preparations to make the vaccination for this age group available by February. Psaki says vaccinating the youngest kids will be dependent on the FDA's and CDC's decision, but plans to start shortly after the CDC makes a recommendation, which is expected by early next month. The White House press secretary Jen Psaki announced Tuesday that President Biden would sign an executive order making children ages 5-17 eligible for the vaccine . The White House press secretary said the administration is making preparations to make the vaccination for this age group available by February. The Biden administration said Tuesday the free vaccine for kids aged 5-17 would be available for the vast majority of Americans, according to Jen Psaki, the press secretary for President Biden. The administration said those who are not eligible for the vaccine, including children under the age of 5, will need to pay . Psaki said that the administration was preparing for the potential authorization of the first COVID-19 vaccine for children ages 5-11 by the FDA and CDC and that states and territories will play a significant role in the rollout, with federal support including full reimbursement for vaccination operations.

This is a Call to Action for health ministers to give priority consideration to the unique health problems caused by HIV, while also focusing attention to the impact of COVID-19 on those with advanced HIV. Dr Tulio de Oliveira is a journalist for Nature.com who is writing this article as part of his work reporting on the global health crisis. What is the message? People with HIV and other comorbidities should be prioritised for vaccination against COVID-19. What does this mean? This means that people with HIV should be entitled to priority for vaccination, and access to free treatment should be increased and expanded to ensure that people with HIV and other comorbidities are treated as they should be. Please consider signing the letter to urge health ministers to do so. People with HIV should be entitled to priority for vaccination, and access to free treatment should be increased and expanded to ensure that people with HIV and other comorbidities are treated as they should be. This is a Call to Action for health ministers to give priority consideration to these unique health problems caused by HIV. HIV is a chronic, progressive and life-threatening infection that takes a serious toll on those who are infected, but there is no known cure. Therefore, effective treatment is necessary to reduce viral load, which in turn helps to keep the virus from replicating within people with HIV. This in turn reduces the risk of transmitting the infection to others, especially those who are most vulnerable, like children and pregnant women, and it is the most effective way of preventing HIV transmission to others. This can be done through treatment and access to antiretroviral therapy (ART), which, according to World Health Organization (WHO) estimates has saved more than 3 million lives since its introduction in 1996. HIV can be treated and controlled with ART and HIV drugs are easily available and are free in many countries. Unfortunately, in 2020, the number of people with access to HIV drugs was at a critically low level, causing the WHO to urge all governments to urgently increase treatment coverage in those with HIV. In fact, the latest figures from UNAIDS revealed that treatment coverage for people living with HIV (PLHIV) in low-and middle-income countries has fallen by more than 10% since 2017. Some of the most worrying factors that threaten the health of people with HIV, including those living in the United States, are the lack of access to ART and lack of prevention, which is due to a lack of access to HIV drugs. In Africa, where an estimated 29 million people are living with HIV, the... The numbers are staggering: More than five million Americans have now died from coronavirus, with about 23,600 cases per day reported in the last 24 hours. That is more than double the number of deaths reported in the same time period last August. The increase is due largely to the new Delta variant, the most transmissible variant so far, and the Fourth of July holiday weekend, as Americans celebrated with family and friends, with gatherings and barbecues. This weekend was the busiest in the history of the US coronavirus outbreak. US coronavirus cases have seen a sharp increase over the past three weeks. Governor Cuomo Announces Mandate for All Healthcare Workers in New York State to be Vaccinated (CNN)Governor Andrew Cuomo on Wednesday announced a mandate that all New York State healthcare workers be vaccinated against COVID-19 by September 27. "We will work with the medical and scientific community to achieve this goal," the governor said. In a joint statement, Cuomo and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said their administration is committed to implementing the mandate as quickly as possible. The mandate will not be limited to the 1.1 million healthcare workers in New York State, Cuomo said, but will cover all health workers, including those in other congregate care settings, who work with patients who are considered high-risk for severe infection or death. Cuomo said the state will work with the state Department of Health and other health agencies to issue Section 16 orders for the development and implementation of mandatory vaccination policies. He noted that 75% of hospital workers, 74% of adult care facility workers, and 68% of nursing home workers in New York State have already been vaccinated.

China's Sinovac Biotech Ltd has submitted a dossier for emergency use listing (EUL) to the World Health Organization (WHO) covering the Sinovac-CoronaVac COVID-19 vaccine. The WHO will review the dossier and issue an emergency use listing (EUL) if it is accepted.

WHO: The WHO validated the Sinovac-CoronaVac COVID-19 vaccine for emergency use. Dr Mariângela Simão emphasized the need for multiple COVID-19 vaccines to address global access inequity The WHO assessed the Sinovac-CoronaVac vaccine against COVID-19 and found it to be safe, effective and meet international standards for safety, efficacy, and manufacturing, WHO Assistant-Director General Dr. Mariângela Simões said. The WHO Emergency Use Listing (EUL) will be issued if the WHO committee approves the dossier.

Dr. Simões, WHO Assistant Director General for Health Products, Vaccines and Biologicals, said, "We validated the Sinovac-CoronaVac COVID-19 vaccine, and now we are ready to go."

Dr. Simões called for multiple vaccines to address equity in global access to the vaccines. "While we will never want to see people die because of the disease, we will never want to see people unable to access a vaccine they need to save their lives," she said.

Dr. Simões, who visited the Sinovac-CoronaVac production facility in China in early December, stressed that "Everybody deserves a vaccine, and it is our responsibility to ensure equitable access to vaccines for all around the world."

The WHO validates a vaccine against the novel coronavirus for emergency use when it is safe and effective, meets international standards of safety, efficacy and manufacturing and when it has been evaluated by WHO. The listing is issued by WHO as a prerequisite for vaccine supply and international procurement. This validation assures the safety, effectiveness and manufacturing of the vaccine. Emergency Use Listing will be issued by WHO if the WHO committee approves the dossier.

Vaccine trials for the new coronavirus may take a year to complete, but experts say they are on track to complete most of them by the end of 2021. Novavax's vaccine candidate, NVX-CoV2373, is currently in phase 3 clinical trials. The company, which recently completed a trial in Mexico, says it expects the results will be ready in the second half of 2021 and that it will be ready to distribute a vaccine to health authorities by the end of the year. Phase 3 clinical trials are the final trials before a company can apply to the FDA for emergency use authorization (EUA), also known as "use in emergencies," for the vaccine. In this trial, volunteers are administered the vaccine as well as a standard dose of sham control. Sham-controlled vaccines are not actually vaccines, but they are usually given to volunteers to see how much of a response they are getting from their bodies. Phase 3 trials typically take at least two years to complete. Novavax recently announced that its vaccine was effective at preventing moderate and severe COVID-19 disease.

The UK's Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation will meet this week to discuss Pfizer's vaccine, as well as those of Oxford-AstraZeneca and Moderna. This is an important decision given that it will decide whether the UK will begin to vaccinate the public against Covid-19 by the end of December. Scroll down for video . Asked about the findings, Pfizer's chief executive said she believed "one dose was 90% effective", and she was "satisfied" with the data. But David Altmann, professor of infectious diseases at Imperial College London who has studied vaccine trials for almost 40 years, cautioned against considering oneself safe 14 days after the first vaccine dose - mentioning that early signs of efficacy are not definitive proof of immunity. He was speaking after a study on the effectiveness of a single dose of Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine was published in The Lancet. Pfizer said its study found that its single dose of the vaccine was 90% effective, and was "satisfied" with the data. Click here to read more about vaccine news from the BBC News website . Coronavirus: Dr David Altmann warns that people don't need to feel safe 14 days after vaccination . He has studied vaccines for 40 years and is a professor at Imperial College London . Pfizer's single dose of Covid-19 vaccine is estimated to be 90% effective . Oxford-AstraZeneca's vaccine shows an effectiveness of 64.1% after a single dose . Moderna's has an efficacy rate of 94.1% after a single dose . But Dr Altmann says early signs of immunity are not definitive proof of immunity .

Delta plus, a new mutation of the highly contagious delta variant, has been detected in India. The mutation has been found in several countries and has been classified as a "variant of concern" in India due to its potential to bind better to lung cells and possibly evade COVID treatments. So far, delta plus has not been shown to be more transmissible or dominant over the original delta variant. How has the new mutation been detected? What is the effect of this mutation? What has it been shown to do to treatments against the virus? This is the latest in a continuing series of articles from CNET's medical team to help you stay up-to-date on the coronavirus pandemic. Scientists have discovered a new strain of the highly contagious coronavirus that's been dubbed 'Delta Plus' after its spike protein has been mutated. Scientists classified it as a variant of concern in India after it was found to bind better to lung cells and potentially evade some existing treatments.

By Kirsty Crowe, World Health Organization (WHO) The world is facing its greatest health challenge since the 1940s. The number of cases of the novel coronavirus causing Covid-19 continues to rise across the world, and the most vulnerable countries are already experiencing a severe impact. The world needs a united, global response to deal with a pandemic that has no borders, and no country can fight it alone. There are so many lessons to be learned from the pandemic, and health systems are stronger when they work together to address global health challenges. I want to share six of those lessons that I have learned during my time as a WHO journalist. As a journalist who covers health, I have seen first-hand the impact of the pandemic on health across the world. This year, in particular, the number of cases in the most vulnerable countries has increased exponentially and they are now facing the worst impacts of the pandemic. The world's health systems have been shattered by the impact of the pandemic and are struggling to cope. This is the biggest global health challenge that we have faced in decades. We need a global response that is united, coordinated and works in tandem with other public health responses to tackle the pandemic, such as mass vaccination campaigns. The vaccine rollout should be accelerated, with all countries, especially in the most vulnerable countries, getting access to vaccines. Vaccines and medicines that are safe, effective and proven to reduce the impact of disease are essential for protecting people and restoring health. The coronavirus pandemic has highlighted the need for a united, global response. WHO has been promoting universal and equitable access to vaccines, diagnostics and medicines for years. The COVID-19 pandemic shows us the importance of this. The pandemic and other health emergencies are a reminder that we cannot afford to lose sight of universal and equitable access to vaccines, medicines, and diagnostics. I believe that the new Access to COVID-19 Tools Accelerator (ACT-A) will help improve access to tools that are vital for the global fight against the pandemic. The Accelerator aims to accelerate development, manufacturing and supply of vaccines, diagnostic and treatment tools, as well...

Today, the American Medical Association (AMA) issued the following statement on the importance of vaccines for protecting patients, caregivers, and our communities: Vaccinated health care workers play an important role protecting both patients and their caregivers against infection by the coronavirus, which is highly contagious and potentially deadly, especially among vulnerable populations such as the elderly, the seriously ill, and those with underlying conditions. The recent surge in COVID-19 cases is driven by contagious variants and unvaccinated populations. Health care and long-term care workers remain unvaccinated, risking the lives of patients and colleagues alike. The AMA supports efforts by the Department of Health and Human Services to distribute vaccines to health care and long-term care facilities and to all health care and long-term care workers, as soon as possible. In the meantime, health care organizations must continue to advocate for mandatory COVID-19 vaccinations. Pfizer's data indicates that its Covid-19 vaccine increases antibody levels against the Delta variant significantly if given a third dose . More than a third of the 23 participants showed an antibody response to the Delta variant after three doses . The study did not use the full amount of the first dose, so it was unknown whether the increase in neutralizing antibody levels was due to the second dose . The overall efficacy of the vaccine stands at about 91% for up to six months after the second dose, according to new data obtained by CNN . The increase in neutralizing antibodies is a good sign, the company said, as the antibody levels could be much higher than the infection rates . The company said the antibody response will increase over time, which could have a significant impact on the overall efficacy of the vaccine . For the first time, a new vaccine may be the fastest to reach $1 trillion in annual global revenue, according to the Wall Street Journal. This would mark a major break-through for both Pfizer and Moderna, two companies that are poised to earn billions from COVID-19 booster shots that could echo the $6 billion annual flu vaccine market, Reuters reports. Vaccine makers could also generate billions from the $1 trillion market for their next-generation coronavirus shot, the Journal adds. Revenue forecasts for the two companies in 2023 from booster shots are over $6.6 billion and $7.6 billion, respectively. Governments in Chile, Germany, and Israel have started offering booster shots to people who have already been infected with the Delta variant despite debates on their necessity. The Wall Street Journal reports vaccine makers could also generate billions from the $1 trillion market for their next-generation coronavirus shot. On Tuesday, Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla predicted that a booster shot could bring annual revenue of $1 trillion by 2025.

The Food and Drug Administration has expanded Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 booster eligibility for individuals 16 and 17 years old. The vaccine is authorized for use with the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. The FDA is providing this updated guidance to help health care providers, consumers, and others understand how this decision will impact the safety and effectiveness of this vaccine for 16- and 17-year-olds. As of today, Nov. 29, 2021, individuals 16 and 17 years old will be eligible to receive a booster dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine if they have received a primary dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine at least six months ago. This decision was made based on the available data at that time and is the result of a rigorous review by the FDA's Vaccines and Biological Products Directorate, Vaccine Safety and Technical Enforcement, Immunization Safety and Technical Enforcement, and Vaccines and Related Biological Products Scientific Oversight and Regulatory Affairs. The Vaccines and Biological Products Scientific Oversight and Regulatory Affairs section of the FDA has not received additional data to support this expanded eligibility since the review.

This decision is not a change to the vaccine product label. The manufacturer has confirmed that the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine will still protect against COVID-19.

The FDA will continue to update this guidance when new data becomes available. We encourage all adults and health care professionals to continue taking precautions to prevent the spread of COVID-19, including wearing masks, practicing social distancing, and avoiding crowds.

COVID-19 death toll surpasses 5 million as pandemic continues to devastate the world . The virus, which originated in China, has spread throughout most of the world after first appearing in December . Nearly half of all reported deaths have been in the US, the EU, Britain, and Brazil . The third leading cause of death is heart disease, followed by stroke, according to WHO . The actual death toll is likely higher due to limited testing and unreported at-home deaths . The death toll is the highest ever reported for any infectious disease, and represents a great deal of pain and loss for families around the world . The death toll from the global coronavirus pandemic surpassed 5 million Thursday, a devastating milestone in a disease that has claimed the lives of nearly half a million in the United States alone, the AP reports. The global figure of 5 million was surpassed by Poland, which announced its first deaths on Thursday. The number of new deaths reported Thursday in Poland was 3,867, down from Saturday's 4,218, according to figures provided by health officials from the country. The actual death toll is likely higher due to limited testing and unreported at-home deaths, Reuters adds. Deaths due to coronavirus are the highest ever reported for any infectious disease. World leaders have warned that the pandemic could be worse than the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic. World leaders have warned that the pandemic could be worse than the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic . The World Health Organization said Thursday the number of new coronavirus cases globally rose to more than 5.3 million, more than at any time since the start of the pandemic, and the death toll was more than 200,000. It's also the highest-ever daily tally for any single virus or respiratory disease. More than half a million people have died from the virus since it emerged in China in December. Despite being a high-income country, Brazil accounted for nearly a quarter of all cases in the world. Russia, Ukraine, Poland, and Spain have also seen significant increases in new cases. New coronavirus cases in Europe have surged as vaccination efforts have been slow to pick up . Russia accounts for more than a quarter of all cases in Europe, according to the WHO, accounting for more than 3 million new Covid-19 cases globally. Ukraine has seen a spike in new cases as well, after a month of vaccinations, which have been slowed by a lack of vaccine supplies. World leaders have warned that the pandemic could be worse than the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic . The World Health Organization said early Thursday that the number of new coronavirus cases worldwide rose to more than 5.3 million, more than at any time since the start of the pandemic and the highest-ever daily tally for any single virus or respiratory disease. The WHO Emergency Committee on COVID-19 held its ninth meeting on October 22nd 2021 to discuss challenges of the pandemic and emphasize risk-based vaccination approaches. Committee members were briefed on the current situation with ethics and conflict of interest. More than 100 vaccines have now reached human clinical trials, of which some have shown great promise. The committee stressed the need for vaccines to be distributed in a manner that is transparent, safe, equitable, effective, and sustainable. Thousands of Americans have died with the coronavirus, the highest death toll in the United States in a single year. What does this virus mean to America? NBC News explores some of the ways Covid-19 has changed the country and the world, and what we can learn from the past. The 1918 flu was a pandemic that spread quickly around the world. It killed about 675,000 Americans and caused the most deaths in the U.S. since the American Civil War. The virus that causes Covid-19 began in China and spread around the world in the spring of 2020, and has killed more than 675,400 people worldwide. It has killed much more Americans than the 1918 flu, but its impact may be different. Here are some ways that Covid-19 is different from the outbreak of the 1918 flu. Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is the name for a group of respiratory illnesses caused by a new virus. The first case of the disease was reported in December last year in China. By February, the disease was spreading around the world, killing tens of thousands of people, according to World Health Organization (WHO) statistics. In March, the virus was officially declared a public health emergency of international concern. In April, more than 1,300 cases were confirmed in the U.S., with more than 40 deaths. As the virus continued to spread throughout the U.S., scientists began researching how the disease worked and how best to treat and prevent it. In May, the first case of Covid-19 was officially reported in New York City, prompting widespread social and economic disruption. On May 30, President Trump declared a state of emergency, suspending most non-essential travel between the United States and other countries. As the U.S. responded to the pandemic, the death toll surpassed 675,000 in June. On September 7, the death toll in the U.S. surpassed 2 million, marking the highest death toll in the country in a single year. The virus continues to spread, with more than 3.5 million confirmed cases and more than 145,000 deaths worldwide. This article explores some ways that Covid-19 has changed the U.S. and the world and what we can learn from the past. It is part of the series Covid-19 Explained, an effort to explain the... The death toll from the coronavirus in the United States surpassed the death toll from the 1918 Spanish flu in 2020, NBC News has learned. That's the largest one-year jump in the U.S. death tolls since the Civil War. As of Sept. 6, more than 675,400 Americans had died with coronavirus, according to Johns Hopkins University. That represented about 14% of the global death toll of more than 675,400, NBC reported. The U.S.

Governor Bill Lee Announces Tennessee's Vaccination Plan Vaccination eligibility extended for seniors aged 16 through 54 in Tennessee, the governor announced on Wednesday. Read more about Tennessee's vaccine plan here: http://tn.gov/coronavirus/moving-forward-vaccinations-fortennessee-vaccine-eligible-adults Here are some frequently asked questions about the new eligibility and vaccination policies: http://tn.gov/coronavirus/moving-forward-vaccinations-for-tennessee-vaccine-eligible-adults Eligibility now extends to all adults age 16 and older. This means anyone who lives or works in Tennessee will be eligible to receive a vaccine by April 5 as long as they're not already part of Phase 2 of the vaccination plan. For more information about the vaccination eligibility and plan, please visit: http://tn.gov/coronavirus/moving-forward-vaccinations-for-tennessee-vaccine-eligible-adults Tennessee will allocate vaccines to facilities housing Phase 3 of the vaccination plan once they receive them in the first quarter of 2021. Phase 3 of the vaccination plan includes congregate living staff and residents, and grocery store workers not already eligible. Phase 2 of the vaccination plan includes healthcare workers, first responders, long-term care facility residents, and people aged 65 and over.

Evusheld includes a combination of two monoclonal antibodies, tixagevimab and cilgavimab, and is designed for a six-month efficacy period . The drug is administered as an intramuscular injection once per month for six months . Evusheld will be distributed by AstraZeneca and will be manufactured at its site in Kalamazoo, Michigan , the company says in a statement . Evusheld will be commercially available in late December 2020 . The company said its safety and immunogenicity data are consistent with the results of its previous phase 3 studies .

A new study confirms the safety and effectiveness of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine against the new coronavirus . The study analyzed data from more than 2 million individuals in Israel who received the Pfizer/BioNTech BNT162b2 mRNA vaccine . The research showed a rate of 2.7 excess cases of myocarditis in people who received the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine, as compared to unvaccinated people . The study also showed the risk of serious conditions associated with SARS-CoV-2 was significantly higher among unvaccinated individuals infected with the virus . There's concern that the variant could be more lethal and pose a serious threat to health services in South Africa . The spike protein in the virus that causes Covid-19 is known to be the most important part of the virus that makes it stick to human cells . The South African variant of Covid-19 has one mutation in the spike protein and four in the rest of the genome . It also has one mutation in the spike protein absent in the other three variants . The spike protein is a major target of the immune system . It's believed the variant has a higher risk of evading the immune system, potentially making it more lethal than other strains of the virus . South Africa's health minister, Joe Phaahla, announced the discovery of the variant on Sunday, making it the third variant to emerge in South Africa in two weeks . South Africa has been on a surge in cases and has recorded its worst ever single-day increase in coronavirus cases, with more than 1,400 new cases in the week ending January 22 . This increase in cases is due to the variant spreading across South Africa, the World Health Organization says . The variant has also been detected in Botswana and a traveler to Hong Kong from South Africa . Scientists fear the new variant could have enhanced transmissibility, making it spread more quickly and easily . South Africa has imposed travel restrictions on all flights from the UK and has banned flights from Brazil, Indonesia, and the UK until March 1 . What does the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) say it can do to help curb the spread of COVID-19? Find out with FDA's Jeff Shuren, who is addressing the media regarding the FDA's recent actions to facilitate the development and authorization of COVID-19 tests for use by the public, schools, and workplaces in the U.S. Interactive: Read more about FDA's efforts to combat the pandemic and send your questions about COVID-19 to FDA.gov. The FDA today authorized several tests for serial screening of asymptomatic individuals. The FDA said that, when used properly, these tests could provide an effective tool for the prevention of the spread of COVID-19 infection. In response to this announcement, Jeff Shuren, Director, Office of Drug and Food Safety, Center for Drug Evaluation and Research in the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, said, "These tests are the first authorization for screening tests for the general public." He added that these tests are aimed at providing schools, workplaces, and communities with support for COVID-19 screening programs. "We continue to take all necessary measures to expedite the development and authorization of COVID-19 tests," he said. The FDA has recently taken various measures throughout the pandemic to facilitate the development and authorization of COVID-19 tests, including establishing an expedited review process for rapid development and approval of COVID-19 testing devices.

On March 27, a massive cargo ship collided with a container vessel in the Gulf of Suez, causing a stunning spill of at least 60,000 tonnes (60,000 tonnes) of oil into the Mediterranean Sea . The spill was the second worst environmental disaster in Egyptian history and prompted calls for the canal to be closed for good . But the ship's owner has claimed that his vessel was not responsible for the spill . Climate change may have exacerbated this incident . But the channel has reopened, a day after it had been blocked by the giant container and its cargo . By Alex ScottEnvironment correspondent , BBC News, Yale Climate Connections . The spill highlighted the vulnerability of the world's shipping routes to extreme weather and a dependence on just-in-time shipping . The Suez Canal has reopened after being closed for six days by the Ever Given cargo ship . The ship was carrying a cargo of iron ore and was involved in a massive spill of 60,000 tonnes of oil . The Ever Given has been criticised for causing the spill of 60,000 tonnes of oil into the Mediterranean Sea . The spill of 60,000 tonnes of oil into the Mediterranean Sea has been called the second worst environmental disaster in Egyptian history, with the Gulf of Suez closed for the foreseeable future . On March 27, a huge cargo ship known as Ever Given collided with a container vessel in the Gulf of Suez, triggering a massive spill of oil into the Mediterranean Sea . The ship's master has claimed that he was not to blame for the spill, saying he did not see the container ship until it was far out to sea, and had no reason to suspect that a spill could have occurred . The Suez canal is one of the busiest shipping routes in the world, linking Europe, Africa and Asia . It is also an important part of Egypt's economy, bringing in more than £1.5bn a year to the country . But the current storm also raises questions about the role of climate change in the region, which may have contributed to its devastation . Scientists say strong south-southeasterly winds contributed to the Ever Given's grounding . They say they would have been more powerful if the ship was carrying less oil . A massive container ship has got stuck on the Suez Canal, between Egypt and the Red Sea coast, blocking trade at the world's busiest shipping route. The Ever Given, a container ship, ran aground on the Suez Canal, in Egypt, on Thursday evening. Evergreen Marine, the operator of the ship, said that it had no plans to leave the Suez Canal any time soon. In a statement, the company said: 'Evergreen Marine currently has no plan to depart this location, as the tugboats and cranes needed to dislodge the vessel have not yet been able to do so.' The Ever Given is pictured stuck sideways in the Suez Canal with eight tugboats working to dislodge the huge container ship . Evergreen Marine confirmed that the ship was stuck in the Suez Canal . It came about after the ship ran aground on Thursday evening, and has been unable to refloat . The huge container ship is owned by Evergreen Marine, which runs the ship . Eight tugboats and a digger are helping to refloat the Ever Given container ship . Evergreen Marine said it has no plans to leave the Suez Canal any time soon . The Suez Canal is the world's busiest shipping route, with a record 60 million tonnes of cargo passing through it each year .

The Suez Canal Authority has seized the world's sixth largest container ship Ever Given because it refuses to stop its operation despite a court order demanding that it stop, a senior official said on Thursday.

"The order was issued by a court to halt operations. That was the order and the ship must comply," Abdel Salam el-Omar, spokesman for the canal authority, told a news conference at the terminal where the ship is docked.

The ship, owned by Japanese carrier Mitsui O.S. K. Lines, was seized by the Egyptian authorities earlier this week. It had been docked at the Port of Alexandria on Thursday, according to a statement on its Web site. It was expected to leave the Egyptian port on Friday, the company said.

The Ever Given blocked the Suez Canal, which connects the Mediterranean Sea to the Red Sea, in December, prompting a dispute between the company and the canal authority. The company argues that the canal authority owes it millions of dollars in compensation, while the Egyptians say it should bear the costs in the event of a Suez Canal lockout.

The two sides dispute the reason for the seizure of the ship. The canal authorities say the seizure is for a legal dispute, while Mitsui says the company is a third-party investor on the ship and that it should not have been held legally liable for anything the ship did. The company said in an e-mail statement that it would continue negotiations with the canal authorities.

The Ever Given holds a cargo worth more than $700 million, according to its Web site. It holds goods from companies like IKEA and Lenovo. It has been docked at the Port of Alexandria, the site where it was seized, since early March, Reuters reported.

In an e-mail statement, Mitsui said it had decided not to comply with the court order, and that in the event of a lockout the company would "fully co-operate with the Egyptian authorities and abide by all their decisions."

A source with knowledge of the discussions said the authorities would not accept any offer to pay a portion of the amount the company needs to pay to the canal authority, which is expected to be around $916 million.

A senior Mitsui O.S. K. Lines official said in an e-mail statement that the company was "confident that it can resolve the matter."

Oil futures in New York rebounded after a shipping incident in the Suez Canal led to a short time-spread widening on global crude oil prices, traders said.

Oil prices fell more than 12% in less than two weeks and were at their lowest level since early February, following a sharp drop triggered by the spread of the Middle East's war, traders said.

The incident provided a reprieve amidst a downturn in the oil market, with prices having dropped to the lowest since early February.

Oil prices rebounded in early trade on Friday after a shipping grounding in the Suez Canal blocked the main route through the Strait.

The incident was triggered by a cargo ship which ran aground, prompting the closure of the Suez Canal, traders said.

The incident also raised the prospect of more disruption in the Middle East, as it has been almost two weeks since the oil prices fell sharply following the start of the war in neighbouring Syria.

Oil prices rose to above $55 a barrel at one point, but were then dropped back to below $55 by early Friday.

The photo that some people are claiming shows the current route of the Ever Given cargo ship was originally supposed to take has come under scrutiny for a couple of reasons. It's just one in a long list of fake pictures circulated on the internet following a major disruption to the Suez Canal on March 23. This morning we learned that after the Ever Given had been released from its position on the canal, it began its usual route. So it's important to remember that while this photo is a plausible depiction of the Ever Given cargo ship's route before it was caught in the Suez Canal, the ship's route hasn't always been as it is now. So what was the actual route of the Ever Given? Was the ship intended to be drawn in the way that the photo appears to be? Was the route intended to resemble a crude drawing of a penis? First things first: a picture is worth a thousand words, but this one isn't worth too much. The image is genuine and shows the same route as the ship has always taken before it was stuck in the Suez Canal. That means the following things.

The image depicts the full route of the Ever Given cargo ship from the start of its usual route, through the Suez Canal, out to the shipyard that it was built at in the Port of Mombasa. It was drawn in exactly the same way as the route is now, with the lines drawn in the same scale as the lines on the physical map. It does not resemble a drawing of a penis. Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp suffered a six-hour outage on Oct. 4 . The service outage was attributable to human error, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said . Facebook said it suffered a series of maintenance failures during the outage . Some experts and users were quick to speculate that the outage was caused by military action, as rumors spread online . (CNN) -- You might have seen online that the military raided Facebook and caused the service to briefly halt on Oct. 4. The claim is a hoax and Facebook was forced to deny it. This was the company's most serious data center outage in years, according to a statement from Mark Zuckerberg on the company's blog on Oct. 5: "We're all still shaking our heads and processing that this was the worst outage we have ever seen," he said. "We were lucky to get through another day." If Mark Zuckerberg were to die in a car crash, CNN would say, "Lucky he didn't have a job to do today," and we would be right. The real reason why Facebook was down was because we are human and we make mistakes. We know what the damage we have done to millions of users was terrible, but we want to make clear that we are here to fix it. We are working hard every day to fix it . Most of the outage happened when Facebook attempted to migrate data from servers running on older technology to newer technology. The migration took longer than expected, which is why many users may not have been able to log in to the service for six hours. When the migration was complete, Facebook restored data and services. The company said it had restored 99% of the service. The migration may have caused the outage. As for the military raid theory: It was a hoax; it originated with a Twitter user claiming that he had seen U.S. military personnel trying to take down the site, but he later retracted that claim . The military raided Facebook? That's a hoax, and it started on Twitter, according to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg. (CNN) -- A six-hour outage on Facebook and Instagram and WhatsApp appeared to be the result of military action, but it was not the case, the company said Monday. Mark Zuckerberg said on Facebook's blog that the problem was caused by "human error during routine maintenance" and promised the company would fix it. The outage occurred on Oct. 4, Mark Zuckerberg told CNN, when Facebook attempted to migrate data from servers running on older technology to newer technology. "It was a very difficult migration and it required a large amount of work to complete," Zuckerberg said at the time. "We'd like to apologize to all of those affected by this," the company said in a statement.

In a series of tweets, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez called Facebook's decision to withhold from users their own messaging services a monopoly tactic and a threat to democracy. The decision, made without warning, was immediately seen as a violation of user privacy. In her Twitter post, Ocasio-Cortez wrote: The monopolistic behavior of Facebook is not at odds with democracy. Why does Facebook need to be given monopoly power? Facebook responded to Ocasio-Cortez's post with a statement emphasizing that its privacy policies are designed to maintain users' trust and protect their personal data. The statement added: In the wake of Facebook's abrupt decision to stop all messaging services, I was forced to look up what the rest of the world was talking about. Facebook's messaging blackout has not been widely covered. But it has had a significant impact on Latin America because WhatsApp is used by an estimated 65% of all cellphone users there. It is not the only messaging app used by that region. WhatsApp users can still communicate via other apps like Viber. In an interview with Forbes, Forbes editor José Caparroso said that the Facebook decision was significant in Latin America because WhatsApp was used by the vast majority of people in the region. Viber has also been an alternative to WhatsApp, but it has not been widely used. As for Instagram, the company had been working to make its own messaging service separate from Facebook, but efforts to develop the service were thwarted by Facebook's decision. He said the blackout was just the latest way that Facebook was able to expand its profits at the expense of consumers. The statement said the move was not a violation of Facebook's privacy policy, which protects users' data, and it was meant to maintain users' trust in Messenger. Caparroso, who is also a political scientist, said the move by Facebook was significant, because it allowed the firm to gain access to the users' data while maintaining the illusion of user privacy. Facebook will continue to work to offer Messenger and its other messaging services as a free option for users. Facebook and Germany's justice system have come under fire after a prominent German journalist posted political comments to Facebook which were deleted without warning and her account blocked. The Federal Court of Justice ruled on Friday that Facebook's terms of service regarding post deletion and account blocking for community standards violations were "null and void". Germany's election campaign rages on, as the Bundestag holds its last debate before voting, with the Social Democrats in a lead of at least 16 points. In its verdict, Germany's highest court condemned the social network for allegedly breaching European law. Read more: Germany election poll: Facebook to pay out for toxic posts The ruling adds complexity to the debate on toxic discourse on social networks ahead of next month's European elections. Facebook users can now comment on German election debates Facebook bans political posts and posts from users who hate Jews or Muslims More than a million comments and 10 million likes have been posted in less than an hour on the Bundestag debate, which was streamed live on Facebook. Facebook said it had blocked comments on the debate due to a series of hate speech posts that were not content violations. In its verdict, the court added that Facebook's community standards, which prohibit users from posting content that constitutes a direct threat to another person, violated European law. The Federal Court of Justice also condemned Facebook for not offering users a right of appeal against their posts being removed and their accounts being blocked. "The Federal Court of Justice's decision demonstrates that Facebook, as a media company, is responsible towards its users," Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg said in a statement. Facebook was given the power to block users who violated its terms of service in 2008. In a statement, Facebook said it had blocked the user because some of her posts were "significant violations of our Community Standards policy". The German lawyer who filed the case has called the ruling "a victory for free speech". "This is not the first time that we see such an unfolding on Facebook," she added. The decision means Facebook has no legal grounds to block or delete content that violates its community standards, the court added. The ruling comes as the Bundestag is holding its final debate before the May 24 election. The Social Democrats are in a lead of more than 16 points. Thousands of people worldwide have been tweeting about QAnon for the last year and Facebook's recent outage is no different. Social media platforms, including Facebook and Twitter, have been accused of not doing enough to combat the spread of misinformation. The White House hopes to shift the current balance in how companies are held accountable for their posts . President Joe Biden is pushing for new regulation to change the current balance . Social media platforms have repeatedly defended their Section 230 protection in the face of criticism from the White House, courts and state attorneys general . The White House is pushing to revise Section 230 of the law, which shields social media platforms from being held legally responsible for user-generated content. The revised language would make platforms more accountable for their actions, including for content that is false and misleading. President Joe Biden wants to force social media companies to be better at fighting misinformation. In a wide-ranging speech on the importance of social media, Biden highlighted the need for content creators to "come together as a collective to tackle this problem together" and called on social media companies to take more action to counter disinformation and misinformation. President Biden also stressed that social media companies have been doing too little to combat the spread of misinformation. Asked about the report, the White House Communications Director said she has been "very encouraging" of the efforts of social media companies to curb misinformation, but said the social media industry needs to step up its game. She highlighted efforts such as Twitter's recent ban on accounts that repeatedly spread misinformation, Facebook's recent pledge to devote $1 billion over five years to combating the spread of fake news, and Google's decision to allow its ads to be placed in places on its platforms that were previously unprofitable. In response, Twitter President Jack Dorsey and President of Facebook Mark Zuckerberg said their companies will continue to push for stronger regulation to protect users from abuse . Twitter President Jack Dorsey said that while his company has made "significant progress on combating misinformation and hate speech", they must do "much more" and promised to push for new government action. Revenue loss during the time period was roughly $319.6 million per day or $13.3 million per hour, according to Facebook. At the time of writing, Facebook's stock had dropped 4.9%, after a whistleblower accused the company of choosing 'profit over safety'.

Facebook is dropping its facial recognition system after a five-year, $850 million acquisition, the tech company announced on Thursday. Facebook faces $850 million fine from FTC . Facebook users are being told to tag their photos going forward . Facebook has a database of identified photos that is about the size of a university library . Facebook is dropping facial recognition in a decision that follows a five-year legal and financial back-and-forth between Facebook and regulators . Facebook users are told to look to their phones to tag photos going forward . Nearly a third of Facebook users have facial recognition features enabled and the company says about 1 billion people have access to the technology . Facial recognition, a controversial tech tool used by police and surveillance firms, has long been used by Facebook on its mobile users. Now, the social media firm has confirmed it will shut down the facial recognition system after its acquisition of the Cambridge Analytica scandal-hit data firm. In an announcement on Thursday Facebook said the system will no longer be in use. It added that it had been discontinued after five years, with no timetable for when it would be replaced. The announcement comes after the company was hit by a $850 million fine from the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and a $650 million legal settlement with Illinois residents in which it agreed to pay compensation for the company's use of their data. However, the decision by Facebook follows a five-year legal and financial back-and-forth with regulators and is not entirely surprising. Facial recognition has long been used by Facebook on its mobile users . Facial recognition has been used by Facebook since 2012 . In a blog post, Facebook said the system would continue to work in a number of ways. The firm's head of product, Reuben Rogers, said the system would "continue to be used as an extra layer of authentication" on Facebook. In a statement, Facebook said: 'FACEBOOK will no longer use the technology to automatically identify people in user photos, videos, or other media. 'It will continue to be used as an extra layer of authentication on mobile devices and will continue to be used in our advertising products and for other purposes in the future, but will no longer be used to automatically identify people in photos.' Facebook has removed 16,000 fake reviews groups since the end of January, the UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has announced. It said these were part of a wider effort by Facebook to identify and remove groups where fraudulent reviews were being traded. Fake reviews involve purchasing positive reviews to boost sales or negative reviews to harm competitors, coordinated on Facebook and Instagram. It is not known how much money has been lost by businesses that took part in the fraudulent trades. For example, a competitor's Facebook page could be filled with negative reviews, while the fake reviews could be positive. The CMA said Facebook is still struggling to remove groups where fake reviews are still being sold, and is therefore disappointed by the company's delayed response. The CMA did not name Facebook's names in its statement, but said it would be addressing concerns about the social network over what it called "other areas". In January 2020, Facebook agreed to better identify and remove groups where fraudulent reviews were being traded. It has also promised to make it easier for businesses to remove them if they wish.

Facebook's outage on 4 October is one of the most significant and widespread data centre outages in its history. Facebook's security team found that the misconfiguration which caused the outage involved the configuration of its backbone routers. An audit tool was used to configure these routers and the mistake was missed. The outage started when a maintenance engineer attempted to test the capacity of Facebook's backbone routers and accidentally disabled the border gateway protocol (BGP) routers, which connect the data centres to the internet. As a result, Facebook's DNS servers couldn't translate domain names into IP addresses, which meant users were unable to access Facebook as well as the other apps affected by the outage. So what went wrong? And what can Facebook do to avoid such mistakes in the future? The outage started on 4 October when a fault was found during routine maintenance on Facebook's backbone routers. What caused the outage? A configuration error meant that Facebook's backbone routers cut the internet links to the data centres, which affected 2.9 billion users of Facebook, WhatsApp, Instagram, and Messenger. Why was the error not caught? Because a security audit tool failed to catch it, allowing the misconfiguration to be deployed across Facebook's entire network environment. What did the outage mean for Facebook? Facebook's DNS servers couldn't translate domain names into IP addresses, which meant users were unable to access Facebook and the other affected apps. How did Facebook address the problem? Facebook said it would be investing heavily in technology to cut the risk of such errors in the future. As of October 5, more than a week after the fault was found, 2.9 billion people were still affected worldwide by the outage, which began when Facebook's maintenance engineers tested its backbone routers for capacity. Facebook said it would be spending heavily on technology to cut the risk of such errors in the future. As of October 5, more than a week after the fault was found, 2.9 billion people were still affected worldwide by the outage, which began when Facebook's maintenance engineers tested its backbone routers for capacity. Facebook said the problem was the result of a configuration error on the backbone routers, which cut the internet links to the data centres. Facebook said the misconfiguration had been disabled by a maintenance engineer who was testing capacity. The audit tool which configured the routers was used to test the capacity of the backbone routers. An audit tool was used to test the capacity of the backbone routers, but an incorrect command inadvertently disabled the BGP routers, which connect the data centres to the internet. This enabled a misconfiguration to be deployed across Facebook's entire network environment. The error failed to be detected by the audit tool, which meant it was deployed across the entire Facebook's entire network environment.

The Facebook has reportedly shut down a pro-Israeli page with 77 million followers for violating its hate speech and spam rules. The founder of the page, Mike Evans, claims that the page was shut down in response to a "cyber terrorism" campaign against his group by radical Islamists. The group, Friends of Zion Association (FoZA), had a number of notable features including an anti-Semitic section that included photos of Hitler and quotes, as well as a section for children who could be subjected to anti-Semitic content. Facebook removed the 77 million page following a "cyber terrorism" campaign by radical Islamists who used fake accounts to post hateful messages, according to the group's founder, Mike Evans. The campaign has involved an estimated over a million comments, as well as anti-Semitic content including photos of and quotes by Hitler. Facebook took the decision after receiving complaints from anti-Semitists, an Israeli military official, and from pro-Israeli groups that the page had been spreading false news and images, the Jerusalem Post reported. The pro-Israeli group Friends of Zion was founded in 2011.

Facebook employees abused access to user data to track down co-workers who went on vacation, a new book claims. Facebook employees abused access to user data to track down co-workers who went on vacation and harass their former colleagues in a new book, reports BBC Newsbeat. An Ugly Truth: Inside Facebook's Battle for Domination is written by author and former Facebook engineer Jeff Sutter. Facebook is facing a growing backlash over its handling of its own data, particularly in relation to mass surveillance. He claims that engineers abused access to Facebook user data to locate co-workers who'd gone on vacation. Sutter says that Facebook granted engineers 'extensive data access' to streamline their work, which meant that they could 'manipulate data to track people' in an attempt to 'get revenge on their former colleagues'. The book claims that staff were able to access Facebook's internal logs and other corporate data 'without risk of being caught' by Facebook's security policies. They were able to track people to their new hotel rooms, and even access their conversations and real-time location, reports the BBC. Australian media giants Google and Facebook are threatening to limit some of their services in Australia if a digital news code is passed into law by the Australian government next month. The Australian Prime Minister has refused to respond to the threats and insisted his government will not bow to threats from tech giants. The Australian government's Digital News Code is currently being considered by a Senate committee and is expected to be passed in the next few months. The Digital News Code requires digital platforms such as Google, Facebook and Twitter to pay the news media for the content they publish on their websites, and to provide Australians with a way to opt-out of this service. Google says the code could force it to limit services in Australia if it is passed. Facebook has not commented on the Digital News Code, which it has described as "unprecedented and unconscionable". Google has 19 million Australians users, while Facebook users number in the millions. This would be the first time a major digital platform has threatened to limit services in Australia if such a law is passed. The Australian government says the Digital News Code will make it easier for Australians to be able to enjoy the best content from all news media. Scott Morrison has been accused of bowing to the tech giants' demands, which he has rejected. The Digital News Code is intended to protect news outlets from losing revenue from digital platforms such as Google and Facebook.
