Racism in American policing is a system of racial control and exploitation, a new column from former Guardian journalist David Leonhardt explains in a Washington Post opinion piece. Exploiting the system of racial control and exploitation that exists at the heart of American policing, Derek Chauvin and his fellow officers racially discriminated against unarmed black men in Minneapolis. But their actions did not justify killing them and they will not be pardoned.

Chauvin's conviction signals that the United States is moving in new directions. It is time to end the endless cycle of racism, white supremacy and policing that is killing tens of thousands of black and brown Americans each year.

Read David Leonhardt's full column here

Even without racial bias, policing won't solve the problems of inequality and exploitation. One of the many tragedies of the United States has been that people have not considered policing as a system of racial discrimination.

The system works as follows. We are all equally entitled to the freedom of movement under the rule of law. That is the cornerstone of our democracy. In other words, when we are at the mercy of a police officer who decides whether we can go to the grocery store or a convenience store, it is not a free society.

For decades, police, many of whom were white, discriminated and exploited black and brown people in the name of protecting the public. The result is that Americans are at the mercy of the police and they depend on them for access to basic human needs.

At a time when we need to focus the anger about the killing of George Floyd at the hands of a police officer on racism, the system of racial control and exploitation at the heart of American policing should also be considered. This is not a problem of George Floyd's death alone. It is a system that benefits white supremacists and racists, but harms blacks and brown people.

But most importantly, the system of racial control and exploitation creates a cycle of violence that lasts many years. By killing unarmed black people in the name of protecting the public, white supremacists are creating a vicious cycle of revenge. The result is that many black and brown men and women are killed by police in the same way that George Floyd was killed.

Chauvin's conviction signals that the United States is moving in new directions. It is time to end the endless cycle of racism, white supremacy, and policing that is killing tens of thousands of black and brown Americans each year.

Here is an edited transcript of an interview with Steven Clark, who has been working for Derek Chauvin's prosecution team, to discuss the challenges facing the defense in this case. The transcript was provided to the Journal by Steven Clark. The Associated Press has not independently verified the accuracy of this transcript. Q: You were one of the first lawyers to work with the prosecutors in this case. How did you feel about the choice of the prosecution team? Steven Clark: I think they selected the right lawyers. Erin Eldridge and Matthew Frank are two very experienced attorneys that understand the criminal justice system. They have worked on many high-profile cases, including Eric Holder's and John Ashcroft's cases. They have tremendous experience. It was important for them to have a lot of experience on this case and to represent the interests of the government, which is the interest of all of us. Q: How do you feel about the number of attorneys on trial? Do you think it's too large for the jurors to get a good sense of the individual attorneys? Steven Clark: I think it's the right number of attorneys. It's not a one-size-fits-all trial. I have never worked with a trial that had 10 or more attorneys on trial, so I don't know. I only know what I've seen in other trials. But the number of attorneys is what it is.

Facebook posts from a Fall River, Massachusetts police department have been taken down after they were mistakenly reposted by an officer who thought they were re-sharing a meme on their personal page, police said Tuesday. An officer re-posted a controversial Facebook post from the Fall River, Mass., police department to his own page, police said. That post referred to George Floyd's murder and suggested that he should have behaved as Derek Chauvin, the white Minneapolis police officer who killed him, police said. The post also referred to Derek Chauvin's conviction, noting that the officer's punishment for killing Floyd was less than what Chauvin would have faced for committing murder, police said. The officer re-posted the message to his own Facebook page, police said. In a Facebook post, Fall River Police Chief Jeffrey Cardoza said Monday that he was "deeply troubled" by the Facebook post and apologized for it. "We're not an easy department to work in," he wrote on Facebook. "However, we take our responsibilities in a very serious way, and we would never intentionally put words in the mouth of an individual that we didn't intend to use." The post has been removed from the Facebook page of the Fall River Police Department. The post was taken down after the officer re-posted it to his own Facebook page, police said. For more than three decades, police have been able to use lethal force against unarmed suspects in United States on the pretext of qualified immunity—a legal protection that allows them to use force without consequence, even if that force turns out to be deadly. The Supreme Court has repeatedly upheld the use of lethal force by police. However, in recent weeks, the justices have been grappling with the constitutionality of the laws that allow police and armed guards to use lethal force on unarmed suspects—especially with regard to mass shootings by police. While the death of George Floyd has sparked a national conversation about gun violence, the recent spike in mass shootings by police is just as troubling. In April, the number of police-involved shootings reached a record 147 in the U.S., with more than 60 people killed since the beginning of the Derek Chauvin trial. In some cases, police have killed more victims than shooters, despite the high number of police shootings and deaths. The Trump administration supports gun control and has recently proposed legislation that would require gun owners to carry concealed handgun permits. However, the Supreme Court has upheld the use of lethal force by police, leading some policymakers to push for more strict gun laws. This can create a vicious cycle as more guns lead to more homicides, according to Michael Levitt, an expert on gun violence at New America.

Kyle Rittenhouse, the 20-year-old gunman who killed two protesters at a Kenosha, Wisconsin, protest on Aug. 3, has been acquitted of all charges against him. Still, much of the conversation about the case has focused on his weapon, a semi-automatic assault rifle. In fact, two other people were injured while attempting to confront Rittenhouse, and his injuries included a gunshot wound to the back of his head that required him to be hospitalized. Wisconsin's long rifle law allows people to carry a short rifle for hunt purposes. That law, however, allows long rifles to be used only for hunting purposes if the person holds the weapon in a "safe, stable, and controlled" position. The gun's barrel was much longer than the shortest rifles that are considered safe and stable. Therefore, Rittenhouse was not allowed to carry his rifle in a controlled position. The short-barreled rifles that Rittenhouse carried were not considered long enough, so his possession of the gun was deemed legal under Wisconsin's long rifle law, which allows people to carry short-barreled rifles for hunting. In Wisconsin, Rittenhouse is accused of three charges: possession of a loaded firearm during a riot, possession of a loaded firearm by a person under the age of 21, and possession of a firearm during a riot that resulted in serious bodily injury.

The increase in severity rather than frequency of storms is a key impact of climate change, according to the Nature Conservancy's chief scientist, Katharine Hayhoe. Warming oceans are causing hurricanes to intensify more quickly, with Ida strengthening significantly before landfall. The increase in severity means that storms will bring more damage, more power outages and longer recovery times, she said. BATON ROUGE - A dead Louisiana man was found in the stomach of a giant alligator last week after Hurricane Ida caused flooding in Slidell, authorities said Friday. The attack killed 71-year-old Timothy Satterlee Sr., who was the victim of Hurricane Ida and was last seen in the street after the storm hit the city last week, authorities said. Officials with the St. Tammany Parish Sheriff's Office said they were able to capture the creature and will determine whether it had killed the man. The alligator was released at the same location where it was captured, officials said. The alligator was captured by Louisiana Department of Wildlife licensed nuisance hunters, the sheriff's office said. It is believed that Satterlee was attacked and eaten by the alligator the day after Hurricane Ida hit Louisiana on Monday, authorities said, adding that he was found unconscious and dead in the street by a family member early Tuesday morning. Satterlee was the first person confirmed dead from Hurricane Ida, the third major hurricane to hit Louisiana in as many months. After the attack, St. Tammany Parish Sheriff's Office announced the finding and will verify the remains with the coroner's office, according to a news release. It was not clear whether the remains found in the alligator were those of Satterlee, authorities said. "Our investigation is ongoing," the sheriff's office said in a statement.

When Ida hit south Louisiana on Monday night, it was more than a hurricane: it was also an assault on the city's mental health system . It was the first time a hurricane had hit Houma's medical center since it opened 70 years ago, and it was the most difficult time in its 130-year history . The storm caused the medical center's roof to collapse and flood the hospital with water . It took about a week to clear out the water, said the medical center's chief executive officer . Hurricane Ida also took an emotional toll for healthcare workers, many of who were also dealing with the coronavirus pandemic at the same time . The American Psychiatric Association reported an increase in anxiety, depression and PTSD among front-line healthcare workers . In the coming weeks, the hospital will be focusing on mental health services for the community, the medical center's head says . A massive hurricane in Louisiana ripped the roof off a Houma hospital . By . John Sutter . and John Harnish . Associated Press . A massive hurricane hit Louisiana's south . A massive storm tore a roof off a Houma hospital on Monday night, flooding the hospital's surgical floor and leaving patients lying in pools of water . The storm hit south Louisiana as a COVID-19 surge forced the evacuation of thousands of people, including many patients from the Houma Leonard J. Chabert Medical Center. The storm took a massive toll on the city, particularly on health workers. The Houma hospital has been operating since 1870, but it was not ready for this type of storm . The hospital, which is undergoing a major renovation and expansion, was already overwhelmed by the number of COVID-19 patients it received as the devastating virus swept through Houma and other parts of the state. At the time of the storm, the medical center was already running on its last reserves of water because of the thousands of patients it was processing at the same time as its overflowing COVID-19 patients. "It was more than just a hurricane," said hospital's CEO, Jay Smith. "It felt like a very long, heavy weight was on my shoulders." The hospital was not prepared for the kind of storm it encountered on Monday night. In the initial stages of the storm, water started to pour down from the hospital's roof, the CEO said. By the time the flood was under control, it had soaked the medical center's surgical floor and left patients lying in puddles of water. As the storm progressed, Smith said the hospital's patients were evacuated and discharged to other hospitals in the region, as they could not be risked being evacuated back to their flooded rooms. As a result, the number of patients the medical center was processing at the same time was significantly reduced, the CEO said.

This was a spill of diesel fuel into the Gulf of Mexico. That spill was estimated to be between 40,000 and 100,000 gallons (120,000 - 240,000 litres) and had to be cleaned up by a specially trained team of environmental and wildlife protection specialists. Officials at the refinery say they believe it was caused by Hurricane Ida last month and may have been the same spill from this week, which was also estimated to be between 40,000 and 100,000 gallons (120,000 - 240,000 litres). Officials now say the refinery will be closed indefinitely. Spill: Hurricane Ida caused a spill at the Phillips 66 Alliance Refinery in Louisiana earlier this month which affected the wildlife near the site . They say they are expecting to find more birds covered in oil and dead .

LOUISIANA is in a state of panic as Hurricane Ida makes its way southward toward Louisiana's most populated section. The storm now hits the city of Jefferson Parish just outside of the town of Jean Lafitte, where hundreds of residents are trapped on the levees and unable to evacuate due to financial or physical reasons, according to Jefferson Parish Sheriff Scott Sellars. Sellars has said that he doesn't know how many residents have stayed behind after the levees were breached, but he estimates that at least 400 people are in the area. Sellars has told the Daily Memphian, "There are a lot of people who can't evacuate because of financial reasons. There are those who are homeless. There are people who are homeless and can't afford to purchase a car." The storm surge in Jefferson Parish is hitting the area harder than anywhere else in the state, Sellars tells Fox 31. The storm surge was at 10 feet today, according to the National Hurricane Center, but is expected to rise to 12 feet by tomorrow. Sellars tells the Daily Memphian that it takes at least a week to evacuate the levees, which have already been breached. Some people, he tells the station, are staying behind for a variety of reasons. "Some of them have family back home," Sellars says. "They have to make sure that their family is OK." Sellars also says that there is no power in the area because the storm surge has knocked out power. Cell phone and internet service has been severely affected as well. "We're just going to be out of communication because of the storm," Sellars says. "There are a lot of phone lines out.

A CNN journalist has been reporting from Louisiana as Hurricane Ida grinds through the South and East coasts of the United States and its first confirmed fatality has been reported on the front page of the website. Duplessis' death marks the first confirmed fatality from Hurricane Ida, with the storm claiming dozens of lives and causing widespread destruction across Louisiana and Texas in the Gulf of Mexico and Mississippi in the Gulf of Mexico . Volunteers from nearby churches helped to clear the fallen tree from Duplessis' front yard . The death comes as officials are struggling to assess the damage caused by the hurricane . Hurricane Ida is also the most powerful hurricane to hit Texas since Ivan in 1991 when it was a Category 5 storm .

Hurricane Ida: Residents could dispose of their trash Sept. 16, New Orleans Mayor says . Nearly three weeks post-Hurricane Ida, the mayor says residents will be able to start disposing of their trash at Elysian Fields Transfer Station on Sept. 16, 2021. The announcement is part of a long-awaited plan by the city to resume regular trash service . A group of city workers went on strike in May 2020 demanding higher wages and COVID-19 protection equipment . The city's trash collection agency, Metro Service Group, had been lagging in collections even before Hurricane Ida . Some areas of the city have not been serviced since the storm . The National Labor Relations Board certified the strike as a labor dispute in August 2020 and settled it in September . (CNN) -- Nearly three weeks post-Hurricane Ida, New Orleans Mayor LaToya Cantrell announced Monday that residents could start disposing of their trash at Elysian Fields Transfer Station on Sept. 16, 2021. That's a big step forward in a long-awaited plan by the city to resume regular trash service. A group of city workers went on strike in May 2020 demanding higher wages and COVID-19 protection equipment. The city's trash collection agency, Metro Service Group, had been lagging in collections even before Hurricane Ida. The city's trash collection agency, Metro Service Group, had been lagging in collections even before Hurricane Ida. Some areas of the city had not been serviced since the storm. The National Labor Relations Board certified the strike as a labor dispute in August 2020.

Hurricane Ida: FEMA extends time for disaster relief applications in Union County, NJ . The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has announced that residents of Union County, New Jersey, will have until January 5, 2022, to be eligible for individual assistance through the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's (HUD) FEMA Disaster Recovery Center. Residents can apply by calling 1-888-310-8283 or by visiting www.fhud.gov/disasterrecovery. Residents of New Jersey who experienced the effects of Hurricane Ida on their homes and personal belongings are now eligible to access federal disaster assistance, the FEMA Disaster Recovery Center is pleased to announce. The FEMA Disaster Recovery Center in Union County, NJ, will stay open for in-person assistance indefinitely. Hurricane Ida: Louisiana man organizes satirical Trash Parade to draw attention to uncollected garbage in New Orleans . Louisiana resident Aaron Grant organized a satirical trash parade in New Orleans in the wake of Hurricane Ida . Residents who were left with uncollected garbage after the storm were able to show off their creativity in satirical outfits . Friends and family members of Grant were invited to join in the parade and show off their own unique outfits . After the parade, Grant told USA TODAY that he saw humor as a coping mechanism in the aftermath of Hurricane Ida, which hit New Orleans from August 29 to August 30 . The New Orleans resident also said he hopes the outfits will bring attention to the issue of uncollected garbage in the city . A suicide attack is imminent at Kabul airport, Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond has said as he visited the Pakistan border region to meet his counterparts. James Heappey, armed forces minister, described the threat as "credible" and "imminent" and the UK government advised against the use of the airport, he said. Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond met his Pakistani counterpart Shah Mahmood Qureshi at the border on Friday evening

Heappey said: "We will continue to assess the situation on the ground and will give further instructions to those in Afghanistan as needed." A warning has been issued by the US against anyone travelling by air into the country for security reasons.

Heappey, who met his Pakistani counterpart Shah Mahmood Qureshi at the border on Friday evening, said the attack is "very, very credible" and "imminent".

"This is a very serious threat, we are in contact with the US, we are in contact with the UK, and certainly we are in contact with the Afghan government, and they are very, very keen that we get on top of this situation as soon as possible," he said.

Earlier this week, it was reported that IS militants planned to travel to Kabul from the north of Pakistan to launch a terror attack on the airport.

A number of UK officials visited the city to assess the situation, which was calm but tense in the aftermath of an attack last month on a police post in which four UK nationals were killed.

It was unclear whether a suicide bomber would be in the group travelling to Kabul and the group was due to arrive on Friday night.

The UK government urged people to stay away from the airport because of the risk of an attack. The attack is being called by the UK armed forces "credible, imminent and lethal."

Twin blasts in Kabul, capital of Afghanistan, have killed dozens of Afghans civilians and at least 13 US soldiers, US officials have confirmed. General Kenneth McKenzie, who was in charge of the US response to the terror attacks in Kabul, has said 13 US service members were killed and 15 were injured. The Taliban took responsibility, claiming it was a response to US drone strikes. The attack occurred on Sunday when a suicide car bomber detonated car bombs outside the airport and at a hotel in the city. Police said a suicide car bomber detonated a car on the side of the road outside the airport. It was unclear if the car bomb was aimed at the US military. The two bombs, located within 100 yards of each other, were both placed in cars and detonated remotely. US officials told reporters the bomb was detonated remotely, while US officials said it was more likely than not that the car bomb was aimed at a US serviceman. A number of vehicles, including a police convoy carrying Afghan officials, were hit by the car bomb in an attack outside Hamid Karzai International Airport, Kabul police said. The Taliban, which claimed responsibility for the attacks, called them a response to US drone strikes. An attack outside the hotel where the Afghan government is based, which is a short walk away from the airport, killed an unspecified number of civilians. US officials said the FBI was working to confirm the identities of the dead and the wounded. US forces responded to the attack by moving to secure the area. A number of US service members and Afghan police were killed when a suicide car bomber detonated explosives outside Hamid Karzai International Airport in the Afghan capital of Kabul. More than 100 US soldiers were killed in the War on Terror, but the attacks have been few compared to the more than 5,000 US troops killed in the Afghanistan war that followed 9/11. The attacks came less than five months after Joe Biden became president, and three months after he committed to ending the war when he took office. The attack was the deadliest on US soil in Afghanistan since the Taliban took power in late 2001. The Taliban said on Sunday that they were responsible for the twin explosions at Kabul airport and a hotel in the Afghan capital. The Taliban claimed responsibility for both attacks, saying the car bombs were a response to US airstrikes. The US service members killed in the attack on Afghan National Defense and Security Forces included a Marine Corps sergeant, US Navy corpsman, two Army Staff Sgt., a Navy corpsman, a Marine Corps chaplain, a Marine Corps sergeant, an Army Staff Sgt., and a Navy corpsman, the Pentagon announced Thursday.

The Department of Defense said the attack happened Tuesday in Kabul, Afghanistan. The DOD said the group killed was supporting a presidential motorcade in a heavily guarded area near the airport at the time attackers rammed their car into the convoy and detonated explosives in front of it.

All of the 13 victims, including the gunman, died in the attack. Their identities have not been released, and their names will be commemorated at the National Memorial for the United States Military in Arlington, Virginia.

The Pentagon announced Thursday that Ryan Knauss, 20, was killed in the attack, and that Rylee McCollum, 20, was expected to give birth to her child during the third week of this month.

Both were deployed to Afghanistan as part of the U.S. Marines at the weekend to support U.S.-led airstrikes on terrorist targets. McCollum was expected to become a nurse after she completed her medical school education.

Daegan Page, 21, also died during the attack. Before his death, Page's parents said in a statement that he was "brave, compassionate, and full of life" and had so much potential that he was expected to be the next Marine Corp. chaplain. His parents said they were disappointed to learn that he had been named among the slain.

The names of the other slain members of the US-led coalition were not given, according to the Defense Department.

The attack comes as the U.S. prepares to end its combat mission in Afghanistan by the end of the year, though coalition forces will continue to provide security in the country.

Kabul, Afghanistan (CNN) -- As U.S. troops pull out of Afghan in the wake of last week's suicide attack at Kabul airport, the U.S. military is beginning to focus attention on a key part of the Taliban's security plan: recruiting fighters from outside the country to fight in Afghanistan. This strategy would be a dangerous gamble for the U.S. and Afghanistan, but the U.S. military is willing to take that risk to reduce the overall threat of U.S. troops in Afghanistan. U.S.-led forces are trying to stop ISIS-K militants from capturing the rest of the country, but the U.S. is preparing to let ISIS-K, and other militants, move on to threaten Kabul if they think it's safest to do so, said a U.S. official. Kelsee Lainhart's recovery journey has taken her from Walter Reed to Shirley Ryan AbilityLab in Chicago. She survived the Kabul Airport attack on Aug. 26 . Today, she's a role model in the fight against paralysis . Lainhart was paralyzed on her left side after the attack . Here, she shares her message of hope and empowerment to others who have been similarly affected . (CNN) -- "I can't see, I can't move, I can't speak," Lainhart told me, her voice trembling in her throat. "I can't control my muscles and I can't breathe." Lainhart was sitting on a chair in the middle of a living room in Kabul. She had been shot in the chest during the Aug. 26 bombing of the U.S. Embassy, which left 11 U.S. service members dead and wounding more than a dozen people. Thirteen service members from the U.S. were later killed in the attack, which began when an attack vehicle parked outside the Embassy opened fire, according to U.S. officials. A bomb exploded outside the entrance to the Embassy, injuring at least five people, including several U.S. service members, and killing a Taliban fighter, U.S. officials said. A few days later, Lainhart, who had been injured in the attack, was airlifted to Walter Reed Air Force Base, where she spent several months recovering. She was eventually discharged after undergoing surgery at Walter Reed. She was discharged from the military on Sept. 30 and transferred to Chicago-based Shirley Ryan AbilityLab, which houses patients with paralysis who are recovering from severe brain injuries. "I am not an easy person to talk to," she said. "I am difficult and I can be mean," she said. "I know that I am weak and that I may not recover. I am just not going to hold it in for long. And that's what I want to give to other people who are in the same situation." Lainhart added that she is a role model in the fight against paralysis, which continues to strike thousands of U.S. service members who return home. "Right now, I'm all about giving back and I want to empower other people to want to do the same," she said. "I want to inspire them." Lainhart, 24, spoke to CNN from her home in Chicago. Kabul's airport is secure after an ISIS-K suicide bomber attacked the facility last week, officials said Wednesday, but the struggle to secure it will likely continue, particularly as the Taliban continue to move in on the city and its perimeter.

The attack also highlighted how quickly insurgents could strike in the final days of the US withdrawal from Afghanistan, officials said.

The Taliban gained control of the area around the airport and released several prisoners, including members of ISIS-K, when they seized Parwan prison at Bagram air base and Pul-e-Charkhi prison near Kabul.

A US official said the operation to bring the suicide bomber back from the prison to Afghanistan "has taken longer than expected."

The identity of the bomber was confirmed by two US officials and Rep. Ken Calvert, the Democrat who is chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee.

"These attacks show that the Taliban can be very dangerous and very disruptive," Rep. Calvert said.

The last Canadian troops left Afghanistan on Thursday, hours before an attack at Kabul airport killed 11 U.S. marines and one Canadian navy medic. Canada's national security minister confirmed that all Canadians involved in the mission have been accounted for and are safe. The attack at the airport came as part of a series of attacks across the country, with the Taliban claiming responsibility for some of them, including Friday's suicide bomb attack in Kabul. The US has confirmed that 11 of its troops were killed, but cannot confirm if the attack was carried out by U.S. troops, or by the Taliban.

The US-led military campaign against the Taliban ended with the mission's deadline for withdrawal earlier this month, with a total of 13,500 troops leaving Afghanistan by 31 August.

The Canadian Forces confirmed all Canadian military personnel were accounted for and safe following the mission's deadline.

According to official sources, the last Canadian forces left Afghanistan around 20:00 local time (15:00 GMT) on Thursday, while U.S. and NATO forces left Afghanistan a few hours later on Thursday and Friday morning, as part of the joint withdrawal plan.

As the Canadian forces were leaving, Canadians were returning home to the airport, where they were greeted by US and NATO troops.

Earlier, the United States said that a suicide bomb had hit Kabul airport, killing 11 U.S. marines and one Canadian navy medic.

"The U.S. military has deployed additional forces to secure the airport," the Pentagon said in a statement.

It was one of the most dangerous journeys journalists have ever taken, to Kabul's airport from the Taliban-held capital of Kandahar. The journey was not meant to be a positive one. It was to be a last resort, an escape. And for most Washington Post reporters, it actually was an escape. On August 30, two days after the Taliban took over Kabul, we were given a chance to travel to Qatar on a chartered plane. Washington Post's staff in Kabul had previously been the subject of assault from Taliban gunmen who had tried to kill us twice while we tried to flee Kabul, and I was worried for Aziz Tassal, my daughter and others who were with us. He was one of the first to leave the capital, in a convoy provided by the United States, on August 29. We left Kandahar on a bus, and then took a helicopter to Kabul. On arrival at the Kabul airport on Monday, August 30, we were met by U.S. and Afghan officials and led to a waiting chartered flight to Qatar. When we arrived at the airport in Kabul on Monday August 30, we were met by U.S. and Afghan officials and taken to a waiting chartered flight to Qatar. Aziz Tassal, my daughter and others were beaten up by militants who tried to stop us from leaving Kandahar to return to Kabul, where they had been beaten up. The United States was aware the Taliban were moving to take over Kabul and the situation had become very dangerous. But the U.S. and Afghan governments were just not equipped to provide an evacuation flight. The Taliban were taking the city by force, and there were hundreds of thousands of people trapped inside. We couldn't even get to the airport. So we had to return to Kandahar, where Aziz Tassal was shot several times and injured, where I was beaten up by militants who tried to stop us from leaving Kandahar to return to Kabul, where we had been beaten up. The Biden administration were escalating evacuation plans, but could not provide us with a safe passage.

KABUL (AP) -- A Marine has been named an official hero of the city of Lawrence, Massachusetts, for saving the lives of women and children during an attack on a military plane at Kabul's airport last week that killed three Marines and more than a dozen civilians and Afghans, officials said Tuesday. Sgt. Johanny Rosario, 25, died in the attack, along with two female Marines, Sgt. Nicole L. Gee and an Afghan soldier, United States officials said. Rosario was in charge of watching the women and children. He also was carrying ammunition for the Marine team that was traveling with him, officials said. City leaders said Rosario, who had been stationed at Marine Corps Base Quantico in Virginia, was a hero who exemplified the Marine Corps' core values of courage, honor, loyalty, service and sacrifice, city officials said. Rosario was also the second youngest Marine in his squad. He had 6 1/2 years of military service, the Lawrence Mayor said. A third female Marine on the flight, a private, was wounded in the attack, and her condition is not known. Two of the dead were U.S. Marines; the third was an Afghan soldier, officials said. The U.S. military confirmed that 13 of its service members and 169 Afghans were killed in Sunday's attack. Rosario is the second member of a Massachusetts military family to be named an official Lawrence hero.

The Taliban seized control over the Afghan capital, Kabul, on Aug. 15, marking the end of nearly two months' rapid offensive across the country . Across the globe, many were shocked by the Taliban's apparent victory in a country that U.S. and international forces had been fighting against for nearly 15 years . But a U.S. administration that has been struggling with the fallout of its withdrawal from the country has promised that Americans will not tolerate the return of U.S. forces to Afghan soil as a result of the offensive . The Taliban had been engaged in an offensive against the Afghan government forces across the country since June 1 . The Taliban claimed they had seized Kabul on Aug. 15 . It was the culmination of several weeks of fighting that saw Taliban forces advance as far east as Uruzgan Province and as far west as Kandahar Province . The Taliban took over control of Kabul on Aug. 15, according to their official website . Taliban militants captured Kabul, the Afghan capital, on Aug. 15, the Taliban announced on their official website . It marked the end of nearly two months' rapid offensive the insurgents launched against the Afghans across the country . The Taliban gained control of Kabul in a series of waves that began as far east as Uruzgan Province and as far west as Kandahar Province . The militants took over control of several cities and towns throughout the country earlier in the month . Many of the towns and cities that were taken over quickly were in the province of Helmand, which borders Pakistan . The insurgents claimed that the fall of Kabul marked the end of their offensive against the Afghan government . The U.S. and international forces have been fighting the Taliban for nearly 15 years . In June, the U.S. announced that it would withdraw all U.S. forces from the country by the end of the year . Alena Knauss, the wife of a U.S. Army soldier killed in a U.S. attack in Afghanistan, has released a touching video message in honor of her husband, who died along with 13 other service members in the attack on Kabul International Airport on Monday. Alena, a native of Las Vegas, is the wife of Staff Sgt. Ryan C. Knauss, who was assigned to the 8th Psychological Operations Group at Fort Bragg. Knauss joined the Army in 2016, the same year he and Alena got married. Her husband, who served with the U.S. Army for nearly eight years, died along with 13 other service members when a bomb hit the airport on Monday. "I just want to tell you how much I love you and how much I miss you. I want you to know that I am praying for you all the time and that I wish I could be there with you tonight," Knauss says in Knauss's last message before he was killed. "I've never been to Afghanistan, and I can't believe I'm saying this, but the only thing I know that I love you so much is you, and I want you to know that," Alena says in the video. "I love you so much, Ryan C."

Amnesty International's Secretary General, Agnes Callamard, has warned that the international community is failing the most vulnerable people in Afghanistan.

Callamard: The international community is failing the most vulnerable in Afghanistan

She spoke at a press conference in Kabul on 16 September in the wake of an assassination attempt against the country's top female human rights defender. Amnesty International is calling on the government in Kabul and the Taliban to facilitate safe passage for those at risk.

The UN has warned that at least 2,000 civilians have died as a direct result of the war in Afghanistan, while more than 4,000 are believed to have been killed.

The UN Security Council declared Afghanistan a "safe haven" for the Taliban, which is a violation of UN Security Council resolutions.

The UN Security Council has declared Afghanistan a safe haven for the Taliban, which is a violation of UN Security Council resolutions.

'Preventable tragedy'

"If the international community had taken the lead in preventing this tragedy, this crisis could be averted," Callamard told the BBC. "But this crisis is not something that is being addressed by the international community."

The UN has said there are at least 1,000 civilian casualties a day from the ongoing conflict in Afghanistan.

Callamard says the organisation's research shows that at risk individuals are facing direct threat from the Taliban. She says those at risk have been unable to access basic services and food.

She adds that human rights defenders are being intimidated by the group, who have threatened and arrested them.

Callamard has called on the international community to suspend or rescind the orders allowing the deportation of individuals to Afghanistan.

"For years the international community has failed the most vulnerable people in Afghanistan," she said.

"The international community has refused to provide safe passage for those at risk and to ensure that those who are at risk are able to access humanitarian aid."

A suicide bomber has detonated his explosives at a memorial service for a Taliban official in Kabul, killing at least five people, Afghan officials say. The four-wheel drive jeep in which the suicide bomber was travelling exploded outside the Eid Gah Mosque, a popular mosque in the capital, officials said. Afghan forces rushed to the scene and arrested three men over the attack, officials said. Reports suggest that an ISIS-K militant is behind the attack, which took place around 5am local time (0230 GMT on Friday). The ISIS-K are a faction of the jihadist group ISIS that were previously affiliated with the so-called Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) group. Suicide bombers have been targeting the nation's mosques in recent years, particularly after the group's withdrawal from many major cities in Iraq and Syria. The bombing comes just a week after ISIS-K militants killed nine people in an attack on a police station north of the capital in Kabul, the police said. Five people were killed and four others were wounded in a suicide attack outside the Eid Gah mosque in Kabul, Afghanistan, officials said. On January 26, 2017, an explosive went off near the Afghan capital of Kabul, killing 170 people and injuring more than 150. The bombing was the deadliest attack on U.S. service members in a decade, and it was perpetrated by an affiliate of the militant group Islamic State. But the photos and videos provided by the military were so limited that we still don't know much about just how chaotic it was. This week, in a collaboration between the Washington Post and the U.S. military, we were able to visualize the chaos of the day of the attack through the use of images from satellites and drones, plus footage we obtained from inside Afghanistan. We were able to piece together what was likely happening as the suicide bomber detonated his explosives in the midst of the airport's chaos. He and his family have since evacuated from Afghanistan, but he remains in the country to help others who may still be caught in the chaos.

The U.S. has ended its military campaign in Afghanistan, but what will this mean for women in Afghanistan in the months and years after? This is what some women are worried about, according to this week's story by CNN's Vanessa Been. Rashida Yasin writes from Kabul that for some women, the return of the Taliban to power is a bad thing. Here's why: It will be hard to make progress if there is no support of women - and there isn't much if the Taliban doesn't take them seriously, she says. In Herat, dozens of women have staged a protest demanding equal rights and equal opportunities - and there are calls for more similar protests in Kabul. Here is some of Vanessa Been's other stories this week: 1. This week's report from Afghanistan shows that as the U.S. pulls out, there are signs of life on the ground that could signal a positive turn for women . 2. Some fear that the Taliban's promise of a better future for women will be hollow . 3. Other women say the Taliban is not going to allow for equal rights in the near future . 4. Many women in the country have also suffered the devastation of war . The Afghan capital of Kabul is beginning to see signs of life returning after American troops pulled out. The airport and a hospital have reopened. But the Taliban is also back in power and some women are worried that the return could be a bad thing. They fear they will not have equal rights, especially in the new cabinet. And some say the Taliban is not going to allow equal rights in the near future. Women from Herat in western Afghanistan have staged a protest demanding equal rights, equal opportunities, and access to basic services. They want to work and send their sons to school. "I want women to be included in the government so the government can do something for women," she tells CNN. "I am a woman and I want to go to school, work and send my sons to school. I want a good life for my sons." She says she hopes the government will change soon. The Taliban's previous rule in the late 1990s was marked by severe oppression, particularly towards women. Many were barred from working or attending school. And in 2000, the Taliban banned women from driving. The government later relaxed the ban. Many now drive, but there are still restrictions. The U.S. Embassy has said that it continues to urge the Afghan government to ensure women's rights are not eroded after the U.S. withdraws. Experts from Qatar and Turkey are working to reopen Kabul airport after the U.S. withdrawal. There are calls for similar protests in Kabul, where many women are waiting for the airport to open.

Kamala Harris has taken over the reins of power as vice president. The new vice president's diverse background and experiences at home and abroad are a reflection of Americans' stories and aspirations, according to the Biden administration. She took over the reins of power at an iconic moment, becoming the 45th president of the U.S. on Wednesday. Scroll down for video . Kamala Harris became the first female U.S. vice president and also the first Black woman and person of South Asian descent to hold the office . Harris highlighted the moment as exemplifying 'American aspiration' in her remarks at the Lincoln Memorial . She was sworn in by Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor, using a Bible that belonged to Thurgood Marshall, and escorted to the podium by Capitol Police Officer Eugene Goodman . Her inauguration is seen as a significant moment in American history, representing progress in both gender and racial equality . Harris' diverse background is emphasized as reflective of many Americans' stories, bringing important perspectives to the administration .

Her new role will be to oversee the administration of the first woman president of the United States, and that will require her to work differently. She'll be expected to focus more on public policy and to have more control over the executive branch.

Vice President Kamala Harris made history on Monday when she marched in Washington, DC with Second Gentleman Doug Emhoff for the annual Capital Pride event. The event was a reminder of the struggles and progress of LGBTQ rights in the U.S. "Let us continue fighting for equality," Harris tweeted. "We must continue to stand for what is true." LGBTQ rights advocates say progress is being made. Still, they say there remain many challenges ahead, particularly for young people, especially transgender youth. The event began with Harris and Doug Emhoff taking the stage on a stage during the main march. The former San Francisco 49ers assistant's wife, Ashley Biden, walked alongside the vice president on the event's opening day. The event celebrates the accomplishments and also draws attention to the many challenges facing the transgender community and the wider LGBTQ community, who are still facing harassment, discrimination and even violence in everyday life. The former first lady, who was one of the speakers at the event, addressed the importance of understanding transgender identity in order for young people to better understand the LGBTQ community. The event was attended by celebrities from all walks of life, including Joe Biden, Jill Biden, Kamala Harris and Doug Emhoff, among others, as well as the mayor of Washington, D.C., Muriel Bowser. At the end of the march, Doug Emhoff held a podium and spoke about the fight against discrimination. "I don't care what your background is, what gender you are," he said. "It's about what you do. It's about what you stand for and what you fight for. And I think that that's what the message here is," he said.

The White House responded Friday to a report that Vice President Kamala Harris was filmed saying she did not get enough nutritious food during her childhood in India. Harris was asked by WSAZ News in Flagstaff, Arizona, about being raised in an Indian-American family and whether the lack of nutritional food might have affected her health. She replied: "I was never starved. I never had to go to school hungry." Manchin says he was surprised to hear Harris was not starved during childhood. Republican senator Joe Manchin, a West Virginia Democrat, responded by saying he was surprised and concerned that Harris had not had enough nutritional food while growing up. "I think she should be concerned about not having enough nutritional food while growing up," Manchin said. Harris, a Democrat, was interviewed on WSAZ in Flagstaff on Thursday. Sen. But the White House emphasized that Harris was not asked about her childhood food situation in India. "That's not what the interview was about," Jen Psaki, White House press secretary, said Friday morning during a briefing. "They wanted to know what her childhood was like and what she thinks about the challenges of our country."

The Vice President spoke with Bill Nelson, Administrator of NASA, about new Earth observation tools for climate change. Harris visited NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center on Friday to meet engineers and scientists working at the facility . They discussed opportunities for using Earth observation tools to help solve climate change . Nelson said that Landsat 9 has been gathering information on climate change for 50 years . The images show changes in global temperatures, clouds, forests, and coastal areas . Washington (CNN) -- The Vice President of the United States, Kamala Harris, on Friday visited NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland. The center is focused on climate science and weather forecasting; the Vice President met with engineers and scientists working there. She was joined by Acting Administrator of NASA, John Glenn. The vice president spoke with the scientists about the new Earth observation tools that NASA is building to help address climate change. Those tools include Landsat 9, the latest in a series of Earth observation satellites, which the vice president praised for its importance in understanding the effects of climate change. "NASA has a role to play, a unique role to play," the vice president said. "But it has to be a role that emphasizes not just technology, but also education and innovation." The vice president also met with engineers and scientists who work on the upcoming International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor (ITER), a large fusion reactor that will be built outside the United States. It will be the most powerful fusion reactor ever built. NASA's first images of Earth from the new Landsat 9 satellite were presented on Friday during a briefing at the center. They showed dramatic changes in global temperatures, clouds, forests, and coastal areas. NASA says the images are contributing to nearly 50 years of Earth observation . The images, taken on Oct. 31, show significant locations that contribute to nearly 50 years of Earth observation. "We know there are billions of dollars to be made out of this research," NASA administrator Bill Nelson said. "We have to make sure that we don't just make this technology because it's cool or because it's trendy, but because it's useful and because we need it." The Earth Venture Mission-3 will examine storms in order to increase understanding of their formation. "NASA's role is not just in developing technology, it is a role in changing the ways that we think about and understand the climate," the vice president said. "And to change the approaches that we have in terms of addressing those threats."

Vice President Kamala Harris will lead the National Space Council under a new executive order . It will continue operations under the Trump administration after Biden took power . Harris will focus on STEM education, cybersecurity, commercial space activity, diversity, and peaceful space norms . The council was previously led by Vice President Mike Pence during the Trump administration, who had revived the council in 2017 . The council's mission under the new order is to continue the Trump administration's actions to advance the national security interests in space, including those related to commerce, education, research and development, and national security and international diplomacy . By . Jillian Harris and Megan Davis . PUBLISHED: . 06:48 EST, 8 January 2021 . | . UPDATED: . 06:51 EST, 8 January 2021 . The Biden administration has confirmed the details of its much-anticipated space policy, which has been a focus of much of the president-elect's presidency. Kamala Harris will now chair the National Space Council, a group tasked with 'continuing the operation' of the Trump administration's actions related to space . Kamala Harris announced her new role in a tweet on Wednesday evening, writing: 'With my leadership of the National Space Council, I will focus on STEM education, cybersecurity, commercial space activity, diversity, and peaceful space norms.' The National Space Council previously led by vice president Mike Pence during the Trump administration, which revived the council in 2017. It aims to focus on STEM education, cybersecurity, commercial space activity, diversity, and peaceful space norms . The council's actions under the order will be reviewed .

President Joe Biden has confirmed the appointment of the first black woman to serve on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit . In a vote of 53-44, the Senate confirmed the appointment of Federal Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson . She replaces Merrick Garland on the D.C. Circuit . In his speech, President Biden said he was 'pleased to have confirmed Ketanji Brown Jackson as the first woman and first person of color to serve on the D.C. Circuit.' 'She will help to ensure that justice, fairness, equality and transparency are at the heart of the administration's policies and practices,' the President said in a statement. Jackson replaced Attorney General Merrick Garland, who died last year . Garland served on the court from 2014 until he was nominated to the Supreme Court by President Barack Obama, who also nominated Jackson . Jackson is seen as a potential Supreme Court nominee . President Joe Biden confirmed her appointment to the court in a speech . She is the first and only person of colour to serve on the D.C. Circuit .

Kyle Rittenhouse is now out of prison, but what about the media coverage of the murder trial? How does it make a difference to your opinion about this case? Two months after Rittenhouse's arrest, the media has continued to paint him in a bad light. In a recent column for The New York Times, columnist Laura Rozen wrote:

As Kyle Rittenhouse stood in court, the prosecutor and defense attorneys made starkly different interpretations of what it meant to be in the wrong place at the wrong time when he opened fire on the men. The prosecution argued that Kyle Rittenhouse should have taken a different path. That he had acted in self-defense when he killed two people and wounded a third. But Kyle Rittenhouse's defense attorneys, led by Kyle Rittenhouse's mother, focused on the possibility that there was another man present who could have been responsible. The trial was not about who fired the shots. Instead, it was about whether he did in fact act in self-defense. Rittenhouse's defense lawyers, meanwhile, have been making a similar argument on the media side. In the past few days, Kyle Rittenhouse's defense lawyer, Bryan Cave, has been telling the media that he is "shocked" to see the coverage of the Rittenhouse trial being so unfavorable to Rittenhouse. "That is the way you get a guy who didn't do it to be viewed as a murderer," Cave said during a news conference in early September. "You have to find the guy that did it, and you have to find him and you have to hold that person responsible." The Rittenhouse murder trial was an opportunity to examine the First and Second Amendments. It was also a chance to give Kyle Rittenhouse a fair shot at telling his side. The media should not be afraid to get involved. All we want to know is who did it and why. This is not about Kyle Rittenhouse's innocence or guilt, and neither is it about the media's credibility. It is an important question that should be answered. Both sides are entitled to a fair trial. We all want to know what was true and what the facts were in the Kyle Rittenhouse murder case. The media should not shy away from the hard truths and the hard questions that will be asked at Rittenhouse's trial. The trial of Kyle Rittenhouse is not over. The media must continue to play a role. This will be one of the toughest, most important and longest-running trials to have taken place in recent American history.

Aside from the most high-profile trials, people tend to shy away from testifying in trials. The defendant's lawyer might make it a point to get the suspect to plead guilty, even if it means he won't be given a fair trial. But in recent years, a growing number of defendants are choosing to take the stand in such high-profile cases as Jussie Smollett and Kim Potter, and they are winning. Why are defendants choosing to take the stand in high-profile trials? And is social media playing a role? Alan Tuerkheimer explains. Jussie Smollett, Kim Potter, Travis McMichael, Elizabeth Holmes, and Potter herself have all taken the stand in recent high-profile trials, and won. Jussie Smollett went on trial last year for allegedly attacking a gay man in Chicago, and pleaded guilty to a lesser charge. He has since been sentenced and will likely be imprisoned for a few years. Kim Potter's testimony against her ex-boyfriend, Kyle Rittenhouse, led to the former's conviction in the fatal shooting of two protesters. And Elizabeth Holmes has been found guilty of fabricating the origin of a patent she claimed was worth $300 million. Tuerkheimer says that a shift in the lawyers' views on how defendants should be treated is one of the main reasons for their growing willingness to testify. Many lawyers have changed their opinions about defendants taking the stand, and are more open to cases where the public can see that a defendant has been treated unfairly, he says. They also want to ensure that they have the opportunity to present new evidence, as in the case of Holmes. But social media also plays a role in these trials. According to Tuerkheimer, many jurors and jurors tend to expect defendants to testify, and in order to avoid being disqualified from the trial, defendants are often more willing to step up and testify than in the past. Jussie Smollett and others have used social media to call attention to their cases, and that has encouraged defendants to stand up. Tuerkheimer is still skeptical about whether social media will make a significant change in how defendants are treated in the future. This doesn't mean defendants can't take the stand in low-profile cases, Tuerkheimer says, but they may choose to plead guilty instead. If a jury believes the defendant has been treated unfairly, they may still be willing to take the stand.

Teachers from across the state have written to the governor, asking for help.

"I don't know what my students are going to do if I'm not in class," says Mary Hart, a history teacher in Oakland Park, Michigan. "If they have to go to school tomorrow, they're going to be like, 'Where did I get off?'"

Across Michigan, schools have been on the brink of closing or suspending classes indefinitely, with no sign of a threat. In some areas, teachers are reporting their students are so fearful they are asking about procedures like locking doors.

Teachers across Michigan are worried that they may lose their jobs. "This is the most dangerous job I ever had." says one woman in the Ann Arbor area. "I don't want to lose my students," she says.

On Wednesday, hundreds of teachers, students, and parents marched in Ann Arbor, calling on the governor to do more to keep schools safe. On Thursday, more than 100,000 people in the state signed an online petition urging Michigan's secretary of education to act.

The threat to two Colorado Springs schools is now being investigated as uncredible, authorities said Friday. The school district said the threats were shared on social media and were found to be politically motivated. Authorities said school officials have not had any credible threats in recent months. The two schools share a campus on the northeast side of Colorado Springs, and both are located near the city limits, the school district said. The threat to Chinook Trail Elementary School came in the form of a Twitter message from a user known as @FuckAllkids. The threat to Chinook Trail Middle School also came from Twitter, and the person who posted the threat was known as @Turtle. The threats come just days after three students were accused of posting racist remarks on the school district's social media page. Parents were allowed to keep their children home despite the schools remaining open, the school district said. Both schools were closed Friday and all students were sent home. School officials said they would monitor social media accounts, but no threats were identified in the last few days. Authorities said that despite the threats to both schools, school officials were upbeat about the threat to Chinook Trail Elementary School. It was uncredible, and school officials said they were optimistic that there will be less racism in the city, Colorado Springs Police Department Chief Michael Johnson said. Iowa police have charged two teenagers in the killing of a 66-year-old woman who was found dead in Fairfield County, Iowa, on Sunday night . In the hours following the find of Nohema Graber's body, the 16-year-old suspect, Willard Noble Chaiden Miller, and the 17-year-old suspect were taken into custody and charged with first-degree murder, reports the Des Moines Register. Graber's body was discovered on Sunday night under the tarp, wheelbarrow, and railroad ties in Fairfield's Chautauqua Park. Authorities were alerted to the discovery of the body in Chautauqua Park after Graber's daughter called 911. According to reports, Graber's body bore signs of trauma, including a head wound that appeared to have caused her death. Miller and Goodale have been held without bond, while Zellner has been released on $100,000 bond. Austin-East Magnet High School will close for two days after the shooting of a student and an injury to a police officer, CNN affiliate WSBTV reported on Monday.

The shooting happened in the school's bathroom on Sunday, when officers were responding to a call about possible armed force, Knoxville police Lt. Darryl Brown said.

Officials said Anthony J. Thompson Jr., 17, of Austin, had been shot. The shooting was described as taking place in a bathroom at the school.

Authorities said there were no injuries to other students.

The Knoxville school district had canceled classes for Monday and Tuesday, according to WSBTV, citing the incident.

A statement from Knoxville police Lt. Darryl Brown said the officers involved in the incident did not have their guns drawn.

"Those reports about the officers not having guns drawn are unfounded," Brown said in a statement.

"We are not in any way discouraging the use of weapons."

WSBTV said that officers involved in the incident were Adam Wilson, who is with the Knoxville Police Department, and Thomas O'Halloran.

The families of the five students shot and killed in the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre, sued Remington Arms on Tuesday in U.S. District Court, demanding the company provide their confidential medical records. A blood drive for shooting victims is hosted near a gun store parking lot. In the wake of the mass shootings in Michigan earlier this month, blood banks across the U.S. were encouraged to host blood drive events in their communities, but Bass Pro Shop in Fort Smith, Arkansas, has chosen to organize one near a store that sells firearms similar to those used in the school shooting. The blood drive was held Thursday night at Bass Pro Shop in the downtown area. The store is just south of the school shooting at an elementary school in Auburn Hills, Michigan, where 26 people were killed. They were gunned down in March over the weekend, and authorities there are searching for a suspect. "We felt it was appropriate to step up as a blood bank to help the families in Auburn Hills," Arkansas Blood Institute Executive Director Mark Schultz said in a statement. The press release for the event notes, "Auburn Hills is a town of some 13,000 that is served by the Fort Smith hospital, which is the only hospital in the city." Bass Pro Shop, a popular fishing and hunting equipment retailer, is also a gun store. The news comes as a reminder of the controversy surrounding mass shootings and blood donation. Last year in New York City and Chicago, gun owners and advocates criticized mass blood drive events that were held in their respective neighborhoods. The group Gun Violence Archive, which tracks gun violence in the U.S., says there have been more than 200 mass shootings in the U.S. this year, the most in at least eight years. While there are blood drive events across the country hosted by nonprofits and local hospitals, there is concern that, for many people, they are inconvenient and they have to drive to locations far from where they work or where they live. Critics say blood drive events provide a false sense of safety and make it easier for people to purchase guns online.

Photography: Anthony Rodriguez The cinematographer who made "Rust" lost her life on the set of her most recent film when a prop gun containing a live round exploded while the camera was on.

Hutchins, 43, was killed when she was accidentally shot by an unbalanced prop gun loaded with a live round. She had been on the set as part of a test of the production's new prop gun, the result of years of development by Halyna Hutchins and fellow cinematographer Olia Oparina.

Hutchins had been shot seven times, including in the head, and lost consciousness as she was rushed to a hospital, where she was pronounced dead.

The American Film Institute (AFI), a nonprofit organization, established a scholarship fund for women cinematographers in her memory. In the six months since the shooting, the fund has raised $25,000, which is more than double the amount needed to award a scholarship.

"I've been close to Hutchins on and off film sets for the last 10 years," Oparina told WABC News in New York. "She was a wonderful person to work with, and I know how much she touched the hearts of the people she worked with and affected through her positive approach to life."

If you were working on 'Saturday Night Live', you'd know how to stay safe and be a team player - not to mention have the ability to joke about things that happen on the set while they are still happening on the set. This, however, was not what happened with the film 'Rust'. The shooting death of Cinematographer Halyna Hutchins by Alec Baldwin on Christmas Day 2017 is not just a personal tragedy for Baldwin; it was a tragedy for the entire filmmaking community and for those who worked on the film. While the shooting was not intentional, it was an unacceptable accident, and as a Union Prop Master who has worked at SNL for more than 20 years, I know the film industry better than anyone. Baldwin's lack of diligence and disrespect for other people and for a job can be found in countless other movies and in countless other jobs. I am writing to draw attention to the conditions surrounding the shooting and the lack of attention given to safety and team cohesiveness before the shooting even started. The last time I was on the set of 'Rust', which was shot on the same day as the shooting, we were lucky to get out without being injured and the day was full of fun, and to my knowledge other members of SNL, the cast, crew, and other filmmakers in the area were having a great time as well. I am a union prop master with a background in film and television production for 20 years and have worked in some of the most challenging, dangerous and stressful jobs in the business - I know the value of staying safe and feeling empowered as a team. Roughly 15 minutes after we left the set of 'Rust', we heard news that a shooting was taking place at the set of the film. Before I knew it, I heard about the injuries sustained by the director Joel Souza and Cinematographer Halyna Hutchins. We all knew that Alec Baldwin was drunk, and we were all shocked and saddened by what happened to this young man, who was supposed to be responsible for the safety of everyone in the film, including himself. A few days later, it was revealed that there were more than 12 rounds of bullets that Alec... This means you can expect your payment if you qualified, even if you missed the deadline to file your 2020 tax return, because the IRS will use your information if you don't have a valid 2019 or 2020 tax return. Here are a few things you should know about the stimulus payment: What's next for seniors? As of April 7, the Social Security Administration (SSA) has identified nearly 1 million seniors who don't have valid 2019 or 2020 tax returns. As of the same time, the SSA had collected information on more than 1.7 million households that have seniors on their Social Security benefits who didn't file a 2019 or 2020 tax return. The vast majority of seniors who didn't file their taxes are getting their stimulus checks, according to the IRS. But there is no guarantee that you will receive the stimulus payment even if you didn't file a tax return for 2019 or 2020, because the IRS will only use your information if you don't have a valid 2019 or 2020 tax return. It's still possible to apply for other stimulus payments if you qualify. You can expect your payment when you receive your regular Social Security benefits, most often electronically. If you don't know when your regular Social Security payments will begin, visit the Social Security Administration's web page to get the latest information on your retirement benefits or call them at 1-800-772-1213. What do veterans need to do? Veterans who qualify for the stimulus payments need to have valid 2019 or 2020 Social Security returns. If they do, the IRS will send the payment to them electronically. If you have questions about whether you qualify for the stimulus payment, you can call the Social Security Administration's Veterans Administration (1-800-772-1213), the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (1-800-829-8787) or the IRS (1-800-857-1040). You may also want to visit their websites.

The recovery of stimulus payments is complicated and it can be difficult to know what you are entitled to. We are here to help. The $2 trillion American Rescue Plan contains more than $1.9 trillion in additional economic relief for Americans to help them through the pandemic. That includes a second round of $900 billion in aid for the American people, the first phase of which was sent out last week. Some stimulus payments, such as the first set of checks, are taxed as a tax rebate while others are paid as stimulus checks. The Recovery Rebate Credit is a special type of stimulus payment that gives money to those who didn't receive their stimulus checks last week. The Recovery Rebate Credit can be used to pay off some debts like back taxes and child support. A Treasury Offset Program gives a discount to your tax refund if certain debts are paid back. This means you may have less to pay back on top of your stimulus check. As of February 28th, you still have time to apply for and receive a Recovery Rebate Credit. You do not need to file your federal tax return for this to happen. Apply at https://www.irs.gov/apply-for-recovery-rebate-credit or call (800) 392-7613 if you have questions. Here is an example of how your recovery rebate credit would look on your federal tax return: If you received $13,000 in stimulus checks, you would need to file a federal tax return and use the Recovery Rebate Credit to pay back back taxes and child support. In some cases, you may receive your Recovery Rebate Credit as a credit on your federal federal tax return. In that case, you could get a bigger tax rebate, depending on the size of your state tax return and income. If you receive your Recovery Rebate Credit as a credit on your federal federal tax return, you can pay it back through the Treasury Offset program. The Treasury Offset Program works with the IRS to give you a discount on your tax refund. This is a savings of hundreds or even thousands of dollars a year. Here is an example of how a recovery rebate credit would look on your federal tax return: If you received $13,000 in stimulus checks, you would need to file a federal tax return. You could use the Recovery Rebate Credit to pay back back taxes and child support. If your federal tax return was $100,000, the Recovery Rebate Credit would give you a discount of $20,000 on your federal tax return.

On Monday, the US Senate passed the largest stimulus package in US history - over $900 billion. But what impact will the bill have on the finances of US families? The US Senate passed its third stimulus bill, which contains a $1,400 per adult and $600 per child check. But will this have any effect on household financial stability? This is an analysis of how the new stimulus package will impact households. By John CampbellBusiness and finance editor, Morning Consult As a journalist writing about the economy, I find the focus of political debate and economic commentary on the third stimulus bill to be a bit of a surprise. While the overall size and timing of the bill is good, the lack of data on the impact on households' ability to pay their bills has been striking, as have some of the policy suggestions contained in the bill. When the US Senate passed its first $2 trillion bill in 2009, the debate raged for months over the impact on household finances and consumer spending, including the role of student loans and the potential impact of the massive tax cut. Of course we all liked it when the student loans were forgiven, but that is not the point. What is interesting to note is that when we looked at the financial situation of US families, we saw that it was not the most popular bill, despite the amount it was spent. This is because at that time, there was limited data on the financial situation of US families. This time around, there has been even more focus on the impact of the stimulus package on consumer spending. That is a bit of a surprise, in my view, given that traditional economic data like the GDP and consumer spending data do not provide a full picture of the distribution of savings among the US population. So let's look at the data from one of the most comprehensive sources we have - Morning Consult. It tracks all aspects of the US household finances and its tracking data includes all three stimulus packages in addition to all of the other economic policies in the past 20 years. So let's look at the distribution of savings among the US households. We looked at two different scenarios: first, let's assume we are on a recovery, with the economy growing and consumer spending rising, and second, let's look at an economic downturn. So let's assume that we are on a recovery, with the economy growing and... 1. This time around, there has been even more focus on the impact of the stimulus package on consumer spending. So let's look at the data from one of the most comprehensive sources we have - Morning Consult. 2. For most Americans, tax filing season is always a busy time of year. But in 2020, it's going to be a little bit more stressful for a group of people who won't receive stimulus checks this year: College students who have adult dependents. That means that while their parents will receive the full amount of up to $600 a week, their dependents will not be eligible for the money. The good news is that college students with dependents can receive $300 a month in stimulus money if they file their taxes on time and meet some additional guidelines. So what are you waiting for? File your taxes now if you are not receiving a stimulus payment. A group of Americans won't receive stimulus checks when filing their tax returns this year . Because of their dependency status, they weren't eligible for the $600 a week payment . But college students who have dependents will receive $300 a month in stimulus money if they file their taxes on time and meet additional guidelines . So if you are a college student who has dependents, you should be looking forward to tax season this year, as it will give you a chance to claim the Stimulus money missed due to your dependency status on previous returns .

Americans are hungry for a second stimulus check to help them weather the economic fallout of the coronavirus pandemic. But with the economy improving and unemployment claims down sharply, it looks increasingly unlikely that Congress or President Trump will give Americans a fourth stimulus check at this time. The White House released its weekly unemployment claims report on Tuesday and indicated the number of Americans claiming unemployment insurance fell by 2.2 million in August, the highest drop since April. While that is a much bigger drop than the 12.7 million who applied for unemployment in August, it is still only 12% of the total number of Americans unemployed during the same month. While the economy appears to be getting back in gear, many are still craving a second stimulus check from the White House or Congress to help pay their bills. That's why over 2.8 million Americans have signed a petition for a $2,000 monthly stimulus payment that would be paid out for three months in a row. "We need this now," Change.org petition creator Stephanie Bonin told USA Today. "We are at a critical time, and it's so important to make sure the stimulus checks get in to the hands of those most in need." Bonin pointed out the importance of getting the stimulus check to the people who need it most. In the United States, 2 million more people applied for unemployment insurance in August than in July. Bonin said the reason for the jump is because many Americans had to stop working to care for elderly family members or sick family members during the pandemic.

US bank giant and digital payments platform Venmo is offering check cashing for stimulus payments. Venmo is also waiving fees for cashing government payments, so that users of its app can access their stimulus funds without a cut.

The Venmo app is already a popular tool for cashing government payments, such as SNAP (food stamps) and SSI. However, Venmo has yet to provide cash-back for the second round of stimulus payments being delivered to eligible US adults via direct deposit, paper checks, and EIP cards. Users will be able to access their payments with a verification email, Venmo debit card, or active direct deposit, and location services, including GPS and Wi-Fi. They can also deposit the money directly onto their bank account.

Venmo has partnered with First Century Bank and Insign Money to offer cash-back from the government's second round of payments. The feature is being rolled out across the US.

In fact, Venmo, which is owned by PayPal, is waiving fees on the cash-back feature. This is the first time a major bank and payments service have worked together to provide an app feature. Venmo's partnership with First Century Bank allows its users to withdraw cash from any bank within the network, rather than just First Century Bank. First Century also provides customers with debit cards that can be used with Venmo to cash checks.

Venmo has been trying to grow its mobile payments presence across the US, and the new feature will further expand the utility of this tool for cash-back from government stimulus payments. Venmo users can use their Venmo debit cards to cash checks, or deposit the money directly onto their bank account. It also allows users to withdraw cash from any bank within the network, rather than just First Century Bank. As such, Venmo is starting to take on some of the more established mobile wallets, such as Apple Pay, which only works with Apple Pay on Apple devices. With the new partnership with First Century Bank, Venmo will no longer need to rely on one partner for its cashing of government checks.
