Tiger Woods should have been evaluated for possible signs of impairment before the day he crashed his SUV, experts say.

It is still unclear exactly what led to the crash last week, but authorities are treating the incident as an accident. In a statement, Alex Villanueva, LA County Sheriff, said there was 'no evidence of impairment' in Tiger Woods' SUV. The LA Times quotes him as saying, "We have no cause of the crash as of yet."

In an effort to make the story more dramatic, authorities have tried to make it look like the SUV crashed through a fence and ended up in a wooded area. While the Sheriff's Department acknowledges that there was a fence that was hit in the crash, Woods' car was partially submerged in water and he was found sitting on the ground outside of his SUV a few blocks away, according to the Times.

In the statement, the Sheriff's Department said that the crash was an accident because of what they call 'impairment of consciousness.' That means a driver must not be able to remember what happened to him, according to CNN. The statement even says that the crash was due to "a sudden change in roadway conditions, resulting in a loss of control of the SUV."

The statement also says there is "no cause of the crash as of yet," which again makes it seem as if the incident was completely out of Woods' control and the authorities are just trying to make a dramatic statement that the crash was not intentional.

This is a very unethical way to go about investigating a possible crime. Experts say that if a driver is driving under the influence of drugs or alcohol, they would have a harder time remembering what happened to them. It makes it even more difficult to determine whether or not a person was driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, especially when they were unconscious.

As the Sheriff's Dept. continues to try to make this crash a tragic accident, it does little to help the public. Instead of focusing on what caused the crash and trying to help Tiger Woods and his family deal with the aftermath, the Sheriff's Dept. seems to be focusing on what happened to Tiger's SUV and trying to paint Tiger as the one who caused a crash that he clearly wasn't at fault for.

Experts say they are frustrated with the LA County Sheriff's Department's lack of transparency. They are also upset that there has been little publicity about the case, especially since they say that the lack of transparency is due to authorities' attempts to make this crash seem more dramatic than it actually was.

Tom Brady has done it again. This time it's not just the championship but also the record book. Brady's previous six Super Bowl wins as a member of the New England Patriots 3. Brady holds the record for most Super Bowl appearances, with 10 4. He has won the most Super Bowl MVP awards, totaling five 5. Brady set records for the most Super Bowl pass attempts (421) and completions (277) 6. Tom Brady now has more Super Bowl wins than any other quarterback The first is perhaps the most impressive of the whole list. Brady is the first quarterback to ever win more Super Bowls as a member of the same team than any other quarterback (10). Tom Brady has been in the Super Bowl MVP spotlight for the past week after the Tampa Bay Buccaneers defeated the Kansas City Chiefs 35-10 in Sunday's game. Supporters and opponents of the decision were given a chance to weigh in on the issue in an informal poll conducted by the columnist, who wanted to know which player's accomplishments deserved to carry the trophy on his shoulders. Supporters of renaming the Super Bowl MVP Trophy for Tom Brady said the late NFL commissioner Pete Rozelle is deserving of such recognition for his work. Opponents of renaming the award said Rozelle's accomplishment must be recognized, but that Tom Brady should take the award, or it should be named after someone else who played an integral role in the Super Bowl. "We are all in agreement that Pete Rozelle deserved this honor," David Smith said.

Tom Brady and his new sportswear company The Tampa Bay Buccaneers quarterback is launching a new fashion line with his own personal stylist and two partners . The fashion line will be focused on training clothes and activewear, with the goal to make 'Brady' one of the largest name-sake sportswear brands, comparable to Michael Jordan's Jordan Brand, reports the Los Angeles Times. Brady's business partners are Jens Grede, Skims co-founder, and Dao-Yi Chow, co-founder of Public School New York. They are the ones who will run the brand and will also be its cofounder and CEO. ' We're all looking forward to working together and seeing this vision come to life,' he said. In a statement Jens Grede said, 'I am thrilled to have Tom join our team as the brand's cofounder and CEO. Black Lives Matter Boston is partnering with the Museum of Fine Arts Boston to show that art is a weapon against racism and inequality. Weems is one of the leaders of the movement, which has been inspired by the 2014 death of Trayvon Martin . The House of Representatives has impeached President Trump on two counts: one charge of abusive behaviour and the other of threatening the integrity of the US election. There is no doubt Donald Trump will lose his presidency on the first count, which is abuse of office. But his lawyers have had to work hard to try to convince senators that they have not lost their sense of fairness or impartiality. Trump's lawyers say he was acting within the limits of the constitution in firing Comey as FBI director, in firing his generals and in imposing travel restrictions on foreign nationals in the US. But they will be looking to add a third count: that the impeachment process was unconstitutional. So why do 43 Republican senators vote to convict President Trump? Sen. Pat Toomey, R-Pa., faces calls to censure after voting to convict former President Donald Trump of incitement of insurrection in his second impeachment trial on Capitol grounds. The Pennsylvanian GOP leader is the latest Republican to share the fate of his colleagues who supported Trump's charge of election fraud. Toomey is one of a growing group of Republicans who cast their minds back to a time when a president's impeachment was just a political issue and not a constitutional offense. That time is about to come again, as Trump's trial nears its conclusion. A censure vote against Toomey is being considered by Pennsylvania GOP leadership, although it is symbolic since Toomey is not seeking reelection. The GOP chair, Lawrence Tabas, is planning a meeting to discuss a potential censure resolution against Toomey, who was one of seven Republicans who voted to convict Trump on Monday. He was one of only two Republicans who voted to acquit Trump, along with Sen. Mitt Romney of Utah. Trump was acquitted of the charge of incitement of insurrection but found guilty of other charges, including one of misuse of power.

House Republicans have a pivotal moment of direction this week, after rejecting a conservative push to remove Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's committees. Greene is running for re-election this year in a district that includes much of Arizona and California and has been critical of Democrats and her party for years. Greene's impeachment vote against President Donald Trump is a defining moment for her political future, as she has been widely seen as a potential presidential contender. She has shown support on social media for violence against Democrats and various conspiracy theories. Republicans leaders voted 145 to 61 to keep her committees, and defeated an alternative plan to remove her, in the most significant show of unity in recent months. It means she will continue in her key roles, and likely face tough questions from Democrats on Capitol Hill next week about why she voted against Trump. House Republicans have an important decision this week as they reject a conservative move to remove the hard-right Republican from her committees . Rep. Eric Swalwell, D-Calif., on Wednesday filed a lawsuit against Donald Trump and his son-in-law, former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani, for their roles in the January 6 insurrection at the U.S. Capitol.

He also filed a lawsuit against Rep. Mo Brooks of Alabama, saying the Alabama Republican's actions helped foment violence against the U.S. government.

Swalwell said Brooks and other Republicans made baseless claims of election fraud and attempted to sway President-elect Joe Biden's administration.

The suit accuses Trump and others of "willfully, recklessly, knowingly, or intentionally" conspiring to violate civil rights, negligence, inciting a riot, and inflicting emotional distress on Swalwell.

Swalwell said the insurrectionists broke into the U.S. Capitol building "with weapons, horses, and firearms" during an attack on the House of Representatives on January 6.

The lawsuit details how Trump made false election fraud claims before and after the election, and how other Republican leaders helped spread that false information, including calling election officials and Republican lawmakers, according to the lawsuit.

The American Civil Liberties Union supports impeachment of President Trump for the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol. President Trump is the second U.S. president to be impeached, and the ACLU argues that impeachment is the correct way to remove an executive official for abuse of office. Across the country, many people have been protesting and supporting impeachment of the president, and the ACLU supports those efforts for political and moral reasons. The president's impeachment request has been approved by the ACLU board of directors. The president is a public employee who, by virtue of his position, must abide by the rules that govern speech in the public interest. As such, this impeachment request can only be based on actions taken in the course of his public office. President Trump's speech does not violate the First Amendment. As a public servant he cannot be sanctioned for speech, no more than any other public official. The ACLU's position is supported in part by the fact that impeachment was used in the impeachment of President Andrew Johnson for the murder of Ulysses S. Grant in 1865. Johnson was not a member of the executive branch, and he did not speak for the U.S. The impeachment of Andrew Johnson followed an investigation by congressional committees and an indictment of the President of Murder. Both Andrew Johnson and Trump are public officials who have abused their positions, and the actions of both men, including Trump's speech on Jan. 6, justify impeachment. The ACLU believes it is appropriate to remove the president from office so that he can be tried for the offenses of impeachment.

Daniel Goldman, a former federal prosecutor and counsel to House Democrats in the first impeachment trial of Donald Trump, announces his candidacy for New York Attorney General . Mr. Goldman joins a potentially crowded field, with other candidates including Zephyr Teachout, and state Sen. Shelley Mayer . The former congressional staffer calls himself a committed civil rights advocate and a champion of equal justice . He promises to fight back against what he sees as attacks on democracy, citing "Trumpism" as a continuing threat . Goldman is running unopposed in the Democratic state party, with the goal of defeating Republican Gov. Andrew Cuomo . (CNN) -- A former top adviser to Democrats during the first impeachment trial of President Donald Trump has announced he will run for New York Attorney General. Daniel Goldman tweeted his intention to run as an independent on Wednesday evening. "This is the most important elected office in the state and it's important that we have a new AG who has both the vision and the experience to lead New York into the next era," Goldman said in a statement released by an affiliate of the New York Democratic Party. Goldman, 54, is also a former federal prosecutor and a top aide to House Democrats in the first impeachment trial. The former congressional staffer has been a staunch ally of the president but has publicly criticized some of the president's actions. He said that Trumpism was a "national threat" that was just one of a "continuing threat" against democracy. Goldman, a former congressional staffer in the House of Representatives, is running as an independent . The attorney general is the top law enforcement officer in a state, and is the most powerful law enforcement officer on the federal and state agendas. As such, it is often seen as a battleground state for political office. In New York, the office of AG is currently held by Democrat Andrew Cuomo, who has held the office for two decades. Goldman said he intends to focus on issues like voting rights and reproductive rights, and to fight against what he sees as attacks on democracy, including those from what he calls "Trumpism."

McCain supports Donald Trump's impeachment and says he should be held to account. Donald Trump will not be returning to the Republican fold, but what happens when he is removed from office? Arizona's former Sen. Cindy McCain is pushing for the former president's impeachment, calling the storming of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 as "treasonous." She says Trump's actions were "treasonous," and should be held to account. In her latest column for the Arizona Republic, she criticizes the age of current Republican members of Congress as a problem that impacts their concern for the party's future. "They do seem to be old enough to be in charge of their children," she writes. "I think that they have to think about their children, and how to ensure that they can get a good education and get a good job, and grow up and become citizens." She added: "While I believe in the power of the democratic process to resolve these issues, it is also the responsibility of political leaders to ensure that our society is safe from threats to our democracy." McCain's latest column comes amid a flare-up in conflict between her and her daughter, Cindy, over Donald Trump's actions after he left office. Both McCain and Cindy have criticized Trump's actions since the former president left office, and she was censured from the Arizona Republican Party for endorsing Joe Biden over Trump in the last presidential election.

Republican Representative Michael Guest says the election result should not be allowed to stand, citing widespread voter irregularities in multiple states and significant violations of the legislative will that should be overturned on a case-by-case basis. Mr. Guest challenged the certification of election results in two states citing violations of legislative will, not widespread fraud, he said. Guest said he was a U.S. diplomat and a former professional wrestler.

He said he met dozens of Trump supporters and educated them about the electoral process.

The events that unfolded in Washington D.C. this week are unprecedented in modern U.S. history, Mr. Guest said. Guest said his job as a reporter was to inform people about what is happening.

"As a U.S. diplomat, I want to inform the world about what is happening in the U.S.," he said.

Mr. Guest is from the state's 4th congressional district in West Virginia. His district includes parts of West Virginia, Virginia, Maryland, and Washington D.C. Guest also said that while the election result should not be certified, "we will not take up arms."

Donald Trump is no longer president of the United States of America. In less than 12 months, he and his administration have had more than their share of controversies, but the most significant have been the impeachment proceedings against him, which led to his removal from office, and the coronavirus pandemic, which led to the first economic shutdown of U.S. history. With that said, there have been plenty of other things to talk about during his final months in office, so here are the five biggest stories that have dominated the news during his presidency. 1. Impeachment proceedings led to Trump's removal from office After the first debate, Trump's campaign repeatedly claimed the results had been rigged and he would win the election by a landslide if it were decided based on votes from the popular vote, rather than the electoral college. In October 2016, Donald Trump was elected president in the first U.S. presidential election in a generation to be decided by vote from the electoral college, which is based on votes from each state. In January 2017, the Republican took office after winning 270 electoral college votes over his Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton. During his final months in office, Trump was removed from office twice for breaching U.S. impeachment proceedings. He was charged with obstructing Congress, which led to him being impeached for the second time in December 2019, and a third time in February 2020. Both times he was found guilty of the offence, and the House of Representatives voted to send his case to the Senate, where he faces a second trial. 2. Coronavirus outbreak led to the first economic shutdown of U.S. history On March 27, 2020, President Trump declared the U.S. was at a public health emergency due to coronavirus and called on people to stay at home. The order came three days after the first person in the U.S. tested positive for the virus. By March 30, more than 25,000 people in the U.S. had tested positive for the virus, according to data from Johns Hopkins University. By May, nearly 1 million people in the U.S. had tested positive for the virus and the U.S. had become the worst-hit country by number of cases. In April, the first death due to coronavirus was reported in the U.S. The number of cases in the U.S. increased by more than 600% by the end of April and more than 300% by the end of May. 3. Trump's successor Joe Biden was inaugurated on January 20 On January 20, Joe Biden was inaugurated as the 46th U.S. president. The inauguration was the first to be held without Trump in the White House for nearly 20 years.

On Wednesday, the House began the second impeachment trial for former President Donald Trump for "incitement of insurrection" after he urged his followers to storm the US Capitol on Jan. 6 . The trial included over 140,000 words in the record, with the impeachment managers speaking over 91,000 of those words, and Trump's lawyers contributing 33,000, the Washington Post reported . Impeachment managers also spoke more than four times as much as Trump's lawyers during the trial of his previous impeachment trial . Trump's lawyers spoke about 21,000 words in the first trial . The House's vote Wednesday to begin the trial included a bipartisan agreement to start the proceedings on a Thursday, meaning Trump would be in the room to defend himself . In an effort to prevent Trump's supporters from breaking into the Capitol, the House Speaker's office said that it would be a "safer place" for Trump to be if he remained inside his mansion at Mar-a-Lago, Florida . The second impeachment trial of former President Donald Trump for "incitement of insurrection" has been set to take place in the House of Representatives . Trump supporters stormed the US Capitol on Jan. 6 in an attempt to stop Congress from certifying the results of the November election .

Impeachment: The vote by some Republicans to impeach President Trump is a victory for democracy . The group of Republicans who voted to impeach President Trump on Thursday is a small minority of his party, but that does not mean they represent the whole of the GOP . And their actions, as well as those of their Democrat and conservative backers, will help set the stage for Donald Trump to be removed from office . (Associated Press)

Republicans face an uphill battle to oust Trump from the presidency because the majority of their party will likely be against him. But the vote by 10 Republicans to impeach Trump on Thursday is a victory for democracy and a significant step in the right direction. And it should provide Republicans with a new sense of momentum to get the impeachment proceedings through the Senate and force Trump to step down as president. The vote by some of Trump's allies to impeach him is a vote of conscience, and a victory for democracy, and their actions and those of their Democrat and conservative backers will help set the stage for Donald Trump to be removed from office.

The vote by 10 Republicans is a small minority of the GOP. The party may be in turmoil as Trump fights his second impeachment, but many GOP senators who voted to impeach Trump and put him on trial did so out of a sense of duty, not ideology. They saw themselves as defending the Constitution and the rule of law. Many Republicans believe impeachment will be an effective way to remove Trump, and they hope the process will eventually result in the president's removal from office. But this is unlikely to happen unless more Republicans join the majority of Democrats in supporting impeachment.

Even before the vote, some GOP leaders like Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) appeared to acknowledge this. He has said that the party needs to address divisiveness, change how it runs the party, and that the GOP cannot always rely on Trump's rallies to push issues. If McConnell and other GOP leaders want to see a change in the party after the election, they'll need to start listening more to what the young conservative activists want and working toward that goal, as well as listening more to their conservative base.

The impeachment vote should help GOP turn the page on Trump, and help the party move forward.

Democrats and Republicans have been working toward the same goal for months now. Their actions will set the tone for the post-Trump era and help push impeachment ahead. And, again, if McConnell and other GOP leaders want to move the party forward, they will need to turn the page on Trump.

The decision to permanently ban former President Trump from Twitter was a bold move taken at the highest level, says a CNN legal analyst.

Twitter exec Vijaya Gadde played a pivotal role in the decision to ban former President Trump from the platform, writes David Leitch. Twitter initially suspended Donald Trump for 12 hours before permanently banning him due to the risk of further violence and Gadde took an active role in the decision, Leitch says in his blog. Gadde, Twitter's head of legal, policy, and trust, has been with the company since 2009, and was one of the first people to challenge Donald Trump on the platform.

"I have worked with @DonaldTrump since he was elected president in November of 2016, and every day since," Gadde wrote in a statement on Twitter on Monday. "I remain committed to doing what is needed to ensure that Twitter remains a safe space for all of our users."

David Leitch, CNN's legal analyst, says Twitter had a longstanding reputation of being less strict than Facebook and Google. That reputation was challenged with the Trump ban.

The Turkish government has passed a controversial law requiring social media sites to be regulated by the Turkish government. The controversial Turkish advertising ban on Twitter, Pinterest and other social media sites, which were ordered to comply with the law as soon as possible, has been implemented. Twitter and Pinterest have been banned on Turkey's social media platforms for violating a new law requiring them to have a legal representative in the country, the media regulator said Thursday. The controversial law passed in October requires social media sites to remove content at authorities' request and maintain a legal presence in Turkey. Twitter has been banned from advertising on Turkish social media platforms on Thursday, as it failed to comply with a new Turkish law that requires them to have a legal representative in the country. The new law is designed to give Turkish regulators control over what is posted on social media sites, where the government could order them to remove certain content at the behest of the authorities. Research shows that right-leaning tweets have more prominence on Twitter's Home timeline than left-wing ones, according to a new study.

Twitter's Home timeline shows the most retweets by people who follow a given account.

The new study found that in six out of seven countries, right-leaning tweets were more amplified than left-leaning ones. For example, in both Canada and the UK, right-leaning tweets were more than twice as likely to be retweeted than left-wing tweets. Twitter said that it is unclear why its algorithm produced these results.

The study also found that political content on Twitter was more likely to be amplified on Twitter's Home timeline than through a chronological timeline. According to Twitter, the company does not control the timing of when content is shared on the Home timeline and is unable to ensure that the chronological timeline will not be affected.

Twitter's study looked at tweets from elected officials in seven countries including the U.S., U.K., Canada, Brazil, Russia, Germany, and Japan. The researchers found that political tweets were more likely to be retweeted when they appeared on the Home timeline rather than through the chronological timeline. In the U.S., for example, right-leaning tweets from elected officials were more than twice as likely to be retweeted on Twitter's Home timeline compared to left-leaning tweets. In the UK, right-leaning tweets from the UK Prime Minister were more than 10 times as likely to be retweeted on Twitter's Home timeline compared to left-leaning tweets.

The Washington Post: US Sen. Lindsey Graham wants Twitter to be like other businesses Graham is planning to challenge Twitter ban on President Trump Graham said Friday that Trump had the right to tweet as he did, but that Twitter should also face legal responsibility when it bans users for violating its terms of service . He also said that he believes that Twitter can be held accountable . Graham, R-S.C., would like to see companies, such as Twitter, forced to share their user information with the government if they violated privacy laws . (CNN) On Friday, U.S. Sen. Lindsey Graham, a staunch Trump ally, announced he intends to challenge Twitter's recent ban of President Trump from posting on its platform. Graham said the move should not be viewed as a legal victory for Trump, but instead as a chance for the U.S. to take back control of what happens on social media. He told reporters that he would fight to restore Trump to Twitter and that the president's tweets would continue to be available to the public. On Tuesday, Twitter banned Trump from its platform indefinitely, saying he had engaged in violence against the country. Trump called the decision a "ridiculous attack" and a "slam dunk." Twitter has said the president violated its terms of service, including its ban on inciting violence. He said in a statement released on Twitter Friday that he had no doubt Twitter could be held accountable by the court if Trump violated its policies again. "This is what happens when you have absolute immunity from being sued," he said. Graham said he believes that Twitter can be held accountable for its actions, but that it shouldn't be "absolutely immune from being sued." He also argued that Twitter must share information with the government if companies violate privacy laws. "I think it's possible Twitter would do something similar to what Facebook did when Facebook was selling the data of its users to the political advertisers and campaign groups," he said. "If you can't trust a company, you don't use it."

The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) has released a preliminary report on the causes of the winter freeze that hit Texas earlier this year, leading to hundreds of deaths and widespread power outages. The FERC report found that freezing and insufficient winterizing of generators contributed to 44% of the outage issues, followed by natural gas fuel shortages, which contributed to 31% of the issues. The 28 recommendations made by the FERC address issues related to generator winterization and training. Texas officials and residents are still searching for answers to events leading to the winter outage that left millions without power in Texas. The FERC report recommends that regulators, energy suppliers and the Texas Public Utility Commission conduct annual winterization training and equipment inspections to prevent future outages.

This picture was released by the Texas Transportation Agency on Thursday, January 21, 2016. The blackout in Texas was so severe, that millions have been left without power. The blackout in Texas was so severe, that millions have been left without power. Photographer: Jose Luis Gonzalez/Getty Images

Texas officials say the freezing temperatures contributed to hundreds of deaths, left more than 700,000 without power, and led millions to take up to 6 hours to get power back on. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission released a report Thursday on the causes of what many call the worst blackout in US history. The 28 recommendations are focused on generator winterization, conducting annual winterization training, and monitoring pipeline temperatures. This image shows an outage street in Texas. Officials have been looking for answers to what led to the severe blackout, which many attribute to winter weather.

For years, regulators have tried to crack the mystery of why this happened. FERC released its findings Thursday, and regulators say they now know the main cause of the Texas blackout was "freezing or insufficient winterizing of generators," according to the FERC report. The findings say that 44% of the issues were due to freezing, while 31% were due to natural gas fuel shortages. But most natural gas production and processing facilities were not protected against load shedding, leading to a decline in supply. This picture shows a block of homes during the blackout. Officials are still searching for answers to what led to the blackout in Texas, which many call the worst in US history.

Extremely cold weather hit the United States over the weekend, with some areas seeing temperatures below freezing and others seeing temperatures in the 30s below zero. It was the deadliest winter storm to hit Texas in 25 years, leaving many without power. The scientists who are studying climate change are divided on whether climate change could be making it more likely for extreme cold weather to hit the U.S. and other parts of the world. On one side, climate scientists say that rising temperatures have warmed the Arctic so that the polar ice is melting more easily. The melting ice in the polar regions has led to more severe weather events such as the cold snap in Texas. But experts on the other side of the fence say that warming in the Arctic isn't the reason for more extreme cold events. What are the implications of the extreme cold snap for the U.S. and the rest of the world? The cold snap in Texas caused massive energy demand spikes and blackouts in the state, which is the only state in the U.S. to have had a blackout on Saturday. Image caption A power failure left some communities without power for up to four hours on Saturday Scientists are divided on whether climate change is increasing the likelihood of such extreme cold events. Some argue global warming could make these events less likely, while others suggest warming in the Arctic could lead to more frequent cold spells further south.

While Texas is still recovering from the Winter Storm Uri, another winter storm is heading in from the north.

Texas is most at risk.

NERC says there's a 37% shortfall in energy supplies in the state.

Texas has already experienced its worst winter weather in decades. Winter Storm Uri has knocked out power to nearly three million Texans, left millions without heat, and caused billions of dollars worth of damage, according to the region's governor. Winter Storm Uri, which hit Texas last month with blizzard-style winds, was the first winter storm in more than a decade to hit the state with winds of at least 40 mph. And while the impact of Uri has subsided, another storm is heading in from the north. The North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC) warns Texas is most at risk, potentially facing a 37% energy shortfall, per Business Insider, which notes that this could leave residents in the state without power for months. While most of Texas is likely to be spared the kind of power outages experienced by the Northeast in recent years, the threat from the coming winter weather may not go away. "We are aware of the situation in Texas and are working hard with our energy suppliers and regulators," NERC's executive vice president Mark Olson said in a statement. "We are confident that our suppliers can take the necessary steps to mitigate this threat." The Texas A&M University hurricane expert said that after Winter Storm Uri, a second storm like this could come from the north, but that there was no evidence such a storm was on the horizon. He said the energy demand would be lower, so there would be no need for emergency generators. Aside from the potential for widespread power outages, the report from the NERC also comes on the heels of an uptick in the number of lawsuits being brought against the power company. Some of the lawsuits allege that the company, ERCOT, had a "willful" refusal to reduce the load on its lines, leaving some communities in Texas in the dark when the storm hit. "We are confident that our suppliers can take the necessary steps to mitigate this threat," NERC's Olson said. "We are confident in the resilience of our systems." Citi charged Canadian wind farms for replacement power despite them not having to pay for it, Reuters has learned. The two Canadian wind farms halted their turbines in February during the worst winter storm in Texas in years and claimed force majeure (force of circumstances) under their contracts to protect themselves from the damage, Reuters can reveal. The two companies, Shannon Wind and Flat Top Wind, say Citi ignored their requests to halt billing for the millions of kilowatt hours they were not producing and billed them for the electricity they did produce at higher rates than they could sell at the time. "Citibank is aware that Innergex filed a lawsuit with the U.S. District Court for the Central District of Texas against Citibank," a Citibank spokesman told Reuters in response to the Reuters story. The lawsuit is an attempt to get the bank to stop billing the companies for replacement power it was unable to provide, he said. "We are not aware of any action pending by the U.S. District Court for the Central District of Texas against Citibank." Citi Energy, the energy division of Citigroup, has yet to respond to an inquiry by Reuters. Shannon Wind and Flat Top Wind, subsidiaries of Innergex, halted their turbines in February during the worst storm in Texas in years . The two wind farms claim force majeure, which allows them to stop working during an extreme event that causes their turbines to freeze . The companies are now suing Citi for charging them higher rates than they could sell at the time for the electricity they were producing . Citi has yet to respond to an inquiry by Reuters about whether a lawsuit has been filed against the bank .

Houston Texas's power grid collapsed during severe winter weather in February, leaving hundreds of thousands of people without electricity and causing massive damage to homes, businesses, schools and hospitals across the state. The cause of the power failure is not yet known, but it's clear that the state's power grid has not been this vulnerable in a long time. The storm's power failure devastated the Texas power grid, leaving hundreds of thousands of people without power On February 21, Texas suffered a winter storm, followed by heavy ice and snow on February 22 and 23, which resulted in widespread power outages across the state. In the aftermath of the storm, more than 1,300 people were hospitalized, and 151 people were confirmed to have died. However, BuzzFeed's data review suggests that this could be a much higher number of fatalities, and an analysis by the Texas governor suggests that the death toll could be as high as four times that number. The Houston Chronicle ran an article with the headline, "Lost power could be killing Texas residents." The headline caught the eye of BuzzFeed's data team and drove traffic to the article, leading to over half a million page views, over 200,000 unique visitors, and 4.1 million impressions in the first two days of the story on February 24 and 25. The original article is still available on the Chronicle's website. According to the Texas governor, more than 1,300 people were hospitalized with severe respiratory problems after the storm, which was followed by heavy ice and snow on February 22 and 23. No deaths had been confirmed at the time. On February 24 and 25, BuzzFeed's data team did a simple analysis. We used an "excess fatalities" analysis, comparing the number of deaths that happened during the storm week to those during normal conditions. Our analysis suggests that the February winter storm could have killed between 426 and 978 more people than normal. In fact, the exact number could be higher, because data on how many people are injured in accidents during the storm week does not yet exist. In the aftermath of the storm, 151 people were confirmed to have died. The data team also estimated that the storm week alone could have killed 702 people. The analysis is based on state records in the past decade, and we also looked at other states with similar weather, but without the same widespread power outages that occurred in Texas, to see if they had a spike in deaths. To do that, we analyzed data from each state over the past decade, looking for similar weather patterns to the one we saw in Texas. We found states that experienced similar weather patterns to Texas, but without widespread power outages, like Maryland, Virginia, and West Virginia. Those states did not see a spike in deaths.

Griddy Energy has reached a settlement with Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton over the winter storm of 2016 that left millions of Texans without power. In a settlement announced by Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton on Tuesday night, Griddy Energy is to pay $2.5 million in damages to customers that received very high electricity bills during the storm. The bill was caused when the company offered consumers a 'wholesale electricity rate' to pay for high-priced power generated by the company's own nuclear plants. The agency sued the company after thousands of customers complained about bills ranging from $2,000 to $13,000. "This settlement marks an important step forward in the fight to hold energy suppliers accountable," Attorney General Paxton said. The new settlement will prevent Griddy Energy from billing any of its Texas customers for any future power bills from the storm. In a statement to CNN, Griddy Energy said it "remains committed to providing Texas with reliable, affordable energy for years to come". Griddy Energy will pay $2.5 million to settle the storm bill . The company will also stop billing its Texas customers for future power from the winter storm .

One in four households in Texas has no power, according to Maria Benitez. But in a state with a high concentration of Black and Latino residents, her plight is nothing new. The Austin resident and her family are among a growing number of people struggling with power outages and burst pipes caused by winter storms in Texas that have hit the region hard. Maria Benitez has no power or water after the region's winter storm caused severe winter weather, leaving her struggling in her home with two small children . The winter storm has left Austin, Texas and surrounding areas with severe snowfall, leaving nearly 400,000 people without power . It has also caused hundreds of thousands of people to experience burst pipes . These issues have been exacerbated by extreme weather conditions affecting Texas . The state has seen snowfall as high as 10 feet in parts . Austin resident, Maria Benitez and her two children are among 1 in 4 Texas households without power . Maria Benitez's husband was recently injured after his truck broke down and was not able to get home until after the storms were over . Maria Benitez and her children are now struggling without power and water in a state that has seen severe winter weather in recent years .

Vistra Corp. (NYSE:VIS) issued a new estimate for the cost of a recent winter storm Uri, which hit the Midwest earlier this year. The energy company raised the February estimate from $900 million to $1.3 billion, or an increase of 1,000 per cent. The winter storm Uri was the most severe to hit the Midwest in 25 years, the company said in a regulatory filing. The storm cost Vistra approximately $1.6 billion in January, when it raised that estimate to $1.3 billion, according to a regulatory filing. Vistra also revised its outlook for its 2021 EBITDA and free cash flow guidance. The company said it expects 2021 to see a revenue increase in the low single-digits, with EBITDA and free cash flow falling into the range of $1,475-$1,875 million and $200-$600 million respectively. In a regulatory filing, Vistra said its new estimate for the cost of the winter storm Uri had been calculated using a conservative approach based on the potential for additional legal, regulatory and accounting challenges, the Wall Street Journal reports. "We remain encouraged about the opportunities for growth."

Extreme weather across Texas has caused massive power outages that are expected to last for days, leaving millions without electricity. This is the third winter storm that has hit Texas in the space of a month, and has been named the most extreme to hit the state in more than a decade. It will also push the average temperature below freezing for the first time in nearly six decades, though not to as low as the winter of 1969-70. The rolling blackouts were announced Tuesday morning by the Southwest Power Pool, which oversees the distribution of electricity across Texas, Oklahoma, and some parts of Mexico. The Southwest Power Pool said Texas had no choice but to shut its main transmission lines, which account for more than two-thirds of the state's electricity production, in response to the severe winter storm. "The power grid is down and we cannot restore power quickly enough to meet demand," Power Pool executive vice president and president of Texas, Paul Menchaca, told reporters. "We're working as hard as we can, but we can't restore power on demand at this point." More than two million people were left in the dark across Texas, according to the power company Entergy. While the rolling blackouts caused some economic disruption for businesses, most of the impact came down to inconvenience for customers. "It's going to take days, probably a week, for us not to be able to turn on our heaters. It's going to be cold, and it's going to be hard, but we've got to go through it," Travis County, Texas, fire chief Mike Smith said. The severe weather system that has hit Texas and parts of Oklahoma resulted in more than 3,000 power outages, with 2 million people in Texas without power Tuesday . The Texas Energy Office said the cold spell is the second-deepest recorded in the state . The severe weather system will lead to the lowest temperatures in Texas in more than half a century . Some 1 million people were affected by the severe weather system in the Southwest Power Pool system, which includes Texas, Oklahoma and parts of Mexico . More than 3,000 power outages were reported in Texas and over 3 million people were without power in Oklahoma . The severe weather system has led to the lowest temperatures ever recorded in Texas .

Winterization is a process in which facilities are made weather-proof to handle extreme cold weather conditions.

As a result, the energy consumption is reduced.

This is especially useful for power and gas utilities, which can save billions of dollars each year.

This year, the Texas government is planning to spend about $60 billion to deal with the severe winter weather. This would be the second largest budget in the history of Texas. (In 2013,

the winter weather caused Texas to spend $57 billion on fuel to power homes and businesses.)

The energy industry is calling for the winterization of their facilities to prevent more severe winter weather. More than 75% of Texans say they agree with this idea. But this is more likely to be seen as a symbolic action, rather than a practical one. A poll by the University of Texas at Austin shows that large majorities blame the lack of winterization of power and gas facilities (75%) and the unprecedented nature of the storm (68%) for its impact.

Energy providers in Texas have begun the process of winterization. For example, the Energy Department of Texas has started a project to winterize a gas pipeline that supplies gas to more than 1,000 Texan communities. And the federal government is investing in the winterization of natural gas and power plants in Texas. There are estimated to be about 2.5 billion gallons of natural gas stored in tank farms that could not be used because the facilities are not winterized. This could cause energy providers to lose millions of dollars if they had to sell the natural gas for a higher price. So the companies are working to winterize their facilities.

The energy providers are now planning to spend $60 billion to deal with the severe winter weather. This would be the second largest budget in the history of Texas. The Texas electric utility companies have already taken steps to winterize their facilities. For example, they will be installing more heating and cooling units in homes and businesses. The energy industry wants the government to help pay for the cost of winterization.

Texas governor Greg Abbott has fired the head of its electricity grid operator after a deadly winter storm that left millions without power for weeks amid freezing temperatures . Bill Magness was fired after a deadly winter storm that resulted in widespread power outages in February . Texas governor Greg Abbott has now named Brad Jones president and CEO of ERCOT, the utility . Magness will not be replaced, but a new chief financial officer has been named and a three-year transition has been announced for the company . The storm led to more than 100 deaths and left millions without power amid freezing temperatures in the US state . Mr Magness had faced criticism over his handling of the storm and his decision to turn off the power grid in some Texas towns . The utility said Magness' actions were meant to save lives and prevent property damage . A Texas A&M University Today story highlights that the winter storm has hit food markets in a way that was not seen since the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic. This is due to weather, rather than a systemic supply issue, the story states. Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service research economist David Anderson said that the winter storm has caused supply and demand problems, which has created significant shortages in food. The story is titled: Texas grocery stores are experiencing severe shortages due to severe winter storm . In a column published Thursday, AgriLife extension economist David Anderson said the severe winter storm has caused supply and demand problems for Texas groceries. Anderson, from Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service, said snowstorms are common and have not affected food markets since the beginning of the pandemic. Anderson, an economist with Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service, said while the winter storm has caused supply and demand problems, not a systemic supply shortfall, his team's research suggests the winter storm is the most recent event of its kind that has affected grocery stores. And he suggested that the pandemic would be the next. "As we are watching the effects of severe weather events in Texas, I have to wonder if we have not seen the worst," said Anderson. "We could be looking at a domino effect for the rest of this year, which could produce a significant shortage of groceries for years to come." He added that the pandemic would not be the first major event that has had a significant effect on grocery markets. "I don't think the pandemic will be the first significant event that we have seen in a decade or two that has caused an impact on food markets," he said. AgriLife Extension Service economist says Texas grocery shortages are due to supply and demand issues and not a systemic shortfall . In a statement released Thursday evening, AgriLife Extension Service said it has been monitoring reports from across the state, which has been hit by winter storms, ice storms, and snow. "We are... Houston, Texas (CNN) -- The winter storm that hit Houston and parts of Texas over the past two weeks was one of the worst in the state's history, leaving people without heat, food, running water and power for days. An analysis of how residents coped in Harris County, the area most hit by the storm, found that many were forced to leave their homes due to the lack of hot water and electrical supply, making them more vulnerable to cold temperatures and illnesses like the flu. More than half of Harris County's residents said they lost access to hot water, compared with less than a quarter of Texas residents as a whole. Harris County has some of the highest rates of poverty in the state, with an estimated 36% of residents living below the poverty line, according to the U.S. Census Bureau. Most people were left without running water, power or access to hot water, the survey found. The U.S. census bureau estimates that as much as half of Texas' population will not have access to running water for at least a week after the storm, making it especially dangerous for those who already suffer from water-borne illnesses like the flu.

Media coverage of a missing woman has reignited discussions on 'missing white woman syndrome' Last September, news of an Amazon prime video sex video surfaced that was allegedly directed at a young black woman. Gabby Petito, 23, from Idaho, went missing on August 3, 2017. She has been missing for almost five months. Her disappearance has been covered extensively in the media and has led to widespread public concern about her safety.

The case of Petito, whose disappearance sparked nationwide debate on the issue of missing white women, has received intense media coverage since her disappearance. The story has been reported by multiple outlets, including CNN, the Washington Post, Fox News, and the BBC. A number of politicians from both sides of the political spectrum have also shared their views on the case and have been critical of media coverage of Petito's disappearance.

In fact, the hashtag #missingwhitewomensyndrome has been trending on Twitter since Gabby Petito's disappearance, with millions of people sharing their opinions on the issue. The hashtag was started by the author and activist Lauren Berard in June of this year. As the name suggests, the hashtag highlights media's disproportionate focus on white female victims, neglecting victims of color.

The hashtag trending on Twitter has been criticized by journalists and public figures from across the ideological spectrum. Others have argued that the hashtag is actually a symptom of a larger problem in media coverage of missing women. According to a CNN article written by Lauren Berard and published last month, the term 'missing white woman syndrome' was coined by a woman who worked as a magazine editor when she was a teenager. She felt that media coverage of missing women was skewed by a focus on white women of a similar age to her, and often neglected cases of women of color.

The article explains that although the hashtag was coined by a teenager, the term was popularized by a news reporter. She used the term to explain how the news media's focus on missing women was a symptom of a larger problem in media coverage of missing women.
